PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, on 23 August 1991, I received a letter from Senator Paul McLean resigning his place as a senator for the State of New South Wales. Pursuant to the provisions of section 21 of the Constitution, I notified the Governor of New South Wales of the vacancy in the representation of that State caused by the resignation. I have now received through His Excellency the Governor-General a certificate of the choice by the Houses of the Parliament of New South Wales of Karin Nicole Sowada as a senator to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Paul Alexander McLean. I table the documents. Will the honourable senator please come to the table to make and subscribe the oath or affirmation of allegiance?

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Karin Nicole Sowada made and subscribed the oath of allegiance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the Treasurer's statements on interest rates last Thursday that:

QUESTION.PARA: Further easing now would not affect the economy until 1992, when the recovery should be well under way-a case of too much too late.
And:
If the Reserve Bank and the Treasury thought now was the appropriate time (to ease monetary policy), it would have happened.

I ask the Minister: what changes have taken place in the economy since last Thursday, five days ago, which justify the one per cent lowering in interest rates today? What complementary measures will the Government be taking to ensure that the rate reduction is sustainable? Is the reason for the seemingly panic cut not more to do with shoring up the fortunes of the failing Prime Minister than with sound economic management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is fair to say that, as I recall, there have been no dramatic changes in the indicators relating to the Australian economy in the last week. Having said that, let me also say that the Treasurer and others have always said that there would be a further lowering of interest rates at the appropriate time. Very much in the Treasurer's mind was the consideration that the Reserve Bank should meet and consider this issue, as it did today. It was following that meeting of the Reserve Bank that the further interest rate cut was announced. The Government has always said that interest rates should be set to ensure a modest and comprehensive economic recovery and one in which declining inflationary expectations can be sustained. It would be inappropriate to have left nominal rates at the previous level while the expected inflation rate fell away underneath the nominal rates and we still had a situation of relatively high interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: In trying to put that into perspective in terms of real interest rates, I make the point that the latest figures for 30 August 1991 show low real interest rates in Japan at 3.9 per cent and Australia at 5.5 per cent. On the other hand, Germany has interest rates at 5.3 per cent; France, 5.8 per cent; Britain, 5.8 per cent; Italy, 7.4 per cent; and Canada, 5.4 per cent. In terms of those countries with which we like to compare ourselves and our economic ambitions from time to time-rightly or wrongly-the level of real interest rates in this country is not vastly different from what is revealed in those figures.
On 14 August, Senator Short claimed that real interest rates were at near record levels.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which they were.
—Yes. Senator Hill claimed in the Senate that the Government was increasing real interest rates at the time of the last easing in May. Peter Reith made similar comments.
—Mr Reith to you.
—I acknowledge the correction. This latest cut should be welcomed for what it is-a consistent response to falling inflation.
—You should have done that 12 months ago.

—I would not get too excited about all this at this stage. Since January 1990 there has been an 8 1/2 per cent fall in nominal interest rates. That has been consistent in the last part of those nearly 18 months with a declining inflation rate. That is an achievement which the Opposition should recognise, never having attained any such achievement itself in its many years in government.
—You strangled the economy.

—I am not making the point in relation to inflation; I am making it in relation to inflation connected with interest rates, which is what Senator Short asked me about. Whether there are complementary policies, as he put it, which the Government may embark on is something which will be determined by the Government and announced at the appropriate time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does not the Minister's answer that there have been no significant changes in the economy since last Thursday simply mean that the Treasurer, in his statement last week that a further reduction now would be a case of too much too late, was wrong in his assessment of a fall in interest rates? Alternatively, does it mean that the Reserve Bank rather than the Government is now the sole arbiter of interest rate movements? Will he please answer at least the second part of my question-he did not do too well on the first part-as to what complementary measures the Government will be taking to ensure that the rate reduction is sustainable? If he does not give an answer to that, then the obvious answer to the whole question is that this move has done nothing more than shore up the fortunes of the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me say that the Treasurer's statement this morning, and the complementary statement from the Reserve Bank in particular, referred to subdued economic activity as a reason for the lower interest rates. They talked about the lower rates helping to improve business cash flows and they sought quick action by the banks and other financial institutions in adjusting loans to business in response to this cut.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that the Government consults with the Reserve Bank about these issues. If Senator Short had listened to my previous answer he would have heard me say that, as I understand it, it was the Treasurer's view that he would like to await a meeting of the Reserve Bank before making any further announcements about interest rates. There is no doubt that the government of the day consults with the Reserve Bank about this issue and gets Reserve Bank advice; there is no secret about that.

I do not know the context in which the Treasurer's remark was made last week. I think it was probably made in the context of the lagged effect of lowering interest rates. A further reduction now, as he put it, would be too much too late in terms of the lagged effect of interest rate reductions. Be that as it may, the cut has been made. It is welcomed by the Government; it is consistent with the Government's other policies.

The honourable senator asked me about complementary policies which might be embarked upon by the Government. I gave him an answer to that part of his question, but there was such a hubbub from his side of the Senate that he probably did not hear the answer. Sometimes people on the Opposition side of the chamber get too excited; when the polls go up the excitement goes up and Opposition senators' intelligent contributions to this debate go down. I gave the honourable senator an answer to that part of his question and he can look at it in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to an article in yesterday's Gold Coast Bulletin which refers to an Australian visa stamp placed on the passports of Taiwanese tourists. Is it a fact, as stated in the article, that Taiwan has threatened to suspend the opening of direct air links to Australia if the wording of the visa is not changed? If so, are Australian and Taiwanese officials working towards the solution of this situation and is it expected that the new air links will commence on schedule?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in respect of this matter is as follows: following several years of negotiations, a commercial aviation understanding which provides a framework for establishing Australia-Taiwan air services was signed on 25 March this year. On 28 March Australia-Asia Airlines, a Qantas subsidiary, successfully concluded talks on technical and commercial issues with Taiwan aviation interests and a technical agreement was initialled by both sides. The Taiwan authorities have indicated that the arrangements which have been negotiated are acceptable, but they have yet to sign a technical agreement. A signature is required before airlines from both sides can lodge applications for operating approvals.

ANSWER.PARA: Following an unofficial visit to Australia in July by Taiwan's Minister for Economic Affairs, Mr Vincent Siew, a senior Taiwan official announced that there were no obstacles in the way of the commencement of air services between Australia and Taiwan. However, I have seen press reports-these were reflected in the Gold Coast article-to the effect that Taiwan intends to extract maximum political advantage from commercial deals with foreign companies.

Australia has made it clear to the Taiwan side that our commitment to a one China policy remains firm and that Australia rejects the concept of linkage between what are mutually beneficial economic arrangements, on the one the hand, and issues of a purely political nature on the other.

I have also seen press reports, which are more explicitly reflected in the article to which Senator Colston refers, to the effect that Taiwan has threatened to suspend the opening of air links with Australia until the wording of an Australian visa stamp, which is placed in the passports of people from Taiwan, is changed. Such a linkage would, as a matter of principle, be totally unacceptable to Australia.

I have sought, and have now received this morning, an assurance that the Taiwan side is not, in fact, insisting on a linkage between the relatively small matter of a visa disclaimer stamp and the very significant issue of mutually beneficial air services between Australia and Taiwan. Moreover, I have been informed this morning that the Taiwan side is keen to see air links commence and that the necessary procedures are under way to enable air links to commence within the next month or so.

May I just say, in respect of the visa disclaimer, that its purpose is to make clear that the issue of a visa and its subsequent insertion into a Taiwanese passport does not in any way imply Australian recognition of the Republic of China-so-called-or the status of its officials. Given that Australia's one China policy is now so well understood on both sides of the Taiwan Straits, I have asked officials to report to me on whether such a disclaimer is necessary any longer. I hope to have their report within the next few weeks and I will make my decision at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a statement of his ministerial colleague Senator Cook that the leadership crisis within the Government `turns serious matters of government into consideration of who stands where and which candidate might they support'. With about one million Australians out of work, does not the Australian community deserve a government which is prepared to concentrate on the business of governing rather than who gets the top job?
—Why don't you complete the quote?
—Senator Cook is very sensitive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what Senator Cook said about this issue, but the point of the question is that there is a lot of press speculation about leadership issues in relation to the Australian Labor Party, there is a lot of press reality about leadership issues in relation to the Australian Democrats and there is a fair degree of speculation about leadership issues in relation to the Liberal Party of Australia. The key question in all of this is whether the Liberals, who seek to attain the golden prizes at the next election, can seriously carry Peter Reith with them into that election campaign. There is a lot of speculation about that behind the scenes in the Liberal Party.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Hill's question is couched in terms of `Is the Government not taking care of the real issues in this community? Is it preoccupied with leadership issues?'. Let us look at the issue of unemployment, which has been raised by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it not a real issue?

—Of course it is a real issue. It is a tragic issue about which I and other Ministers are very concerned, but it has to be seen in its proper context. One must look at it in the context of the political opposition in this country. Senator Short was in here two weeks ago, before the Budget, saying that there should be no Budget deficit. Dr Hewson, since the Budget, has been saying that there should be no Budget deficit. The problem for the Opposition is that it has to make up its mind about where it stands on these issues, because no Budget deficit means another 50,000 people unemployed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition has to decide-and it is a real problem for those opposite-whether its role model in politics is Arnold Schwarzenegger or Mother Theresa. That is what those on the Opposition benches have to decide. They are very touchy about those seven years in government when they were wimpish about all these issues and did absolutely nothing. They now have to come in here, be tough and try to psych themselves into being a tough opposition. The sad fact is that they are not very good at it.

The Opposition comes in here with a bleeding heart, talking about its concern and social responsibility. At the same time, Senator Short and Dr Hewson are talking about there being no Budget deficit and a whole range of other measures which-as pointed out by, I think, a good journalist in the Age today, Michael Short-are not relevant to the real questions which are confronting this country. The Opposition is not relevant to the real questions confronting this country.

It is all very well to take advantage of perhaps mild discomfiture on the part of the Government as a result of the attention of the press to an issue which is not as paramount as the Opposition would like to think. The honourable senator should not come at me with these sorts of questions. Unless the Opposition has its policy settings right, it is not fit to be in government in this country, and it has not got those things sorted out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government doing about the recent violent death of an Australian citizen, Yankel Rosenbaum, during race riots in New York and a newspaper report that Mr Rosenbaum may not have received proper medical attention?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like all Australians, and particularly members of the Jewish community in this country, I was very saddened to hear of the senseless murder of Mr Yankel Rosenbaum in Crown Heights, New York, on 19 August. The Australian Consul in New York made representations to the New York City police department to request a report on the incident surrounding the death of Mr Rosenbaum. The Consul also contacted the hospital where Mr Rosenbaum died to seek his medical records and asked to be kept informed on developments, including a report of an inquiry into the hospital's handling of his treatment.

ANSWER.PARA: The Consul also approached the Mayor's office to convey our concerns over the situation and sought assurances that Australians living in the Crown Heights area of New York would receive full protection. Counsel to the Mayor's office assured the Consul that every effort was being made to ensure the safety of all citizens in the Crown Heights area. The Australian Consul in New York has also been in touch with an Australian rabbi and other Australians in the Crown Heights area to check on the welfare of Australian citizens. He has provided registration cards in order to obtain details of the Australian citizens in that area.

Finally, my Department has been in constant contact with Mr Rosenbaum's family since the incident and has provided consular assistance both here and in New York. On behalf of myself, the Government and, no doubt, all honourable senators, I express our condolences for the very sad bereavement and very tragic circumstances that have occurred for Mr Rosenbaum's family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preamble my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support by reminding him that Perth and the metropolitan area of Perth are built on a very shallow, sandy aquifer which provides habitat for wildlife and part of Perth's domestic water supply. Firstly, how advanced are the plans for another runway at Perth Airport? Secondly, is it true that the Federal Airports Corporation has asked the Water Authority of Western Australia to prepare a drainage concept plan for the area? Thirdly, if so, when was this begun and what effect would it have on the wetlands system? There is an extensive wetlands system near the airport. Fourthly, will this drainage concept plan be submitted to the Western Australia Environmental Protection Authority for consideration and will the Western Australian public have an opportunity to respond formally to the plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In exchange for not having an answer to this question, could I instead welcome Senator Sowada to the Senate. I hope that she finds her time here rewarding. As an archaeologist, I am sure she will feel right at home in the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: To deal with control of the aquifer at Perth Airport is a very detailed question. Unfortunately, I did not receive notice of this question until five to two. I am seeking an answer for Senator Coulter and I should be in a position to provide him with that answer at the end of Question Time today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations-and it is with some feeling of trepidation and absolute disbelief, tinged with sadness, that I ask this question of the Minister. Has his attention been drawn to reports that the Opposition intends to cut the ties between Australia and the United Nations International Labour Organisation if the Opposition is ever elected to office? I emphasise the words `if ever'. Is the Opposition spokesperson quoted in these reports the same John Howard who recently attended the International Labour Conference of the United Nations body and took part in its deliberations? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the consequences for Australia's interests if the link between the United Nations body were cut, as Mr Howard has proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Herald-Sun newspaper yesterday reported-and I assume the report is accurate-that Mr Howard has said that the Opposition dissociates itself from the ILO, that if the Opposition were to become government it would withdraw from the ILO, dismissing the views of the ILO Committee of Experts on Australian industrial relations law as `foolish and gratuitous'. The ILO is the United Nations industrial relations agency, and Australia is a founding member.

—On a point of order, Mr President: it is incumbent on the Minister, if he is seriously attempting to address this issue, to explain the context in which this matter arose. As I understand it, it was in relation to a letter leaked, perhaps by the Minister's office, perhaps by someone else, and it was in that context that Mr Howard was dissociating himself from those remarks. I invite the Minister to say that it was not a comprehensive statement in the way that he is portraying it. I ask you, Mr President, to correct him.
—Order! There is no point of order. I cannot be responsible for comments.

—Thank you, Mr President. I note in the point of order a rapid remodification of the Opposition's position. I wonder who speaks now on the Opposition's case, Mr Howard or Senator Alston. The United Nations industrial relations agency is the ILO and Australia, as I was saying, is a founding member. We are one of the few continuing members from the old League of Nations days and Mr Howard, it is true, visited the ILO as part of the official Australian delegation last year and this year.

ANSWER.PARA: In that context his remarks are extraordinary from several points of view. They are extraordinary as remarks of a politician, because what he said, in expressions of contempt for the international body, has the stamp of a Saddam Hussein of industrial relations. The remarks are extraordinary from the point of view of a lawyer who, in this context, is a disgrace to his profession. He is talking about judges of world rank-not by practitioners of industrial relations-who are experts in the field of industrial relations, making a finding as to the relevance of an international convention and as to whether Australian domestic law conforms to the precepts of that convention, which, after all, is a convention that has been adopted in this country since 1973 and a condition on which we have reported to the Committee of Experts since that time.

There are five quick points I should make. We as a country are obligated under international law to ensure that national law and practice are in conformity with the freedom of association convention. That is an obligation imposed on us by our embrace of that convention-a convention which we have ratified for 18 years and which has survived under several different types of government in this country.

Secondly, if Australia were to withdraw from the ILO, we would be a laughing-stock in the world. We would be one of the few countries, and the only developed country, withdrawing from a world body of this sort; we would be a joke in our region; and we would be eliminated from influence in a significant agency of the United Nations. It would be futile, because our obligations under conventions would continue.

Thirdly, we could not withdraw from the freedom of association convention in any case. One can only withdraw from conventions every 10 years. The next opportunity for us to withdraw from this convention would be in the year 2000. Even if we did, we would still be bound by the United Nations Convention on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, which ensures the right to strike. I point out to honourable senators opposite that this international covenant was adopted by the Fraser Government, not by any Labor government.

Fourthly, it cannot be said-as Mr Howard pretended to say or as some other commentators have said-that the ILO does not know. We are required to report events in Australia to the ILO. We do so and have been doing so since 1973. Australia enjoys the unique distinction of being one of the few countries whose members on all the tripartite bodies are on the governing body of the ILO. The employers' body is represented by Brian Noakes of the Confederation of Australian Industry, the workers' body by Martin Ferguson of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the government body by the Australian Government. All of us are on the governing body of the ILO. We help run the show. So the ILO does know what happens in Australia. In any case, this is a matter of judges expressing a view.

Finally, I can say this: Mr Howard's own policy-as I understand it, because it does keep changing-is for workplace bargaining. Under such a system, he argues that there should be no exercise of the right to strike during the period of the bargaining. But that system contemplates the right to lockout and strike when the bargain is being set. Is Mr Howard saying that under his preferred system of industrial relations there will be no rights at all for any organisation, no matter what is happening to it and no matter the industrial circumstances? Is he saying that there will be no rights ever? If he is, let him say that. That is not only a contempt of the ILO but also a contempt of basic human rights principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to reports that the Prime Minister requested Keating supporter Senator Richardson to act as an intermediary between himself and the employment Minister, John Dawkins. Why does the Prime Minister require a go-between instead of talking to his Cabinet Minister directly? Has the Prime Minister completely lost the capacity to influence some of the members of his Cabinet who are Keating supporters? What hope do almost one million unemployed Australians have when the self-confessed compassionate Prime Minister and the key employment Minister will not even talk?
—Order! I am not so sure how much ministerial responsibility there is in the question; however, I call the Leader of the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer that part of the question that relates to my ministerial responsibility-the reference to unemployment. Senator Campbell has asked one of the questions which have been prepared in advance by some Cardinal Richelieu of the Opposition- somebody who sits in a backroom and prepares all these questions.

ANSWER.PARA: I have already answered the second part of this question. That question can be rephrased to read: what sorts of opportunities, what sort of hope, do nearly one million unemployed people have when they are confronted with an Opposition of wimps? They are confronted with no choice. They are confronted with an Opposition which would have no Budget deficit and which would put another 50,000 people out of work on that aspect alone. They are confronted with an Opposition which has had its only political joy in the last few years from rising unemployment. Opposition senators come in here week after week complaining about these issues for which they have a new found social concern.

I just say that the question has to be addressed in that way. What hope would there be for a society which was subject not only to the sorts of policies which the Opposition now espouses but also even policies which would have a more adverse effect on unemployment in this country than the present Government's policies?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Vallentine.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank members of the Opposition for their warm welcome. I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister prepared to investigate allegations made on the SBS Dateline program on 17 August that in June 1991, an inspection group at Maralinga headed by the British High Commissioner, Brian Barber, discovered what Australian scientists believed could be part of the uranium shield or detonation device from an atomic bomb? I also ask the Minister whether the sample was concealed in a safe at Maralinga to avoid embarrassment to the British Government. I further ask whether the Minister could explain why the sample was not immediately sent to the United Kingdom for proper analysis and identification, and why the discovery was not made public. Will the Minister confirm allegations made on the Dateline report that an Australian radiation laboratory report on isotopic ratios at Maralinga was sanitised at the request of British intelligence in 1988-89 because Whitehall feared it would reveal a breach of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty? Finally, I ask whether the Minister--
—Order! Senator Vallentine, this is becoming a speech.
—This is the last part of the question, Mr President.
—It had better be brief. Would you conclude the question, Senator Vallentine?

—Will the Minister explain the proposal from the United States Los Alamos nuclear weapons research centre to undertake valuable research at Maralinga that Australian Government scientists say will be of considerable military significance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not promise that my answer will be as long as the question.

—On the other hand, it might be. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has sought advice on the allegations raised in the SBS program and has been advised that a piece of uranium metal recently discovered at Maralinga has no nuclear proliferation significance. This material was secured at Maralinga pending information from the United Kingdom Government as to its possible proliferation significance.

ANSWER.PARA: Discovery of such items at Maralinga should not be surprising given the extensive program of British nuclear tests that took place there. This piece of uranium was just part of 7,000 kilograms of uranium metal now, in all shapes and sizes, buried at shallow depth at the Kuli site. It was not necessary to send a sample to the United Kingdom for analysis as the United Kingdom Government was able to make an assessment from the information provided by the Australian Government. It is also considered that this material presents no risk to the public while it remains within the restricted area at Maralinga.

Data produced by the technical assessment group, TAG, in its study program was assessed before publication to determine whether it contained proliferation sensitive information. These determinations were based on advice from the United Kingdom Government and the Australian Safeguards Office. These assessments resulted in minor changes to one of the TAG team's study reports in which some numerical data was rounded in response to non-proliferation concerns. TAG scientists had full access to the unrounded data. Publication of the rounded figures had no significant effect on radiological dose calculations or TAG's conclusions.

I can also say that scientists from the Los Alamos laboratories of the United States Department of Energy have proposed a joint program of research at Maralinga to study the geochemical behaviour of plutonium in an arid environment. This is a matter of considerable interest in the United States because of its vast legacy of contaminated military nuclear sites. No decision has been taken on the United States proposal, which follows substantial participation by the US Government in the TAG study program.

While little credence can be given to the interpretations of the scientific opinions by the SBS Dateline program, the program at least provides a timely reminder of the need to resolve the question of rehabilitation of the former British nuclear test sites in Australia following the TAG report. This matter will be shortly raised with the United Kingdom Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, but the Government needs reminding that the British Government has already claimed a complete clean-up in 1967 and 1979. It is surprising that this material was stumbled upon in 1988, the British having claimed that they have already done a clean-up and that they had no further responsibility. In light of that I ask: is the Government prepared to conduct a full and open investigation into these and other allegations included in the Dateline program before negotiations with the British Government regarding compensation are held?

—I have already said that the Government places little credence in any of the interpretations made by the SBS program. We will be raising this matter further with the United Kingdom Government. The rest of Senator Vallentine's question seems to debate the content of my answer. I am advised by the Minister that that is the appropriate response to this question. I do not think there is anything further I can add.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the ALP leadership crisis presently paralysing the Government and, as such, I believe it relates to his responsibility as Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does he honestly believe the statement of his colleague Senator Gareth Evans that `the overwhelming majority of members of the Government and the parliamentary party believe that the issue of leadership has been resolved and should be put behind us', or is he an adherent to the recently reported plan of Senator Robert Ray for the introduction of a third man to the leadership struggle in the form of Simon Crean?
—I think there is probably less ministerial content in this question than the previous one.

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, you made a comment which, with respect, should be challenged. These questions go to the heart of the capacity of the Government to govern. If Ministers are going to be out canvassing support for their particular candidates, the Government clearly cannot govern. In light of the situation where nearly a million Australians are unemployed, surely it is relevant.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I hear and read all sorts of things but they are not to do with my ministerial portfolio and I will not comment further.

—Mr President, I ask this supplementary question on behalf of all those unemployed: does the Minister expect them to believe that the leadership crisis is not affecting the Government's ability to govern, given the acknowledgment by Senator Cook yesterday that the issue is diverting the Government from what it is doing?
—I answered the question earlier. I would not answer a question on behalf of anybody who purports to represent the whole of Australia's unemployed.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. In view of the continuing concern being expressed by stevedoring employers about the current high level of idle time accruing in the stevedoring industry, what action is the Government taking to resolve this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government shares the concerns of both stevedoring employers and, indeed, the unions about the current level of idle time on the waterfront. However, the Government does not agree with the short-cut solutions that have been proposed by some employers, as well as the unions, in respect of providing redundancy packages to watersiders without going through the process of negotiating enterprise agreements. We have steadfastly resisted that course for a year and will continue to do so. The real solution to the idle time problem is to expedite the remaining enterprise agreements. Indeed, the resolution of outstanding enterprise agreements in just the ports of Sydney and Melbourne will solve the idle time problem in Australian ports.

ANSWER.PARA: As I informed the Senate the last time we sat, I expected a level of exits from the industry by the end of this month of around 1,100. That has, in fact, occurred. By the end of last month 1,102 waterside workers had left the industry under the program. The parties are now giving priority to the conclusion of the outstanding enterprise agreements in the ports of Sydney and Melbourne with the completion of the Conaust and Strang Patrick agreements for those two ports. When these enterprise agreements are concluded, this will see exiting from the industry a further 780 redundant employees which will, in fact, alleviate the idle time problem.

I am very pleased to be able to advise the Senate that Conaust advised me this morning that, this morning, negotiations were successfully concluded on the Conaust enterprise agreement for the port of Melbourne. I understand that the actual agreement will be forwarded to WIRA tomorrow for its formal assessment. This agreement will see 218 employees leave that single enterprise by the end of this month.

The Waterfront Industry Reform Authority advises that in addition to those Melbourne and Sydney agreements, other agreements are expected to be concluded by the end of September which will result in another 440 employees exiting the industry. This means that at around the end of this month or early next month I expect that a total of 2,200 waterside workers will have exited the industry which, effectively, will mean that we will have made up the time lost in some of the delays that have occurred this year. I expect that within the next few weeks we will have successfully concluded the agreements for both Strang Patrick and Conaust for the ports of Sydney and Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard that before.

—I hate to be the bearer of more bad news from the waterfront. Mr President, the fact is that I was advised, as I have said before-and I hate to give you this bad news-that the Conaust agreement for Melbourne was successfully concluded by agreement between the union and the employer in Melbourne this morning. I am pleased at this acceleration of the program. I am confident that the waterfront industry reform program will be on track by the time the two-year expiration period for this program is concluded in November.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Since 13 February this year I have been asking about surcharges on commuter aircraft going into Mascot. In the light of the announcement yesterday that Hazelton Airlines-probably Australia's most efficient small commuter airline-will cease services to 14 country towns this week, does the Minister now concede that the additional charges levied as a result of peak period charging were inappropriate, given the parlous economic state in rural areas, which have resulted in a massive cutback in air services to country areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not. Not only was the level of those charges not excessive in respect of the particular impact they had on Hazelton's passengers, but also I have to say that peak period pricing-and I had a totally open mind on this subject, as Senator Brownhill knows-has proven on analysis to be a very successful regulator in making much more efficient use of the runway capacity at Sydney Airport, with or without a third runway. In fact, it has shifted a great deal of the smaller traffic out of the peak periods successfully and, conversely, has increased the number of larger aircraft-that is, the greater number of passengers-utilising the airport during those times. For the advice of the Senate, the actual impact on Hazelton passengers of peak period pricing was $1.34 per passenger.

ANSWER.PARA: It is regrettable that Hazelton has had to reorganise its schedules, although I have to say that it is not an unusual circumstance with a commuter airline. I must say that it is interesting to note that in respect of the ports which Hazelton has discontinued servicing, the absolute responsibility for providing air services for those ports rests with the New South Wales Government which, of course, regulates the intra-State traffic in New South Wales. It might be very interesting-and I would be happy to provide Senator Brownhill with a copy of this analysis-to compare the per cent charges that Hazelton makes in this regulated environment, in which it has a guaranteed monopoly on services in New South Wales, with the deregulated charges that occur in the intra-State services in Victoria and South Australia. It is an extremely interesting comparison.

Regrettably, Hazelton has suffered in excess of a 40 per cent drop in its passenger numbers in the past 12 months. However, on analysis, there is no question that peak period pricing bears a very small part of that overall cost burden. It is true that the total level of Commonwealth charges has increased over that period of time because of the Government's unabashed policy of moving away from where taxpayers generally are supporting services which the majority of them do not use to where user pays occurs in the aviation industry. I would invite the Opposition to tell me that in government, whenever that happens, that is a policy it would seek to reverse. Undoubtedly, the major cause of the regrettable decline in Hazelton's passengers was the current bite of the recession in the rural areas of New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister concede that the cause of the problem is the government charges imposed in the past five years, which have risen from 2 per cent of air fares per passenger to 17.6 per cent and which this year will cost Hazelton $4.2m in imposed government charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, two factors have contributed to Hazelton's problem. A factor is the comparative high fare structure-and that is beyond argument-of the airline. On average, Hazelton is charging between 16 per cent and 38 per cent more for similar mileage over similar routes compared to the deregulated services in both South Australia and Victoria to which precisely the same costs apply.

ANSWER.PARA: Those figures that Senator Brownhill provided are accurate. The Government is moving away progressively from a situation where taxpayers generally, the majority of whom do not use air services, were paying the lion's share of the costs of providing these services-the airlines are getting value for money in that the services they are paying for actually are being provided, and they are extremely expensive to provide-to a situation where the people that are using the airline services bear the cost. The Government will not resile from that. Frankly, I would be astonished if the Opposition indicated publicly that its policy would be to move away from it as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing both the Minister for Transport and Communications and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It follows on from a question I asked in December last year. Is the Minister aware that more Aboriginal women have died from violent assaults in their communities in the Northern Territory and Queensland than Aboriginal men in custody in those States? Is the Minister aware that Aboriginal women have difficulty gaining access to the telephone in situations of personal vulnerability and threats to their safety? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether Telecom Australia has responded to Ann Moyal's report entitled `Women and the Telephone in Australia', which I mentioned in my previous question, which recommends the installation of dual telephone connections in out-stations and remote settlements and a specific women's telephone service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for her continuing interest and pursuit of this extremely important issue. I am aware of the current level of death among Aboriginal women-not just statistically but, of course, personally. There is no question but that Aboriginal women by and large bear the brunt of the very widespread and significant alcohol abuse and the violence that results from that alcohol abuse in Aboriginal communities. They are, along with their children, the principal recipients of the results of that social situation.

ANSWER.PARA: I have pursued the question since Senator Kernot raised it in the Senate. I have been provided with a response from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Research was undertaken by Ms Judy Atkinson into family violence in Aboriginal communities nationally in connection with the national domestic violence education program in 1989-90. The results of this research were published in the form of a booklet and a video entitled Beyond Violence-Finding the Dream by the national domestic violence education program through the Office of the Status of Women in March last year.

The research highlighted the severity of the problem of family violence in Aboriginal communities. Ms Atkinson indicated that more Aboriginal women have died from violent assault in communities in the Northern Territory and Queensland than the total deaths of Aboriginal men in custody in those States. The results of the research are readily available publicly.

Senator Kernot asked about Telecom's response to Ann Moyal's study of women and the telephone in Australia. It is a fact that Telecom actually commissioned this study from Ms Moyal in response to a general lack of research in the area and a positive desire by Telecom to thereby identify areas where Telecom's services could be enhanced and improved. This study was part of Telecom's general funding of research, which was also included more recently in a study of the affordability of the first telephone and the report on social equity in telecommunications.

Telecom is currently considering the results of these studies to address the needs of a range of disadvantaged groups and, in particular, the concerns of Aboriginal women that have been identified by these studies commissioned by Telecom. Telecom has also established the Telecom Australia Consumer Council at national and regional levels, including representation directly from Aboriginal groups in order to ascertain more accurately specific needs of those groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. The report I am referring to by Ann Moyal was presented in June 1990. I wonder whether the Minister would undertake to find out for me how much longer we might need to wait for some positive action?
—I did indicate in my answer that that was the case. I will get a response from Telecom as to when it expects these considerations to be concluded.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services agree with Dr John Deeble, an architect of Medicare, that recent Budget changes will `slowly but inevitably destroy it' and that the changes were `ill-advised, unjustified and ultimately destructive'? Is the Minister aware that the ACTU, the Labor premiers of Queensland, Western Australia and Victoria, the Australian Council of Social Service, the Australian Community Health Association and the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation are all opposed to the reduction of rebates for general practitioners' consultations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the language which has been employed by Dr Deeble and some other critics of the Budget decisions taken in relation to, in particular, what is described as the co-payment for visits to a GP which might be required by the GP or permitted by the Budget decision. It is a fact that the Labor Government remains committed to the provision of the best possible primary health care to Australians so that they can visit their GPs and obtain that care without great financial stress and distress. That will be achieved within the structure of Medicare, as has been a foundation of the social policies offered by this Government since its inception in 1983.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the sorts of criticisms made are such that they ought to be given due weight, and they will be by a committee established by the Caucus only this morning. That committee will deliberate within the guidelines set down by the Caucus in order to achieve an outcome which is fiscally responsible and in fact meets the same bottom line fiscally as was set out in the Budget Papers, and in order to achieve the good policy objectives which have always been before the Government in relation to Medicare, that is, the best possible provision of health care for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce comment on recent press speculation that the partnerships for development program is under threat as a result of pressure from the USA and current GATT negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can comment on that briefly. There were some indications of complaints from the United States about the previous offsets program which was in existence for a very long time. The United States commerce department had some concerns about the implication of offset schemes. The offsets scheme no longer exists in relation to the computer equipment and systems industries and has been replaced by the partnership scheme. That is a voluntary scheme. I do not believe it falls foul of GATT rulings and is unlikely to do so following the renegotiation of trade in the TRIM scheme at the GATT.

ANSWER.PARA: The other part of the question which I think it is important to address in relation to the partnership scheme is, of course, the fact that it was developed well prior to the current GATT Round. It is, in that sense, the grandfather. It is a scheme which winds out of existence over time and I think in those circumstances it should not suffer any disability or criticism of the kind that the honourable senator suggested in his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the negative response to the Government's Budget and, in particular, the fact that Senator Schacht, one of Mr Keating's campaign managers, attributes this response to the absence of the former Treasurer from the selling team, stating that `If he is not up-front, the Government does miss that political salesmanship'. How can the Government govern while people such as Senator Schacht continue to destabilise the leadership?

—That alleged comment by Senator Schacht is a comment, essentially, about the advocacy attributes of the former Treasurer. I would not query those at all. I think the former Treasurer was excellent at arguing particular points and he was certainly very successful in dealing with the Opposition in the House of Representatives. But that is not an issue which goes to the Government's performance as a whole. The response to the Budget, as the Treasurer indicated, is not seen by him as an exclusive instrument of economic policy. That is the right view in my opinion. We will see what the response is to the major issues which concern the Australian people over time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the widespread flooding reported in Cambodia, is the Government taking any action to assist the Government and the people of Cambodia who are affected by the flooding? Whilst dealing with the issue of Cambodia, can the Minister give any details of the recent progress towards a comprehensive, peaceful settlement of the Cambodian dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The flooding in Cambodia is distressingly severe. Over 150,000 people have been left homeless in five provinces, more than 100,000 hectares of agricultural land have been inundated, damage to roads, bridges and irrigation systems is reported to be very extensive, and Phnom Penh, itself, is under threat. Relief supplies of all kinds are needed urgently. In addition, the problem of reaching areas which have been cut off by the flood waters has to be addressed. The Cambodians have requested assistance in both of these areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Given the scale of the flooding and the fact that relief supplies are not readily available in Cambodia, the Government has decided that a relief flight from Australia is warranted. Accordingly, a RAAF Hercules will be made available for this purpose and will travel to Cambodia by the end of this week. The Hercules will take a number of flat-bottomed aluminium boats for delivering relief supplies in flooded areas. It is also likely to carry high energy biscuits, shelter materials, sandbags and cooking utensils. The composition of the cargo is still being finalised.

We are also proposing to send in an Australian disaster response expert with the relief flight. We will monitor the Australian assistance and examine possibilities for further Australian support. I have approved an amount of up to $200,000 in the first instance to cover these costs.

On the subject of the settlement process, it is possible to give a very long answer but, under the circumstances, I will keep it short. I simply say that we are very pleased indeed with the progress that has been made in the meeting in Pattaya, which has just concluded, involving members of the Supreme National Council and the representatives of the Permanent Five members of the Security Council.

The parties went to Pattaya on the SNC's agenda with three of the most difficult unresolved issues in the draft text agreed by the permanent five in November last year, namely, military arrangements, measures against the recurrence of genocide, and sovereignty issues relating to the role of the UN in the transitional period up to the elections in relationship with the SNC.

As has been reported, the SNC reached virtually full agreement on all three issues at that meeting. Some aspects of the military arrangements and the question of the voting system to be used still remain to be resolved, but there is no reason to believe that these will not be manageable. They were lesser issues than the ones that were resolved at the last meeting.

There are now very firm grounds for confidence that the settlement process is almost complete. Prince Sihanouk will lead an SNC delegation to the UN General Assembly later this month and there will be further discussions with the Permanent Five representatives there. Assuming that that forward momentum is maintained, there is now a reasonable prospect of reconvening the Paris conference at a ministerial level to conclude a comprehensive settlement by either late October or early November.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Testing of Portable LPG Gas Cylinders

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 June Senator Patterson asked a question relating to gas cylinders-a topic which the Opposition is good at, I suspect. The question related to the testing of portable LPG gas cylinders. The burden of Senator Patterson's question at the time, as I recall it, was whether the pressure of imports of faulty cylinders, amongst others, was responsible for the difficulties of an Australian company situated in Victoria.
—Australian companies have to have tubes tested.
—If I can answer the question, I will.
—If you know what the question was, and obviously you do not.
—All right, I will not bother. I ask leave to incorporate the technical answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: On 21 June 1991 (Hansard, page 5323) Senator Patterson asked a question without notice about the inspection of imported gas cylinders. Her concern was that whereas all Australian made cylinders are subject to testing, imported cylinders are only tested at random. The answer to that question is, as I indicated in my previous reply to Senator Powell on 18 June 1991, that all cylinders are required to undergo the same testing procedures at authorised testing stations.
There have been, however, some suggestions from sources within the industry that some States may not be policing this requirement for imported cylinders as diligently as their regulations require.

The question of the inspection of imported pressure vessels and boilers, including LPG cylinders, was discussed at a meeting of the pressure equipment industry which my Department convened in Sydney on 15-16 August. The purpose of the meeting was to examine the regulatory environment faced by the industry, and to formulate steps to achieve a national regulatory framework for the industry. The meeting was attended by regulators, manufacturers and end-users of pressure equipment.

On the question of imported LPG cylinders, it was acknowledged that some imported cylinders slip through the regulatory net, due mainly to lack of resources within the regulatory authorities. However, the regulatory authorities also confirmed that consignments of faulty imported cylinders had been detected and destroyed. The meeting also agreed that my Department, in consultation with the regulatory authorities, should examine ways of ensuring compliance with the testing requirements including traceability of faulty equipment to manufacturers, suppliers and overseas approval bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 August, Senator Kemp asked me a question-a very tendentious question, if I might say so-about aid to the ANC. I undertook to further check one aspect of that. The advice that we now have from the International Committee of the Red Cross confirms that the ICRC has not received any allegations of torture or ill treatment at either the Dakawa or Mazimbu camps-the two ANC settlements where Australia has been funding training and education activities through relevant non-government organisations. Accordingly, I stand by the assurance I gave in the course of the earlier answer that there is no foundation for the imputation that Australian aid funds have gone to such establishments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter asked me earlier in Question Time today how advanced the plans were for another runway at Perth Airport and whether it was true that the Federal Airports Corporation has asked the Water Authority of Western Australia to prepare a drainage concept plan for the area and, if so, when it was begun.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to Senator Coulter's question is that the Federal Airports Corporation has no plans at present to build another runway at Perth Airport. However, a future requirement for another runway has been recognised in the master plan which deals with the longer term needs of the airport. The FAC has advised that there were discussions with the Water Authority of Western Australia some time ago about proposals by the Authority to drain hill areas for redevelopment in the context of a review of the master plan for the airport. The FAC is not happy with the proposed drainage concept plan and the matter has not been taken any further in the last 10 months.

The Federal Airports Corporation believes that it would be possible to drain the surrounding areas in such a way as to complement the wetlands area rather than adversely affect that area. The FAC has written to State and local authorities and various interest groups giving them an undertaking that the Corporation will enter into full dialogue with them before any action is initiated for the wetlands area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 August, Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me a question about existing arrangements for testing imported foods for certain residues. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the national imported food inspection program introduced by the Government in July last year, a range of imported foods is tested by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) to ensure they meet Australia's food safety standards.

The foods to be covered by the program are classified by the Imported Food Risks Advisory Committee (IFRAC) according to the risks they pose to human health. IFRAC is comprised of a number of specialists representing the NHMRC, Federal and State Health authorities, consumers and importers.

To this point, in assessing risks to health posed by various foods IFRAC has concentrated on the more dangerous microbiological contaminants and it is therefore true that only limited testing for chemical residues is presently being undertaken.

In its future risk assessments, IFRAC is expected to focus more on residues in food. Foods will be included for point of entry testing where there is a significant health risk. Obviously, however, Australia could not justify imposing a testing requirement without evidence of risk.
I am advised that AQIS will refer the Honourable Senator's concerns about organochlorin residues in processed fruit and vegetable imports for IFRAC's early consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Childs (from 104 citizens), Senator Gareth Evans (from 186 citizens), Senator McMullan (from 80 citizens), Senator O'Chee (from 33 citizens) and Senator Short (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Durack (from 31 citizens), Senator Powell (from 31 citizens) and Senator Vallentine (from 31 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by IACO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator McMullan (from 180 citizens) and Senator West (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life to all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b) lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c) cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is increasingly unable to fulfil its responsibilities to provide independence, integrity, quality entertainment and commercial-free services.
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be funded in such a way for these responsibilities and obligations to be maintained.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Increase the annual funding base of the ABC by a minimum of $32 million;
(2) Guarantee adequate and properly indexed funding to the ABC for the next three years on an agreed basis with the ABC;
(3) Maintain the legislative prohibition on corporate sponsorship and advertising on the ABC.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesmanlike leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn baby.
That the right to life of all innocent human beings is the most fundamental of all human rights.
That the first duty of the Parliament and of the Government is to protect this right to life.
That in 1989/90 alone Medicare subsidised 69,587 abortions at a cost to taxpayers of $7.8 million.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will protect the right to life of unborn Australian babies by ceasing to subsidise abortions through Medicare by passing the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990 and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aidex 1991
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX `91. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX `91, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX `91.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
