SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1991 Budget has been brought down at a time when Australia is in the deepest recession that it has been in for 60 years. It is a Budget which should have been about growth, job creation and alleviation of the misery and hardship incurred by the people of Australia over the last eight years of this Hawke-Keating Government. It should have been about jobs, jobs and more jobs but, instead, this Budget is about fewer jobs, more unemployment and more hardship for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget forecasts an increase in unemployment from a figure of around 10 per cent to a figure that will peak, according to the Government, at 10.75 per cent and, for the year as a whole, will average 10.5 per cent. Everyone knows that those figures are underestimates of the real level of unemployment in this country because, taking all factors into consideration, the number of unemployed in Australia today is in excess of one million people. What this Budget really is about is a self-preservation job. It is more concerned about preserving one job in Australia-the job of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-than ensuring jobs for average Australians.

Since the Budget we have seen, and for months preceding it we saw, nothing in terms of government in this country but division, leadership squabbles, and leadership tensions and battles that have absolutely obliterated from the Government's mind any approach to rational economic policy or indeed any other policy making. This Budget was another lost opportunity; a great loss for those million Australians who are unemployed and those further people who are destined, in the Government's own words, to join the dole queues.

The unemployment benefit payment figures in this Budget are in excess of a staggering $5 billion. Indeed, they are closer to $7 billion. There has been a doubling of unemployment benefit payouts in this country in the last two years. The number of jobs lost in Australia in the last 17 months under this Government is no less than 322,000. Over the last 12 months the drop has accelerated to the point where almost 1,000 Australians have lost their job every day of the year. Almost 1,000 Australians every day of the year have found their jobs destroyed by the policies of this Government, by the ineptitude of this Government and by the fact that this Government is not concentrating on governing Australia. What this Government is concentrating on is its leadership-internal ego-tripping disputes.

A party that deliberately engineers, pulls the levers and creates more than one million unemployed persons cannot call itself, by any stretch of the imagination, a Labor Party. This is not a party for labour. This is not a party for any Australian. This is a party for the destruction of the economy and through that the society we have known throughout most of our federation.

It is a destructive act that has not occurred just because of the present Prime Minister-one of the chief architects though he may be. It certainly has not occurred as a result of the appointment of the new Treasurer (Mr Kerin), because he has not been Treasurer long enough to do that, although his performances in recent days-particularly the extraordinary confusion brought to money markets as a result of his statement only five days ago that we did not need an interest rate cut, that it would be inappropriate and that it would be too little too late; followed by the announcement today by the Government of a one per cent fall in interest rates-have seen him beginning to show the ineptitude of his predecessor.

Although this Budget was brought down by Mr Kerin, it is a Hawke-Keating Budget. There is no way, despite the former Treasurer's attempts to rewrite history and his role in the economic policy formulation of this country over recent years, that he can absolve himself from the responsibility of being the chief architect of the economic policies that have brought more hardship, a greater loss of jobs and a more rapid rise in unemployment in this country than at any stage in the last 60 years. In my own State of Victoria the situation is desperate. For six months now unemployment in Victoria has well exceeded 10 per cent. Indeed, male unemployment is closer to 11 per cent. Victoria is worse hit than many other States, although several States are in a similar position and virtually every State of Australia is suffering the same problem.

It was only a few weeks ago that the new Treasurer, Mr Kerin, gave a speech which was regarded by some as a fairly seminal speech about social justice. It was a good speech. It was worth reading because it tried to expand the horizons a little. The Treasurer said in his speech to the Irish-Australian Chamber of Commerce:
. . . the most effective anti-poverty policy ever implemented has been sustained economic growth. It has brought increased social justice to hundreds of millions of people on our planet.

That is absolutely right. If a government is concerned with social justice; if a government is concerned with compassion; if a government is concerned with jobs and providing people with the opportunity to increase their living standards to be able to live the sorts of lives that we all want and aspire to and, even more, want our children and grandchildren to aspire to, then growth is the sine qua non. What does this Treasurer do? This Treasurer and his predecessor and the Prime Minister for the whole period-Prime Minister Hawke-have presided over policies that have produced exactly the opposite to what Treasurer Kerin is saying is required in terms of social justice.

The thing that I find absolutely incredible is that so divided is the Labor Party, and so divided is the Government, that they want to toss out the Prime Minister because they think he is too old and is getting a bit like Methuselah, and replace him with a person who has been the greatest architect of the greatest disaster-the greatest causer of hardship to Australians-in Australia's history. I find that absolutely incredible.

As I said, this Budget is a Budget of lost opportunity. There is a great deal that this Government could have done for the people of Australia. Sure, there is no quick fix; sure, there is no magic pudding: it will be a long, hard slog. But unless we start making policies that will turn Australia around-that will provide hope, incentive and opportunity for people and businesses alike to invest and get on with doing the things that we all want to do-then the task will be so much harder in the longer term.

It is a Budget of greatly missed opportunities. A great deal could have been done. There could have been a much tighter approach to government spending and fiscal policy. The Government's own spending policies have blown out enormously, not just because of unemployment benefits but because it did not have the guts, the courage or the ability to take the necessary steps to rein in its own situation. As a result, interest rates will be considerably higher than they otherwise would have been. This year the Government will have to sell $11 billion worth of bonds in the bond market. That is more than a doubling on last year. If there is to be any recovery in the economy in the course of 1991-92, it will come very late in the piece. The bond selling operation will compound the difficulties of any recovery. It runs every risk of cutting off the recovery, in the same way as has happened time and again in the past.

There has been no attempt in this Budget to tackle the foreign debt problem or our balance of payments problem. There has been no attempt to tackle the real problems that we face. The Government should have made a meaningful start by reforming the tax system. It should have lowered the overall rate of tax; reduced personal income tax; abolished the stupid wholesale sales tax and replaced it with a fair and equitable goods and services tax; provided the necessary compensation to pensioners and low income earners in that sort of situation; and given flexibility to the labour market-all the other things that we know are needed. In 1983, in this chamber Senator Richardson said:

I might say that the Labor Government was elected primarily on the issue of unemployment. It recognises its responsibilities in this area and if it fails over the years to meet the problem of unemployment it will not be elected again and it will not deserve to be.
Amen to that. The voters of Australia will say amen in trumps when the next election is held.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the debate today to 1 hour and 10 minutes and that each of the seven senators participating in the debate will be limited to 10 minutes. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask the Clerks to set the clock accordingly. I call Senator Maguire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: -This afternoon we are having a special debate on the 1991 Federal Budget. We are canvassing the various issues and the parameters involved in setting the Budget for this financial year. The Budget proposes a deficit-that is, an excess of expenditure over revenue-of $4,700m. I might point out that this is a cyclical and not a structural deficit. It is not one that reflects longer term factors. It is simply a deficit that reflects our position in the economic cycle due to the impact of the automatic stabilisers-that is, changes in revenue and outlays reflecting the current economic position. We are not talking about a longer term deficit. We are not talking about permanent changes in policy on the expenditure or revenue fronts which impact on the final bottom line of the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: This year the Budget provides for 2.6 per cent real growth in outlays. In other words, spending in the Budget will grow 2.6 per cent faster than the inflation rate in the community. Of course, the inflation rate is now very low. Revenue, however, will fall by 4.1 per cent in real terms. So the net result is a Budget deficit. For the edification of Senator Short, this is the first Budget deficit in five financial years at the national level in Australia. In the last four financial years the Hawke Labor Government delivered Budget surpluses. This is something the Liberals were totally and utterly incapable of doing in all their years in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the adjustment in the figures for last year?

—There was still a surplus of nearly $2 billion. Senator Tambling is very sensitive about this; he does not like hearing the truth about his Party's record. For four financial years in a row this Government has delivered a Budget surplus at the national level in Australia-something those opposite were totally and utterly incapable of doing in all of their years in office.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that, in the Budget, revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product-that is, revenue in relation to Australia's national income, if you like-is equivalent to 24.5 per cent. However, when the Liberals were last in office, revenue was not 24.5 per cent of gross domestic product; it was 26.1 per cent.

So, on the basis of this important indicator, Labor is clearly not a high taxing party. In fact, the record under the Liberals shows that Federal government revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product was 1 1/2 percentage points higher in their last Budget than now. We hear continual rhetoric from the Liberals about government spending. The reality is that government spending in this Budget, as a proportion of gross domestic product, will be 25.7 per cent. In 1982-83, the last year in which a Liberal-National Party coalition Government was in office, Budget outlays were 28.8 per cent of gross domestic product. So, clearly on the basis of those figures, Labor is not a big spending, high taxing government. The reality, as we have seen time and time again, is quite different from the Liberal Party rhetoric on government spending.

It is very illuminating to look at the specifics of the Budget in terms of where the increases occur in government spending. Across-the-board there is a 5.7 per cent monetary increase in spending. The highest growth areas include a 29 per cent growth in law, order and public safety; and a 17 per cent growth in general and scientific research, which is part of the Government's clever country policy. We are trying to underpin the longer term viability of Australian industry by boosting research and development spending in the Australian community. The Budget provides for an increase of $19 1/2m for stages 1 and 2 of the cooperative research centres program. There is a 10 per cent growth in education outlays and so on.

One of the new initiatives, the better cities project, comes under the heading of housing and community amenities. There is a 9.7 per cent growth in that area; in other words, 9.7 per cent compared with an average growth in spending of 5.7 per cent. An amount of $56m has been allocated this financial year for improving urban infrastructure and urban public works and renewing facilities in our large metropolitan cities.

Of course, this Budget contains important revenue measures. These measures include the first full financial year impact of the income tax cuts which began on 1 January this year. They involve increasing the tax free threshold-that is, the amount of tax exempt income-and reducing the marginal rates of tax. This financial year those income tax reductions will cost the Budget $1,100m. But the reductions are not offset by any changes in the Budget; they are not offset by any expenditure cuts. The Budget provides for personal income tax cuts of $1,100m this financial year.

One of the items that is clearly ignored by those on the other side is the large reductions in wholesale sales tax which will occur this financial year. As a result of Government policy, more and more inputs used by business for production purposes-that is, raw materials, capital equipment and so forth-will be exempted from sales tax. As a result of those moves, the Budget revenue will be $200m less this financial year, rising to $375m less next financial year.

This important measure will help business contain costs by freeing a lot of the inputs-the raw materials and the capital equipment used in production-from sales tax. Goods used in storage, handling and dispatch at goods producing premises will be exempt from sales tax. Pre-production items will be exempt. For example, all goods used in research, development, engineering and technical design will be sales tax exempt in this Budget. Honourable senators who represent or reside in rural areas will be pleased to know that this Budget will, as a result of the sales tax changes, completely exempt hand tools used in agriculture and the fishing industries. The total cost to revenue of those measures this financial year is $200m.

I should point out that the Budget does not contain a consumption tax. This afternoon Senator Short talked about the Liberal Party policy of introducing a consumption tax should it ever be elected to office. It is absolutely and abundantly clear that there will not be a consumption tax-that there will be no tax on food, clothing or footwear introduced by this Government either in this Budget or in future Budgets. This is a Liberal Party policy. Our Budget will not make every Fletcher Jones, Sussan, Williams shoes, and Betts and Betts shoe shop a branch office of the Australian Taxation Office. The reality is that that is what those opposite are going to do. That is what they are on about and that is what their policies will lead to.

I point out that those opposite are making a pilgrimage regularly to New Zealand. They rush over to New Zealand to see what has been happening under the conservative Government in that country. Time and time again they make the pilgrimage across the Tasman to see what has been going on under the conservatives in New Zealand.

I point out what would happen to the price of books in Australia if that group on the other side of the chamber were ever elected in this country. I will show what would happen to the price of books in Australia. I have here a book from the Department of the Parliamentary Library. The Australian price is $9.95. The New Zealand price is not $10.95 but $19.99, including a goods and services tax. This is a Penguin book retailing in Australia for $9.95. The New Zealand price is $19.99, including a goods and services tax.

These are the people opposite who want to bring in a goods and services tax. They want to copy New Zealand. This is what they want to do: they want to tax the book industry. The reality is that they will put a tax on knowledge in this country. That is what is happening in New Zealand right now. There is a $10 difference in the price of a quality paperback book as a result of the introduction of a goods and services tax in New Zealand. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pick up where Senator Maguire just finished off, with his shout across the chamber that we this side of the chamber would impose a tax on knowledge. That is an ironic statement coming from a man who represents a government which has just broken one of its promises to the students of this nation not to increase the HECS in excess of the rate of inflation. Instead, what this Government did in this Budget, about which he was trumpeting a few moments ago, was increase HECS in excess of $140 over the indexed cost of education. What this Government has done is intellectually, morally and politically dishonest.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no surprise that Senator Maguire comes in here and tries these half-baked half-truths in an attempt to hoodwink the Australian populace. The truth is-and Senator Maguire has to accept this fact-that eight years of this Labor Government have destroyed the economic fortunes of this nation and have turned a generation of young Australians to a future of despair and desperation. How is this being done? It is being done through a massive and staggering youth unemployment rate and through a government that has no policy to deal with the creation of jobs or to deal with the jobs that it wipes out by the thousands every week.

Senator Maguire, the much touted economist from the Government's back bench, finds himself curiously at odds with Senator Button, the Minister representing the Treasurer, and indeed with the Treasurer, Mr Kerin. Senator Maguire's opening comment was that the Budget had gone $4.7 billion into debt and that we should not worry because this is not a structural deficit but a cyclic deficit.

That is an interesting view of economics from Senator Maguire. The Treasurer, Mr Kerin, on the 7.30 Report on Budget night said that it was a structural deficit. I quickly consulted Hansard. On Wednesday, 21 August, Senator Button said in response to a question from Senator Short:
I have consistently maintained in this place that it is a structural deficit caused by the recession.

That is a curious interpretation of the facts from Senator Maguire. If Senator Maguire cannot even work out whether it is a structural deficit or a cyclic deficit and if he puts himself at odds with his own Treasurer and with the Leader of the Government in the Senate, what credence do we give to the other statements that he makes in this place? What credence do we give to the other statements of a man who has deliberately tried to hide the facts about the stark economic truth of this Government's policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one else gives him any credence.

—It is exactly as Senator Short says: nobody else gives him any credence. Senator Maguire's latest stunt of waving around a book and saying that the difference between the price of a book in Australia and its price in New Zealand is based solely, 100 per cent, on the fact that there is a goods and services tax in New Zealand is ludicrous. He did not even have the honesty to quote the price in Australian dollars for the book in New Zealand. He used a New Zealand dollar price and an Australian dollar price and tried to hoodwink the populace and those of us in the chamber into believing that the price difference is due to a goods and services tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Maguire is going over to sit next to Senator Jones. Senator Jones might finally be setting him straight. I will set Senator Maguire straight because Senator Maguire does not have the honesty--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the book.

—He does not even know the Standing Orders. He cannot interject from a seat other than his own. He does not have the honesty to talk about youth unemployment. Senator Maguire might not like it, but I will talk about youth unemployment in my State of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the facts about youth unemployment in Queensland? In June 1990, 80,300 people aged between 15 and 19 years were in full time employment. In June 1991, 12 months later, how many young Queenslanders aged between 15 and 19 were in full time employment? There were 56,100. This Government, in the space of 12 months, wiped out 24,000 full time youth jobs in my State of Queensland. It is not just confined to Queensland. It is not just my State where this Government has wreaked its economic havoc. It has done so in Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia, Tasmania-everywhere across this nation, where we have seen the results of an eight-year flirtation with the policies that this discredited Labor Government has tried to advocate. For example, in Brisbane, 11,800 full time youth jobs were wiped away in a year. Across regional Queensland the effect of this has been just as bad, if not worse.

The fact is-and those opposite do not like acknowledging it, but it is true-that it is the young people of this nation who suffer in a recession. If they have just left school and go for job interviews, the first question they are asked is, `What is your work experience?'. If they are young and they answer honestly, most of the time they have to say that they do not have any work experience. The employers then say, `I do not have a job for you'.

The sad fact is that the young people of this nation will bear the brunt of this recession. Young people in this nation have the highest unemployment rate across all groups. Twenty-seven per cent of young people in Queensland looking for full time employment cannot find a job. Over a quarter of the young people in Queensland are consigned to the unemployment scrap heap by a party that calls itself the Labor Party. Twenty-seven per cent of young people in Queensland are consigned to the unemployment scrap heap by a party that puts up people like Senator Maguire, with their half-baked half-truths, in an attempt to hoodwink the populace from what everybody knows is the truth, although those on that side might not like to acknowledge it.

There is a social cost to this youth unemployment and I will tell honourable senators about it. In Cairns, 56 per cent of all crime is committed by juveniles-people aged 18 or younger. It is no surprise that the reason for this is that Cairns and the far north have one of the highest unemployment rates in Queensland, and it impacts on young people. It is no surprise that, in a town where there is the highest rate of single parent families in Queensland and an excessively high unemployment rate, there is an alarming youth crime rate. All of those young people who commit a crime and are apprehended have a blot on their life from now until the day they die. Those young people have been driven there because of the failed policies of this Government.

I do not believe that any government has a right to impose by design a recession that discriminates against young people-the future of this nation. I do not believe that any government has a right to consign people to the scrap heap, be it the unemployment scrap heap or the social scrap heap, because they were foolish enough as a result of the unemployment rate and a lack of opportunity to commit petty crime, juvenile crime.

This Government has no right to do it; no government has a right to do it because the young people of this nation are the future of this nation. If this Government destroys the hopes and aspirations of young Australians we can have no hope for better standards of living across this nation. We need to tap into the powerhouse of Australian youth. We need to create incentive and we need to let young people know that there is a reason for striving; there is a reason for trying to do better for themselves. But this Government has cruelly kicked their aspirations in the teeth.

This is the Government that, in the middle of a recession when one million people are out of work, is imposing a tax on jobs. This is the Government that will strangle the hopes and ambitions of hundreds of thousands of school leavers this year by throwing them into an economy which does not have any jobs and into a job market which will shrink at an ever-expanding rate as the Government taxes the life out of small business. This is the Government that comes before us and parades its social conscience. This is a Government that ought to be wholeheartedly ashamed of the things it has done to this nation. Over eight years it has destroyed the strength of this nation, over eight years it has sapped the willpower of this nation and over eight years it has destroyed the economic future of this nation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Labor Government was first elected to office nearly nine years ago. Two weeks ago it brought down a Budget which has done nothing for the unemployed-now approaching one million people. We see the occasional improvement in one set of figures, only to see the next show a continuation of this country's endemic current account problem. We are bumping along on the bottom of a recession-cum-depression. The Government's economic performance makes a sheer mockery of the notion of repaying the Australian people for their faith in the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government clearly bases its policies on whatever is politically or economically opportunistic at the time. Over the years we have seen the Government twist and turn on economic policy. In 1983 the Hawke Government had a policy of fighting unemployment first through the assistance of the so-called accord. This has since changed to the balance of payments being the Government's main economic concern, followed, most recently, by a `fight inflation first' policy. It is really a case of the Government making the best of a bad economic situation.

Nobody believes the inflation target of below 4 per cent was a goal that this Government always intended to reach. We did not hear about it until it had occurred. I cast my mind back and I checked the Hansard of 16 March 1982, in which Mr Hawke is recorded as having stated:
Firstly, that it-
he was speaking of the then Fraser Government-

would stop the ludicrous and obscene ritual in which it engages each month of trying to pick one element or other out of the statistics and to confect some fantasy which puts an unrealistically favourable perspective on the employment and unemployment situation in this country; and, secondly-and as I say, relatedly-that the Government would accept that it has been obstinately wrong-headed in its economic diagnosis and prescriptions and that it would now move positively to undertake policies and programs calculated to improve what has developed into both an economic disaster and a social tragedy.

His words must come back to haunt him. Lower inflation is the result of the worst recession since the Second World War. This Government has literally driven the country into recession through a policy of record interest rate levels from mid-1989 through to late 1990. We have seen a record number of bankruptcies, particularly among small businesses, and a rate of unemployment of around 10 per cent. I believe that there is another one per cent hidden in the invalid pension figures as well. There are 220,000 people, on the Government's own admission, who are about to receive disability support pensions, and I believe that more are hidden in those figures. Clearly, the Government has an extremely poor overall record on economic policy.

What kind of winners are the Australian people where this economic mess is concerned? From the very first major economic disaster of the Hawke Government in 1985 when economic activity collapsed, inflation began to accelerate and the value of the Australian dollar collapsed, followed by a debt explosion, and every Australian has paid dearly. Today the Reserve Bank of Australia announced a drop in interest rates of a full one per cent. Obviously, the Government has panicked in an attempt to stimulate employment and it is an admission that recovery will be even slower than it anticipated in the Budget Papers which were released only 13 days ago.

The unemployed are suffering particular hardship. Let us pause for a moment to examine the unemployment figures. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) clearly has a short memory. In 1983 he clearly believed that youth unemployment was something not to be tolerated. He said, `No Australian government should be forgiven for creating the levels of youth unemployment of the last couple of years which cannot, and should not, be tolerated'. We have heard this afternoon the passionate speech from Senator O'Chee, who is representing those young people. Again, it should be emphasised that this situation has occurred because of the Hawke Labor Government's policies.

The levels of youth unemployment involving young Australians aged 15 to 19 years who cannot find full time jobs are now far greater than at any other time in our history. Yet this Labor Government still has the temerity to paint itself as the true party of full employment. In the past 12 months alone, 129,200 young Australians have lost their jobs. That figure represents the biggest 12-month loss of jobs by young Australians ever recorded. What has Mr Hawke said about that? On 18 August 1982 he said:

. . . we will be dealing with the single most important and potentially dangerous issue confronting our country; that is, the total collapse of the labour market and the increasing permeation of our society by the devastating cancer of unemployment.

I hope that he reads his words again. Nine years later it is clear that this Government has no economic answers or vision for Australia as this country moves into the 1990s. It is a party which is too riddled with factional battles and leadership tensions to summon the will to take the decisions which are really necessary if Australia is to escape from its economic morass.

Instead of interminable leadership bickering and quick-fix solutions to economic problems which are largely of their own making, the Prime Minister and his Ministers should go out and talk to those unemployed; talk to the people in the community-the manufacturers, the farmers or the miners who are trying their hardest to compete in international markets. Where is the urgency in dealing with such important matters as excessive transport costs, excessive waterfront and shipping charges, unnecessary government regulations and red tape, black bans, go-slows, stop works and labour market deals? All of these problems only serve to impede Australia's progress in the world.

Meanwhile, Mr Hawke and Mr Kerin find their time consumed by fighting a rearguard action against Mr Keating's leadership ambitions rather than concentrating on Australia's dire economic problems. Who is calling the shots? Two weeks ago Mr Kerin said that there was no need to lower interest rates and now, two weeks later, we have a complete turnaround. Did the chicken farmer Treasurer have all of his feathers plucked by the Keating vulture, is it the Keating chicken-hawk or is Hawke a chicken? I am not too sure. Does the Treasurer now have any feathers to fly with after that attack?

His Budget is in tatters. The appalling performance of selling the Budget must be making Government senators cringe. The performance of the Prime Minister and Mr Kerin on The Midday Show was pathetic. With one million people unemployed, we have the obscenity of the Prime Minister paying $1.4m for a harbourside house in Sydney and talking about compassion with tears in his eyes. He talks about the pity that he has-which he alleges that we did not have-for the unemployed, while he spends $1.4m on a harbourside house. Where did he get the money? What deal was done to allow a Prime Minister to spend $1.4m to pay for a harbourside house while the country is in such dire economic straits?

Why has the Government not done something for the unemployed? It is obvious that government expenditure must be cut rather than relying on interest rates to cut private spending. The Government should reshape our tax system in order to restore incentives and also remove the damaging bias against our badly needed export industries. The Government should also boost national savings. The Budget 1990-91 has failed on all of the above counts. There are still no signs of the Government finally showing the determination to tackle the real issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue that I wish to address today is of great importance and was a matter announced in the Budget 1990-91. I refer to the continuation of reform of superannuation that this Government commenced in 1983. Superannuation is one of the most fundamental reforms that the Government has undertaken over the past decade.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the election of the Federal Labor Government, superannuation in this country had a number of undesirable characteristics. It was largely confined to those persons who were in the higher pay bracket. The tax on superannuation was 5 per cent-an issue that I will come back to in a moment. Because superannuation was largely confined to those who were higher paid, it meant that persons in the lower paid bracket, overwhelmingly women, had no superannuation provisions at all. Superannuation was also characterised by high commissions and agents' fees. Superannuation was characterised by minimal prudential provisions in the way in which it was administered. For our increasing ageing population who will be facing the prospect of a real decline in the value of their pensions in the future because we will not be able to afford to continue to pay pensions, it was imperative that the issue of superannuation was tackled in a cohesive, well planned and fair way.

I mentioned earlier the 5 per cent tax that existed on superannuation. At that time the tax had a fairly perverse effect, in that those persons who were not receiving superannuation-that is, those who were lower paid-were artificially subsidising the superannuation of those who possessed it: the higher paid. That was an absurd and ridiculous outcome.

Over the last eight or nine years, this Government has set about a number of fundamental reforms to superannuation. The reforms included the encouragement and development of industry superannuation funds through the accord process and the establishment of minimum contribution levels of 3 per cent. As a consequence of those developments, the coverage of the work force by superannuation has risen from a little over one-third to some 70 per cent.

Included in the latest announcements were significant further reforms of superannuation. The Government has announced its intention to ensure that by the year 2000-01 a minimum of 9 per cent of payroll is contributed into superannuation funds, the current level being 3 per cent. This is to be phased in over the next nine years in a responsible manner. It is to be phased in by ensuring that employers in small business with payrolls of under $500,000 are not affected by this provision until 1993-94. For larger employers with payrolls greater than $500,000, the tax, already at 3 per cent, will commence at or rise to 5 per cent in 1992-93. I hasten to add that many of those large employers are already contributing 5 per cent-in some cases much more than 5 per cent-and, therefore, the provision will not hit large business in a significant way for the next two or three years. To phase in superannuation in that way is economically responsible. We should remember that at the present time employers are required legally to pay a minimum of 3 per cent. Unfortunately, many are not meeting their legal requirements; they are breaching the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't got any money!
—Senator O'Chee would do well to remember that the current 3 per cent minimum contribution was a deferred wage payment.
—They can't pay it; they're broke.

—Senator O'Chee cannot complain about that because it is workers saving for their futures. Senator O'Chee would do well to remember that it is not employers' money but employees' money. Those opposite have fudged that issue in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other announcements that have been made, significant changes have been made to the prudential control of superannuation. I have already mentioned the sorts of characteristics that superannuation featured prior to 1983: minimal prudential controls and high commissions and agents' fees. It was very hard to obtain publicly information on the supervision of superannuation. A broad feature of the Government's approach to prudential control is its determination in the area of competition policy to develop a prudential framework which will foster rather than inhibit competitiveness within the superannuation industry. It aims to ensure that many of the secrets that have been kept hidden are exposed.

In terms of enforcement powers, the current arrangements for the regulation of superannuation rely on the taxation power, the result being that the only sanction that can be used against the funds for failing to comply with the regulations is the withdrawal of tax concessions. This is a disproportionate way in which breaches of the regulations should be dealt with. New regulations are being developed to ensure that when there are breaches the penalties paid are in proportion to the breach. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission will continue to regulate access to tax concessions and will continue to be the primary regulator in respect of superannuation arrangements.

I refer to the entry requirements in the superannuation field. Unfortunately, in the past, persons who have been convicted in this country of certain offences have been able to be involved in superannuation. The Government is considering measures to control the entry of such persons and their involvement in the superannuation industry. The measures under consideration include requirements that those dealing in corporations law who have convictions in respect of dishonest conduct or who are bankrupts be excluded from key positions in the management and control of superannuation funds. That is a highly desirable development.

It is important that additional prudential requirements for funds and institutions offering pensions and annuities continue to be developed. It is important that further resources are made available to the ISC to ensure that there is adequate auditing and observation of prudential standards in the superannuation industry.

There has been an increased emphasis on industry education. All too often, as we have seen with company directors over the last few years, people have not been adequately educated in respect of their responsibilities. The introduction of approved education and minimum training standards for trustees of superannuation funds is another feature of the Government's latest announcements.
These are the sorts of issues that have been outlined recently in the development of a cohesive, well-planned, fair and cost effective superannuation policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is sending them broke.

—It is interesting to note that those opposite have taken the tack that it is sending employers broke. In response to that interjection, I have already outlined the responsible way in which this provision is being phased in, taking into account the economic conditions in this country. What is the policy of those opposite on superannuation? They do not have a policy. For the last decade, those opposite have been making policy on the run, such as it is. The Opposition spokesman, when he is challenged to put up a comprehensive retirement policy for superannuation for people in this country, does not have a policy, which is an incredible situation. Superannuation is one of the most important issues facing the future of retirees in this country and the Opposition does not have a policy. Add to that the irresponsible approach of those opposite in the way in which they want to spend those superannuation funds. They have made wild and untrue accusations about this Government's approach.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of honourable senators to a recent media interview with a Liberal Party spokesperson in Tasmania. It makes very interesting reading. Those opposite talk about responsible expenditure and investment of superannuation funds. Last week on the 7.45 a.m. news on the ABC, Mr John Cleary, a well known non-spokesman on financial matters, said to a reporter:
The Government has been called on to implement an ambitious plan to refinance its loan program . . .
I have to say that it was a loan program that arose as a consequence of the catastrophic economic condition that the Liberal Party left Tasmania in. Mr Cleary went on:

There will be in Tasmania over the next ten years between $700m and $2,000m of occupational superannuation funds that will need to be invested on behalf of Tasmanian workers. At the moment, there is no guarantee that we intend to use those funds to pay off the debts of Tasmania.
(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The unemployed are in danger of becoming the forgotten section of our society. We have to keep repeating the figures to remind those opposite that there are 831,900 unemployed in Australia-almost one in 10. The Government has admitted that this figure will go higher, that unemployment will rise to over 10 per cent in the coming year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Labor Government is to be condemned for engineering a recession that has cost more than 300,000 jobs since July last year. Then we have to keep reminding ourselves that more than 150,000 of the young people of Australia, the men and women of tomorrow's work force, are unemployed, and many of them have no prospect of ever obtaining a job. Almost one in three of our young people are unemployed today compared with 20 per cent a year ago, or one in five. In particular, the Hawke Government has to be condemned for eradicating 130,000 full time jobs for teenagers over the last 12 months with the result now that almost 40 per cent of teenagers are seeking full time employment in this country with very little hope for their future.

New South Wales is the only State in the country with a conservative government and it is the only State with unemployment under 9 per cent, but even here there are almost a quarter of a million people out of work. In New South Wales more than 50,000 young people are out of work, and again this is lower than the national average. But the situation is critical in my own city of Newcastle, where 30 per cent of all teenagers are unemployed.

The 1991 Budget was disastrous for our forgotten unemployed in Australia. The Budget Speech was a lame duck apology to the Australian people for the recession that the Hawke Government engineered, which has caused so much anguish to families, especially those with one or more of their members amongst the forgotten brigade of unemployed. Budget Paper No. 1 tells us that:

The Australian economy moved into recession in mid-1990 and the labour market deteriorated sharply from late 1990 onwards. The downturn has been longer and more severe than forecast at the time of the 1990-91 Budget.

One has to ask why the downturn in the labour market was not foreseen. The Opposition kept telling the Government that it would happen; not only would the Government not listen, but also it refused to take appropriate corrective action. Not only was the Budget in 1991 disgraceful but it was also a Budget of no hope for the forgotten sector, the unemployed. Budget Paper No. 1 includes an economic outlook that states:
The moderate pace of recovery and the lagged response of employment . . . is expected to pick-up-and the unemployment rate to fall-only slowly from mid-1991-92 onwards.

That is the news for the unemployed in the Budget. The Budget says to the unemployed, `You have no hope until the end of this financial year; you have little prospect for employment before next year; and more Australians will be joining your ranks'. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had this to say to his fellow Australians who are out of work:
If my Government had not taken action to slow the economy unemployment might have reached 18 per cent.

What sort of consolation is it, when already unemployed, to be told that it might have been 18 instead of 10 per cent? `Be grateful to me', says the Prime Minister, `because I could have made even more of you unemployed'. He has not any answers for the unemployed. He does not tell them how to get jobs or where the jobs of the future are going to come from; nor does he have any answers for his own Labor members of parliament on how they going to hold their seats in the next election with unemployment above 10 per cent. No wonder so many of them are worried. They will not be here after the next election.

We know that unemployment will not rise to 18 per cent. That is simply a ploy by a worn-out Prime Minister. He comforts someone with a broken arm by telling him it could be worse; he could have a broken leg as well. But I suspect-and I hope I am wrong-that the unemployment rate might be higher than the Treasury was prepared to admit in Budget Paper No. 1.

Independent forecasters have been predicting that unemployment will reach 11 per cent by the end of 1991 and will still be as high as 10 1/2 per cent by the end of 1992. The Government has been looking to a few industries to lead us into recovery, in particular the housing industry. The builders are worried that the increasing fear of unemployment is preventing many people from building or buying houses. So little has the Government done to ease unemployment or improve employment that it has continued to make the task for employers even harder. Employers are faced with wage deals being demanded by the ACTU and the more militant unions, and they are faced with a superannuation levy that will cripple many of them and cost the country a further 100,000 jobs.

We do not get much help from the new boy Treasurer (Mr Kerin). His answers on superannuation are very vague. He tells us that it is enormously complex and that a lot of work has to be done yet. There will be a White Paper a little later on, by which time it will be too late for many employers and the new ranks of the unemployed. The Treasurer and this Government do not have any answers. They say, simply, `Trust us, you 10 per cent of the unemployed. The economy will be in good shape for the next federal election'. The Treasurer's message is, `Hang on', but I say, `How do you hang on if you are unemployed? What if you are one of the young unemployed? What hope is there for you?'.

The traditional youth employment sector, for example apprenticeships, has not increased in the last 10 years. There have been no increases in apprenticeships since 1980. Young people face the situation that the number and nature of jobs have halved in the last decade. The young now carry a disproportionate share of the recession burden. They have no jobs, no say and no hope. They face an inheritance of entrenched unemployment, falling living standards and the burden of massive international debt-and there is worse. The collapse of employment for young Australians is a lot worse than the official figures indicate. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the increased plight of young Australians in the last decade.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The official figures, which have been incorporated, show that youth full time jobless rates stand at present at 28.5 per cent, the highest rate of youth unemployment since the Great Depression. But we all know that there is a high level of hidden unemployment. There are far more jobs being lost than there have been official increases in unemployment. The opportunities for young people in this country are declining and will continue to decline unless drastic action is taken.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some actions that the Government could be taking, and some proposals have been advocated by leaders in business: increased funding for post-compulsory education; guarantees that all young people can be assured of a place in school or TAFE after year 10; and the introduction of a credit transfer system between TAFE and universities. But far more than this is needed. What we need to do in this country is create more jobs. We need to give young people hope and we need to give families hope so that parents can provide adequate support and care for their children. We need to create equality of opportunity, not equality of outcomes. We need to manage an economy where all Australians have a right to expect just rewards for their efforts. When the Liberal-National Party coalition is in government, that is just what we will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent Budget of this bickering, quarrelsome, riven with division, in its last days, Labor Government has condemned this country to a fetid legacy of 10.5 per cent unemployment, from which no fundamental turnaround is expected for at least 24 months. This failed Government can no longer conceal the truth. Australia's unemployment rate has burgeoned, so much so that the unemployed in our communities have come to expect that, like a scar, it will be with them until the hereafter. Let us make no mistake about it: unemployment is Labor's Achilles heel and it will most assuredly see this Government fall, without grace and unlamented, from office. Australia and its communities deserve no less than to be rid of this scourge of a government and they will be rewarded, I am sure of that.

SPEECH.PARA: But today I want to talk about people, not figures, because the reality of unemployment is not about numbers or statistics, rising or falling. The reality of unemployment is about everyday people with whom we mix on a daily basis. I want to talk about unemployed people and about what happens to them when the Labor Government they thought was going to help them lets them down, and lets them down badly.

Unemployment in Australia is a catastrophe that goes quite beyond mere statistics, number crunching or back-room bean-counting. Unemployment is not merely a problem for blue collar workers or Australia's youth. It has silently and in sinister form crept into middle class Australia and crippled the abilities of professionals, clerks, middle managers and those who work in factories. It has left few Australians untouched.

We hear alarming stories on a daily basis from national care agencies, detailing the tragedy which has befallen thousands of families. We see the eager queues each morning outside social security departments and Commonwealth employment offices, and we look at the faces of desperation and sadness in those queues. We hear of personnel managers at car plants who had to hand out final notices on a Friday to workers, only to receive their own the following Monday. We see accountants whose firms have gone down the gurgler front up to the social security office only to be told that they have to wait five weeks for security.

We see family men and women in their forties who were retrenched nearly two years ago, who have completed numerous training programs, but who still are unable to find a job. This is what the Labor Party calls compassion. What does a couple on a combined salary of $40,000 and a mortgage to match do when both have been retrenched within six weeks of each other and ended up on unemployment benefits of $254 a week? Well, one waits and watches the bank foreclose on their house and one sits and watches them lose everything for which they have worked all their lives. One watches their lives crumble and inside one can only feel pain. But what one is secretly feeling is that one is glad one is not out there on that queue.

What does one say to lend support to a bright young tertiary graduate who has made more than 150 unsuccessful applications for employment, or to the thousands more besides who will graduate this November and not be able to find any job at all so that they can pay their rent and put food on their table? What one says to them is, `Next time vote with your feet. Vote this Government out and keep it out.'

Let some Labor politicians experience the harsh reality of unemployment, without their mates remaining in office to prop them up with `jobs for the boys'. We have heard the replacement Treasurer, Mr Kerin, frankly speak of no relief in the forthcoming two years for those currently without employment. That in itself is devastating not only for those already unable to obtain employment, but for those who expect that they may be pushed aside on to the lengthening queue in the coming months.

The real tragedy is that no-one can reverse this trend in the shorter term. By early next year, the numbers of those who have been unemployed for more than 12 months will have swelled to a quarter of a million. Again this is an example of Labor's compassion. It is entirely unacceptable. These people will quickly be regarded as unemployable by their own society. Their confidence will wither and their skills base will be lost to their communities.

It is already quite clear that Australia has accumulated a mass of people for whom there is no future and no hope as a result of this Government's policies. Robert Hudson, the Executive Director of the Victorian Council of Social Services, is correct when he asserts that full employment can be created only through the correct mix of policies. But what we have had from the incumbent Government is irresponsibility and the wrong mix. The current mix is not providing a solution to the unemployment problem and, as a result, increasing numbers of ordinary Australians are hurting and suffering.

The Australian community should not have to endure a protracted period of debilitating unemployment. The successful industrial economies of Japan, Sweden and Germany invest far more in skilling their work force and getting unemployed people back into work than we do in Australia. With this most recent Budget, despite the touted increase contained within it in employment and training programs, expenditure per head of unemployed is about 20 per cent less than that provided by the Fraser coalition Government in the 1982-83 recession. It should be remembered that the 1982 recession was caused by the compounding effects of international recession and two successive massive droughts, whereas the current recession is a direct consequence of wrong-headed policies initiated by this Government.

People are hurting everywhere. In Adelaide, for example, 30 per cent of our jobless are young people, but employers cannot advertise positions for them because of anti-discrimination laws. One newsagent in suburban Adelaide is looking for four juniors, but equal opportunity laws prevent his seeking them. Instead, when he advertises he is not allowed to set an age range and would in all probability be inundated with unsuitable candidates. Instead of the Government assisting this employer to keep four workers away from the dole queue, it is making sure that they stay on it, while laws make it difficult for him to get on with the job of staffing his newsagencies. Nanny state legislation like this is not assisting either employers or workers to survive the recession. It is ensuring that they become part of it.

Unemployment in South Australia at present is real and significant and treads water at 10.4 per cent. It has risen 3 per cent in just one year. But real and profound problems such as this require up-front and well-reasoned responses. That has not come from Labor governments, State or Federal. Even the Prime Minister's great mate, the de facto Cabinet member Bill Kelty, has told trade union officials that he does not believe the Federal Government will win the next election unless it reduces Australia's unemployment rate. It is a sad reality that this Government and its leaders are more concerned about keeping their own jobs than in ordinary Australians being able to keep theirs. That is why we have seen the panic reduction in interest rates of one per cent today.

If the Government had established the economic preconditions for a sustainable fall in interest rates, especially preconditions to improve Australia's productivity and international competitiveness, then this fall would be very welcome. But it has not done this. On the contrary, over the past couple of days, we have heard the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), who is sitting here in this debate, defending 100 years of cultural baggage in industrial relations in admitting that the Government will establish an industrial court and remove sections 45d and 45e from the Trade Practices Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true. I have not said that. Get it right.

—In other words, one of the few defences which employers have against the predatory practices of powerful unions will be removed. I see that the Minister is very sensitive about what the Government plans in industrial relations. As Senator Sherry said earlier in the debate, the Government is also to legislate, as announced in the Budget, for further superannuation imposts on employers, which will again effectively be a tax on employers-effectively a Commonwealth Government payroll tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Why would businesses take the risk of hiring additional workers in this sort of industrial climate? We believe that the fall in interest rates today will not be sustainable. It is a panic move on the part of the Prime Minister to allay the fears of his `nervous nelly' backbenchers and head off yet another challenge from that lounge lizard Luigi Locarno, the member for Blaxland.
