INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present an addendum to the annual report of the Department of the Senate for 1990-91.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the addendum be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 31 May 1990, I table the following reports of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare together with the transcript of evidence which were presented to the President on 8 August 1991: Transport of Livestock Within Australia, Equine Welfare in Competitive Events Other Than Racing and Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.

The three reports entitled Transport of Livestock Within Australia, Equine Welfare in Competitive Events Other Than Racing and Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry which have just been tabled are the final reports of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare.

As the Chairman of the Committee, I wish to comment briefly on each of these reports. The first report deals with the transport of livestock within Australia and contains 20 recommendations on the welfare of animals being transported by road, rail and sea. It is not surprising that the Committee's report concentrates on road transport as this is now the dominant mode used for domestic transport of livestock.

The Committee makes several recommendations encouraging a more professional and uniform approach to the transport of livestock by road. In particular, the Committee is of the view that all drivers of vehicles carrying livestock as part of a commercial transport enterprise should be properly trained and possess a suitably endorsed vehicle driving licence. The report addresses specific animal welfare concerns including the use of electric prods, the duration of journeys and loading densities. The Committee also heard considerable evidence on the transport of horses in doubledecker vehicles and is of the view that this practice should be banned.

The second report prepared by the Committee addresses the welfare of horses in competitive events other than racing. As indicated in the report, much of the evidence lodged with the Committee concentrated on equine welfare in rodeos. The Committee, however, does not support calls for the banning or phasing out of rodeos, but is of the view that significant improvements should be introduced to safeguard the welfare of horses and other animals involved in rodeo events. In particular, the Committee considered that only contract stock-that is, stock prepared for and familiar with events-should be used in rodeos. The Committee also encourages State and Territory governments to introduce regulations for the welfare of animals used in rodeos and to develop procedures to collect statistics and information on major injuries and fatalities of animals during rodeo events.

The report on equine welfare also addresses animal welfare concerns in eventing, endurance riding and shows, in particular. The Committee dealt with issues such as the use of prohibited drugs, veterinary supervision, rider education and responsibility and the need for further monitoring of injuries and fatalities.

The third report of the Select Committee is entitled Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry. As noted in the report, the inquiry into this matter began in 1988 and the current Committee did not have an opportunity to resume work on this subject. Therefore, the report is ,not as comprehensive as the current Committee would have wished. Nevertheless, the Committee does address some general issues relating to animal welfare such as the use of the whip, the racing of two-year-olds, jump racing, track design and ergonomics. For example, the Committee does not support a total ban on the use of the whip in thoroughbred racing. The Committee accepts the use of the whip as a guide or control. However, it does not condone the use of the whip to inflict pain on a horse for no other purpose than to make the horse run faster. The Committee makes several suggestions as to how the use of the whip might be controlled or reduced.

The Committee could not agree on the implications for animal welfare of jump racing. Some members of the Committee consider that there is an inherent conflict between jump racing and animal welfare and, therefore, that this activity should be phased out over the next three years. Other members of the Committee considered that animal welfare concerns can be alleviated if improvements to jump racing facilities and practices are introduced.

Over the last nine months the members of the Select Committee have participated in many hearings, inspections and meetings in order to complete these reports and a report on culling, which was tabled earlier in the year. I would like to thank the members of the Committee for their very valuable contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks made by Senator Burns, the Chairman of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare. This is rather an historic occasion in that I believe that this is the first time that three reports have been tabled together. Also, this is the final occasion on which the Select Committee on Animal Welfare will report to this chamber. I trust and hope that tomorrow, after the formation of a new rural and regional affairs committee, this Parliament will have a standing committee which will continue to look at animal welfare matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The report dealing with transport of livestock is wide reaching. We have spent more time collecting evidence on the transportation of livestock than we have on any other inquiry. We have made 20 recommendations which definitely go to the core of our concerns. Of course, there are a number of animal welfare issues which will never be able to be completely dealt with by legislation or regulation.

The real essence of this report lies in education and a national approach. For example, evidence suggested to us that few drivers of vehicles carrying livestock even knew of the codes of practice. One of our recommendations is that people who drive lorries should have a very good understanding of these codes.

We recommend that rural and producer organisations and the transport industry associations should promote training programs to extend the knowledge and skills of those who handle livestock during transport. In addition to special driving techniques, these programs should include training in all aspects of the model code of practice in the road transport of livestock. I believe that people would want their livestock picked up by somebody who knew how to handle them and who knew the codes of practice.

Another recommendation is that the codes should be regulated under relevant legislation. They should be disallowable instruments in order to give them a little bit more strength than they have had in the past. The Committee had no trouble in reaching agreement on the issue of transporting horses in double-decked vehicles. Senator Calvert and Senator Bell, who are both in the chamber at the moment, had no trouble in coming to an understanding on this point.

Probably the biggest issue to do with the transport of livestock is that of volume loading. We had to assess optimum loading and then make recommendations that could not be misinterpreted or abused. There have been other inquiries into appropriate load limits. For example, one was carried out by the Inter-State Commission. However, we were charged with examining the issue from the animal welfare aspect. It should be made very clear that this Committee always believed that its paramount duty was to look at this matter from an animal welfare point of view.

We accept that there is a potential for overloading. But we are confident that the producers and transporters are now more aware of the importance of delivering stock free from bruising and other injury. So they are going to do the right thing by the stock. It is not in the producers' best interests to overload stock in their own trucks or in commercial trucks. There is much more that I could say about the transport of livestock. However, I am aware that other senators want to speak on this matter.

I would like to deal with the report on equine welfare in competitive events other than racing. In essence, this report covered rodeos, eventing, showing, endurance riding and show jumping. I would especially like to place on record the cooperation and assistance provided by those involved in rodeos. Their cooperation was appreciated as it assisted the Committee to produce a report that I believe is fair, equitable and workable. Essentially, the concerns in respect of rodeos related to the source of stock used; spurs and their use; electric prods; flank straps; and the size of calves in calf roping events.

The recommendations made by the Committee in this regard are designed to ensure that there is a more professional approach to rodeos and, in particular, that the interests of the animals are looked after. This great spectator sport should be able to continue for a long time if it is properly conducted and if all of our recommendations are taken into account. Of course, there is a lot to be said for training. The evidence put before us indicated that not everyone does the right thing at the events or during the training leading up to competition. This is an area that should be looked at.

The evidence which the Committee received on eventing was rather limited. I regret that we did not attend any major three-day events to witness at first hand the level of competition. However, I have been to many three-day events. Obviously, we all have to look to our laurels as far as handling animals is concerned. In this area, we were concerned at the lack of statistics available. We have suggested that closer monitoring be done by the various bodies. Endurance riding, show events and other events were also included in the terms of reference and we had a look at those areas.

Another report deals with aspects of animal welfare in the racing industry. We really needed to do far more than we were able to achieve. The report is a great credit to the secretariat because the evidence taken was limited, to say the least. I do not propose to go through every recommendation but I would like to highlight some of the points that were made. Horse racing-thoroughbred and harness-is a big sport involving large sums of money. In fact, it is the largest industry in Australia.

I remain concerned about the pressure placed on two-year-olds to race too early. It is quite interesting to compare the statistics on breakdowns in Australia with some of the other areas which do not have two-year-old racing. The evidence was not decisive either way. Therefore, we could only suggest that the welfare of racing two-year-olds would be improved by requiring veterinary certification of maturity. More work needs to be done on this matter. I suggest that the number of breakdowns in two-year-olds is not fully known and is not fully assessed.

The use of whips has been widely commented on. This is a matter of public concern. It is a very visual thing. As the Chairman of this Committee said earlier, whips are definitely needed to help guide horses.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are needed to guide us in here, too!

—Senator Calvert is correct. This matter of public concern is often written and spoken about. We heard evidence in favour of and against the use of whips. Many other aspects were raised concerning this matter. The potential for abuse is present and there is a fine line between determining what is use and what is abuse. As can be seen from our report, members of the Committee had a number of views on this issue and we suggested a number of reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney, Senator Calvert and I lodged a reservation in respect of the chapter on jump racing. I should make the point that very few dissenting reports or reservations were put forward by any senators. I believe that we worked very well together. That had a lot to do with the fact that the secretariat presented good material to us.

While I remain very concerned at the number of injuries and fatalities in this sport, I am hopeful that, if reforms such as we proposed are introduced, the number of incidents will be reduced. The major problem in this country is that we do not have a sufficiently large industry to sustain breeding horses, especially for hurdles, as is the case in the UK and in other parts of the world. Here in Australia, because we do not have that breeding pool, we suffer from being a poor relation, in every sense of the word, in the racing industry.

I have already remarked on drugs and other issues, but I cannot let comment on this report pass without expressing my extreme disappointment that no-one in the racing industry felt sufficiently moved to bring hard evidence to the Committee on drugs in racing. We have had so much on drugs in racing in the human sports that it is a pity that that matter was not brought more to light before this Committee.

We took evidence on harness racing and I must remark here on the excellent evidence given by Mr Bede Ireland on the question of racetrack design and sulky design. That is one thing the racing industry should look at very closely. Some of the main trainers we had discussions with on an informal basis claimed that track design was one of the reasons why horses do have breakdowns. Obviously, going around a corner on a track which does not have a bit of camber on it causes problems with the horses having a lot of pressure put on their limbs. That is bad for the industry; it is bad for the welfare of the horse; and it is bad for the people who own the horse which has broken down and is not able to race in the future because it has strained a ligament or has done a lot worse damage than that.

These reports have been a great thing for the Committee. It is a remarkable achievement to have three reports concluded together like this and great credit must go to the secretariat. I would also like to pay credit to Dr Margaret Rose from Sydney who has given me much help over my years on the Committee. I thank her very much for that. I thank the secretariat for the help they have given me as a committee man and also as the Deputy Chairman of the Committee since 1985. I also thank the Senate for sitting and listening to our debate on this very important subject. I know that Senator Cooney will have something to say about the reports as well because he has been on the Committee for as long as I have.

The future of animal welfare is the responsibility of all of us in the community. We must ensure that the animals and their welfare are protected in every sphere in which animals are involved. The Committee has concluded but I believe the work has not. I hope that it will continue through the rural and regional affairs committee to be set up tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few brief comments more in a general context because I believe that the Select Committee on Animal Welfare has been one of the success stories of this Parliament. I can well remember in 1985 or 1986 actually giving evidence on the export of live sheep from Australia and also in connection with a number of other reports, although in a different capacity to where I stand now. What this Committee has succeeded in doing is bringing balance to the debate that was occurring in this country with regard to animal welfare. Through all these reports, the Committee has come up with some very important recommendations in terms of developing codes of practice to deal with matters in a practical sense.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take this opportunity to express regret that these are actually the last reports of this Committee. Hopefully, the new committee of which Senator Brownhill has given notice will be able to pick up the running because it is very important that the debate on the codes of practice for animal welfare and handling of animals is kept going ahead in a balanced and sensible manner. Certainly, the work of this Committee, which goes back to 1983 and whose members appear on page 73, has gone a long way towards getting a more sensible and sane approach to the emotion which was occurring when this committee was put in place.

The very reason the Committee came into existence was to address the emotion and the misrepresentations that were coming from minority groups within various sectors and industries in Australia. As I have said, the Committee started off with the inquiry into the export of live sheep from Australia, and then went onto dolphins and whales in captivity, kangaroos, animal experimentation and a number of other issues.

I support the thrust of the recommendations on road transport, rail transport and sea transport, but I want to comment on the recommendation on the introduction of volume loading of livestock. It is my belief that volume loading of livestock is the only sensible direction to go in the carriage of livestock, but of course with the necessary safeguards in the handling and welfare of those particular animals during whichever mode of transport is used.

On this aspect I can speak from experience as a farmer. The education process recommended in this report is also crucial and important because it does not take a lot of mishandling of livestock for huge commercial losses to come through to the producer. I have seen actual situations where damage has been done to a significant number of animals, whether they be sheep, lambs, or bullocks. Fortunately, I have had good operators to carry my livestock so I have never had to suffer that damage. I believe that the recommendation for an education program to train drivers in handling and loading the livestock, and determining pen size and all the other things that go with it is a very positive step in the right direction. I conclude by congratulating the people who brought down this report. I also congratulate those members who have worked on the animal welfare Committee since 1985. I think they have made a very significant contribution to a balanced, sane and sensible debate on animal welfare in Australia .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is a little difficult in one speech to try to summarise the efforts that the Select Committee on Animal Welfare has put into these three reports, which are being discussed concurrently, but I would like to emphasise some of the important things in these reports. I concur with the remarks of the previous speakers. The time that I have spent on this Committee has been enlightening. It has also been a time when, owing to the nature of the Committee and the personnel involved on it, it has been possible to communicate in a rational and well considered manner and consider what has sometimes been an emotional debate within the wider community. That is a reflection of both the maturity of the people who have been involved in this Committee and also the fact that it is a debate which will not go away but must be considered in a sane manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The reports that we have before us required a considerable amount of research and inquiry in order to generate them. I repeat what has been said earlier, that is, that the secretariat should be congratulated on being able to bring together the evidence received in the three separate inquiries and the great amount of research carried out.

A central matter we kept coming back to in the consideration of the Transport of Livestock Within Australia report was the need for a national regulatory framework. There was no dissent within the Committee about the good sense of ensuring that the conditions applying in one State should apply in another and that the model code of practice applicable to this industry really should be endorsed by all State legislatures and adopted by those people involved in the industry. That model code of practice, referred to on the very first page in the recommendations and major conclusions section of the report, really represented the core of the Committee's concerns.

Senator Crane in his well-informed comments picked up on the concept of optimum loading. There was a great amount of discussion about that by the Committee. Research into optimum loading and conditions associated with the transport of livestock really needs further attention. It was pretty obvious, in the time that we had available to us on this Committee, that considerable benefits would derive to animal welfare from adopting the optimum loading density concept in transporting animals. The Committee stated in the report:
. . . departure, in either direction, from the optimum will adversely affect animal welfare.

That seemed a pretty obvious conclusion for the Committee to come to. Also central to the transport of animals, and a subject which the Committee came to understand a lot better as we progressed through the inquiry, is the training of drivers and those people associated with loading stock on to transport vehicles. Somebody with only a superficial knowledge of animal welfare issues might think that training a driver in any special techniques necessary for transporting animals is a very simple matter. However, as we on the Committee learned, it is not just a case of saying, `Go out and look at the animals every now and then'. Many aspects to the transporting of live animals require special consideration, special training and a deal of experience. I was most pleased that in paragraph 4.2.2 the Committee recommended:

. . . that all drivers of vehicles carrying livestock as part of a commercial transport enterprise should be properly trained and possess a suitably endorsed vehicle driving licence. This will ensure that those offering services in the livestock transport industry have undertaken an accepted form of training or have demonstrated a specified level of competence in livestock handling.

I hope that recommendation will be a powerful one, in that it will, by itself, bring about significant reforms in the welfare of animals which are transported from place to place. The matter is not simply a question of a person undertaking a short course or watching somebody else driving live animals; it relates to understanding even how to start the vehicle. Even the technique of starting the vehicle must not be overlooked. Starting a vehicle loaded with live animals needs to be done very carefully and with the knowledge that if the vehicle is started too suddenly the animals at the rear of the vehicle will be crushed or put off balance and trampled. Obviously, one needs also to consider cornering techniques and the correct changing of gears to go up a gradient. All these things must be considered because the driver of such a vehicle is dealing with a dynamic load-not a load of gravel or whatever. There is much to consider. As I said, I hope that that recommendation will be a powerful one which will bring about a great deal of reform in the welfare of animals being transported.

Concerns relating to the transport of animals by rail were also addressed within the same inquiry. Obviously, there needs to be even further refinement of training programs to take into account the differences in transporting animals by rail. However, I do not think that this is either the time or the place to discuss that, although we did hear of some of those differences in the course of the Committee's inquiry.

I turn now to the report entitled Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry. In dealing with our major conclusions, once again on the very first page we are reminded that the Committee was impressed with the views of Dr Heynes of the Australian Veterinary Association on the use of the whip in the horse racing industry. He said that there needed to be changes in the use of the whip in the horse racing industry as a result of pressure from public opinion. I would like to think that this report is part of that public opinion. The public has many vehicles for expressing its opinion and certainly the Parliament of Australia would have to be recognised as one of the most important vehicles for this expression of public opinion. An expression of that public opinion is in the form of this report from one of our parliamentary committees. The Committee stated in the report:
. . . the Committee is of the view that regulations should be introduced forbidding jockeys from whipping horses that have clearly lost the opportunity to achieve a placing in any race.

What could be clearer than that? I suggest that that view of the Committee is shared by all those people who have either witnessed a horse race or who have taken part in any aspect of the horse racing industry. Anybody who presented a view to the contrary certainly does not understand very much about the racing industry and should not really be considered as having a worthwhile opinion anyway. I think that public opinion in this regard can be easily assessed. Certainly, one of the tasks of the Committee was to discover what the public opinion was and to express it in a report. The secretariat is to be congratulated because that opinion was difficult to put into words.
I also draw the Senate's attention to the Committee's consideration of jump racing, detailed in chapter 3 of the report. The report stated:
. . . the Committee has serious concerns about the welfare of horses participating in jump races.

The Committee felt that, even with improvements to the height and placing of jumps, improvements in training and education, and any other improvements in jump racing, the fatality rate would remain constant. On hearing the evidence, the Committee was able to conclude only that there is an inherent conflict between these activities and animal welfare. Therefore, the Committee was of the view that relevant State governments should phase out jump racing over the next three years. I cannot imagine that we are likely to get much concurrence from State governments for that recommendation.

Senator Brownhill, Senator Calvert and Senator Cooney were concerned about this matter but considered that improvements could be made to reduce the danger in jump racing. Nevertheless, it is important that the Committee said this and that the Committee pointed out that the activity itself is a conflict. It is excitement. The danger and excitement will almost guarantee it spectator value for some time, and it will linger on. It is important for this Committee to express that particular concern now. I hope that steeplechasing-jump races-is phased out. I would not like to put a time limit upon it. I hope that eventually it is an aspect of what we now consider to be sport which will not continue for too long into the future.

I was also pleased that through this inquiry into animal welfare in the racing industry we were able to consider the present, almost arbitrary age at which horses are first raced. The welfare of racing two-year-olds has been a matter of some community concern for a considerable time. To address that, it is not only a question of looking at the chronological age of the horses involved; the Committee concluded that the racing of two-year-olds would be improved if there were a requirement that there be a veterinary certification of physical maturity, which is a different matter to chronological age. I was pleased to see that conclusion and that we were able to bring that about.

The report also considered greyhound racing, because the title of the report is Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry. Although in common parlance the `racing industry' means the horse racing industry, greyhound racing was also considered. Concerns were expressed and recommendations made, which I will not go into now, although I recommend all honourable senators to at least glance at them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or go to the Dapto dogs and have a look.

—I thank Senator Aulich for his guidance. For his edification, I will mention another concern of mine. In looking at greyhound racing, there is room to widen our concerns to the welfare of animals in other forms of racing. I do not suggest for a moment that the Committee should have considered cockroach races, the cane toad tournaments or any of the other carnival activities that are notorious throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I suggest that at the seat of this problem, and other problems associated with such activities, is our attitude to animals in general. We still have the attitude towards animals that they are a resource to be exploited by humans; that animals are on this earth simply to provide amusement or to be used as a material economic resource by humans, and that if it suits our purposes we should take animals, do with them what we will and then discard them.

While this attitude has been softened somewhat with regard to companion animals-horses, dogs, et cetera-we retain an arrogance which makes it difficult for us to appreciate the full range of welfare issues which arise when considering the many relationships between humans and animals. I know Senator Cooney is terribly concerned about this because during one of our inquiries he struggled to come to grips with what it was that we were considering about the welfare of animals.

I would like to think that the other members of our Committee have done a little more than merely look at the title of the inquiry and the terms of reference of the particular inquiries. I honestly like to think that all the members of the Committee actually grappled with the question: what is our relationship as humans with animals and how do we use animals and how should we use them, if at all?

Senator Brownhill's moves to establish a standing committee for regional and rural affairs will allow those questions to be asked at some future date. That sort of consideration was partly behind our consideration of the third report entitled Equine Welfare in Competitive Events Other Than Racing, because that was a wider reference which allowed the Committee to consider some of the other relationships we have with animals.

I will not dwell too long on that report but pass through it by saying that it considered many other aspects. Senator Brownhill suggested that we could have spent a little more time on things such as three-day events. There were time constraints throughout this Committee's references. Another good inquiry would be that aspect, if we are able to establish this standing committee.

Some of the things we considered were the carnival events-rodeos or whatever-which include such things as saddle bronco riding, bareback riding, calf roping and steer wrestling. For example, we as a committee were able to attempt to define each event, to describe it and to determine whether there was any standard understanding throughout Australia of what a particular event should be, how it should be conducted and whether there were any guidelines that should be considered if any organisers were about to undertake an event such as calf roping.

The Committee was able to define each of these activities. It was enlightening for us to appreciate that some of these events have been introduced only in the past few decades into Australia. They are not an exhibition of traditional bushman skills, as we might have been led to believe. A number of them have derived from the travelling sideshow, from North American traditions, rather than the traditions of mustering and managing animals in the Australian outback setting. I was enlightened by that. I dare say the other Committee members were also enlightened by much of the other information that was given to us by way of submission when we were considering these particular things.

I must mention quickly that the Chairman, Senator Burns, and I made a reservation on this matter at paragraph 3.108. I should emphasise that, while accepting the Committee's conclusion on calf roping that there could well be an improvement in animal welfare in these events, we put in a reservation which said that we would consider that:
calf roping should be banned from rodeo events as weight limitations or improved roping devices do not overcome the inherent animal welfare problems associated with this event.

Finally, the information that we were given about the practice of rapping illustrates what I was speaking about earlier in respect of our arrogance and attitude to animals. We were told by Dr Ellis, who gave evidence to us, that rapping might also involve putting sharp objects under the leg bandages of a horse in order to condition it to jump higher for our amusement and benefit only-certainly not for the horse's benefit. The Committee considers that rapping and other such practices are unacceptable. We hold the strong view that the Equestrian Federation of Australia should make every effort to eliminate these practices from competition and training.

This is an example of the way in which this Committee worked. We were able to readily identify practices which we considered did not improve the welfare of the animals involved. General consensus was reached quite readily within this Committee about what was and was not appropriate to recommend. I look forward to being able to participate on a similar committee with similar colleagues. Many of the things that the Committee has been able to achieve should have a great impact on our relationship with animals throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because I know that other senators have other reports to present. I thought I had better say something on this matter because it is the last hurrah for the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted over the weekend that Senator Walsh commented in a press report that there were too many committees in the Parliament. I must say that this is one committee that has served a particular issue well. It certainly went a lot longer than the Senate expected and it probably could have gone longer if that had been our wish. It is also very interesting to note that the members of the Committee obviously feel very strongly about the different reports because five out of the six members will be speaking on them today.

Cruelty to animals certainly fires up people's emotions. One thing that this Committee has been able to do is hose down, for want of a better term, some of the issues that could have got out of hand in this country. I refer in particular to our animal experimentation report. If one looks at what has happened elsewhere, one sees that animal liberationists overseas, particularly in the area of animal experimentation and the like, have become urban terrorists. It is not unusual to see fire bombings, murder and properties being broken into. Thank heavens that has not happened in Australia to any large extent. I believe that one reason it has not happened is that we have provided a forum to which concerned groups can put their views.

In the main, this Committee has been able to present balanced reports that most people have accepted. I briefly refer to the first report that we tabled today entitled the Transport of Livestock Within Australia. Senator Brownhill said most of what I would have said. He was also supported by Senator Crane and Senator Bell. I am impressed that we all agreed that volume loading is essential and necessary in Australia from a welfare point of view, not from the point of view of greedy operators being able to load more stock. This matter was very aptly summed up in evidence we received from Dr Hugh Wirth, the President of the RSPCA, and from ANZFAS, another well credentialled welfare organisation that gave us evidence on most matters we looked at. They believe that the term `volume loading' should be replaced by the term `welfare loading'. That sums up the whole section on volume loading.

The other report that has been referred to briefly today is Equine Welfare in Competitive Events Other Than Racing. My concern with that area related to show events. As a former President of the Royal Agricultural Society in Tasmania, it came to my attention on many occasions as I moved around the show scene, that the use of drugs in particular was quite evident in dressage and showjumping. I guess that time will tell whether that will decrease.

We recommended that people at shows increase the number of drug tests on horses in an effort to reduce that problem. We also put the view that, where a show society banned a competitor for using a prohibited drug, that competitor should be banned from all other shows. We were told in respect of another area-eventing-that it had been found that the feet of a horse had been denerved. The horse was banned but the rider was still allowed to continue. Those are the sorts of things that people have to look at.

Like Senator Brownhill, I am concerned that there was very little evidence of any statistics being kept in respect of endurance riding. We drew attention to the fact that there has been a definite increase in fatalities in that pastime.

The rodeo section has been very well covered. Contract stock can be used to reduce the concerns of animal welfare groups about rodeos. We believe very strongly that, by and large, the use of contract stock in rodeo events would go a long way towards reducing injuries to animals.

Finally, I want to say one or two things about our report on the racing industry, which is entitled Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry. As has been said previously, I believe it is unfortunate that we had neither the time nor the resources to investigate this matter as well as we might have. What was done and what has been recommended goes a long way towards covering the area. But there certainly is a need, perhaps at some future date, for a more searching report into some aspects.

I refer particularly to track design. We had plenty of evidence to show us that track design is one of the major contributors to animal injuries and deaths in racing and jumping. Very strong views were put to us by people such as Bart Cummings, to whom we spoke briefly; Richard Hore-Lacy, who trains jumping horses; and well-known jockeys to whom we spoke informally. None of this evidence is in the report because we did not have the opportunity to talk to them formally. It is unfortunate that these personalities did not give evidence.

As has been said, Senator Cooney, Senator Brownhill and I do have a reservation about jump racing. I believe that improvements can be made. It is also interesting to note that those two senators and I are the longest serving members on the Committee. Having spoken to the trainers, jockeys and those people involved in jump racing at Sandown in particular, we all agree that the fatality rate could be reduced if some of the improvements recommended in the report were implemented. We certainly disagree with the notion that jump racing should be abandoned.

The use of the whip, as has been said, is quite controversial. We heard evidence that in the United Kingdom there is a restriction on the number of times a jockey can whip a horse during a race. In all practicality, if that recommendation were carried in Australia I think very little notice would be taken of it. But evidence was given-and we observed it ourselves-of cases when the use of the whip is certainly unwarranted.

I would like to conclude my remarks by saying that I appreciate the help given by the Committee staff during our inquiries. I would like to compliment the staff that I served with: Paul Barsdell, Derrick Abbott, Monica McMahon and Neil Bessell; and particularly the assistance given by Bronwyn Allan, Michael Game and Peter Short.

Senator Cooney referred to some of the former chairmen and members of this Committee. One member of the Committee whom he inadvertently failed to speak about was former Senator Ray Devlin-our former colleague from Tasmania-who had quite an involvement and interest in the racing industry report. I think he would be rather disappointed that we did not have a bit more time to spend observing practical racing and examining some of the things which can be done to improve it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Calvert for reminding me that on the last occasion when I spoke about a report of the Select Committee on Animal Welfare I did not mention Senator Devlin. I see some of his former colleagues in the chamber now-Senator Aulich and you, Madam Acting Deputy President-who would appreciate the work that Senator Devlin did in this area, particularly the work he did on the three reports, Transport of Livestock Within Australia, Equine Welfare in Competitive Events Other Than Racing and Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry, which are now before the Senate. He was Chairman of the Committee during much of the preparation of those reports. He has been very well succeeded by Senator Burns but, certainly, Senator Devlin did some great work on those reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The reports are the last three reports of the Committee. It will go through a metamorphosis and become another committee which will pay some time and attention to the areas at which these reports have looked. This is a Senate select committee which has gone on for many years. I think this is because when people started to look at animal welfare two things happened: firstly, some concentration was applied to the subject and, secondly, there was a development. The way people think about animal welfare now is very different from the way in which they thought about it when this Committee was first set up. Senator Crane made that point and I think all Committee members, including myself, can be proud of the work we have done in that area which has largely been aimed at raising people's expectations.

The things that I might have said about these reports have been said, but I would like to make a few remarks about the report entitled Aspects of Animal Welfare in the Racing Industry. As has been pointed out, it is a very big industry-big in the sense of employing many people, giving out much money in terms of prizes, and providing a livelihood for many people. During our inquiry we were given great assistance by people in the industry. Doctor John Bourke of the Victoria Racing Club was very good, I think all Committee members would agree, in the way he helped us through the intricacies of the racing industry. I think he treated us very well, as did many members of the industry generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not recommend banning steeplechasing, though, did he?
—No, he did not recommend the banning of steeplechasing.
—He recommended bandaging the legs, though.

—He did recommend the bandaging of legs and he talked about shin soreness. But shin soreness is not confined only to horses. My baby daughter, who is now 20 years old, runs and she gets shin soreness. Her mother always threatens to pin fire her!

SPEECH.PARA: I simply raise that issue because we have to have some balance when we are looking at an industry like the racing industry. There is always a risk of some soreness and pain in any sort of contest. Of course, it will be said that people run, exercise and take part in sport because they want to win. But from my observations of the thoroughbreds, I thought they certainly took part in racing very willingly.

The industry seemed to be concerned about, and turned its mind to, the various issues, such as the use of whips and the racing of two-year-olds. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would know that the difficulty with the two-year-olds is that the epiphysial plates may not close as early in some animals as they do in others. If a horse is run when its epiphysial plates are not as closed as they should be, the effect would be the same as running anybody with such plates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you care to tell the Senate what an epiphysial plate is?

—It is the plate at the end of the bone which grows and allows for growth. As it becomes more mature it closes over so that the growing stops, as does the bone. The bone is then able to take more force and impact and to be used more than it was previously.
—Thank you, senator, you have been a great help.

—I simply use that as an illustration of how the people in the racing industry, particularly Dr John Bourke of the Victoria Racing Club, are very conscious of animal welfare. I endorse everything that has been said so far and I hope that this Committee is as successful in its new form as it has been in its form as a select committee.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present the Department of the Senate response to the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on Estimates committee documentation and procedures. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DEPARTMENT OF THE SENATE RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION -ESTIMATES COMMITTEE DOCUMENTATION AND PROCEDURES

The recent report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration's inquiry into Estimates Committee Documentation and Procedures contained a number of recommendations aimed at rationalising the amount and ``flow'' of paper associated with Senate Estimates hearings.

These would affect publishing and circulation arrangements for both Program Performance Statements submitted by departments in support of the budget and additional estimates, and any subsidiary material requested in committee hearings, including the answers. to questions taken on notice.

The Government has not yet provided any indication of its response to the committee's report but it is appropriate for the Department of the Senate to respond to those recommendations which are of direct relevance to it. The broad thrust behind the proposals, to make the Estimates Committee process more manageable and, perhaps, less demanding of resources, offers many potential advantages. However there are major technical problems involved in implementing some of the recommendations which make it impractical for the Senate Table Office to implement recommendations Nos 1 and 2 in time for the 1991 Budget Session.

Later this year the Department of the Senate will be engaging a consultant to develop an overall plan for the implementation of information technology in the Table Office. In this context, the technical problems identified in the attachment to this statement will be considered and a further report on the feasibility of electronically providing information on estimates documentation will be tabled.
The specific recommendations which have implications for the Department of the Senate, together with the department's comments on these recommendations, are set out in the Attachment.
ATTACHMENT
DEPARTMENT OF THE SENATE RESPONSE TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION REPORT ON ESTIMATES COMMITTEE DOCUMENTATION AND PROCEDURES
Recommendation 1 (a)

That the Department of Finance investigate the benefits and costs of inserting in the guidelines for preparation of the explanatory notes a requirement that (a) the explanatory notes be made available to the Senate Table Office in electronic as well as printed form with consequent reduction in print run (pages ix and 24).
Print Run
Not all copies of explanatory notes (now called program performance statements) produced by departments are for the Senate Table Office.

Last financial year the Table Office only received 100 copies of the estimated 250-450 copies of the explanatory notes each department printed. Of the 100 copies received, a substantial proportion were distributed to Senators, the National Library, the Parliamentary Library and the media.

Based on past experience it is unlikely that a reduction in the number of `hard' copies provided to the Table Office would have as dramatic an effect on the print runs as the committee believes. There may be an argument for reducing the print run for some of the statements less in demand, particularly for the additional estimates, but certain departments' statements are very popular and Table Office stocks of their explanatory notes are almost fully consumed. Given the unpredictability of demand for a department's explanatory notes, and the need for some uniformity in the Table Office requirements on departments, it is not feasible to reduce the print run provided to the Table Office below 100, at least for the budget estimates, although the print run for the additional estimates could perhaps be reduced to 75 copies.
Systems Compatibility

The compatibility, or lack thereof, between departments' electronic information systems and the information systems operating in the Senate and the Department of the Senate are vital factors to be taken into account in assessing this recommendation. The Table Office would need to stipulate, to submitting departments, that the explanatory notes be delivered in a standard format on floppy disks. An obvious choice would be WordPerfect. However this may meet with some resistance, as:
(i) some departments do not use WordPerfect, and may not consider themselves in a position to convert their documents to this format; and
(ii) some tabular, and particularly graphical, presentations may be difficult (or even impossible) to replicate in WordPerfect format.

Alternatively, departments may supply their explanatory notes on floppy disk, and the Department of the Senate would be responsible for conversions to WordPerfect. This option would result in additional handling costs for the Table Office and have significant resource implications.

At present 23 sets of explanatory notes are prepared for estimates. A document of some 40-50 pages is the norm for the additional estimates, with the estimates of only a few departments being longer (for example, Department of Defence at 250-plus pages). However, for the budget estimates, the majority of explanatory notes are longer than 200 pages, with several at 400-plus pages. The Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) has advised the Table Office that if the moving around in a WordPerfect document and searching is to be facilitated, the optimum length of the document for down loading onto the Senate information system is approximately 50 pages. Each of the lengthier explanatory notes would therefore have to be reformatted into a series of shorter documents and this would require a substantial amount of time to be devoted to converting and/or reformatting the electronic information to render it more useable on the Senate information systems, time which is not often readily available, given the time constraints already imposed by the very nature of the estimates process.

In the worst case, where none of the information provided by departments was compatible with the Senate information systems, it would be necessary for an officer to be employed for some 45 working days on converting the information in order to make it compatible (in addition to time taken to copy the diskettes, which is discussed later). Further, it is not possible for any officer to be employed to carry out the conversion, as the nature of the work involved requires the services of a technically qualified officer with expertise in formatting and reformatting documents into the most appropriate style for ease of access by users.
Recommendation 2.(a)
The second recommendation which impinges on the Table Office again concerns electronically provided information:
`` . . . the Senate Table Office should:

(a) encourage Senators who wish to obtain copies of explanatory notes for portfolios other than those covered by their own estimates committee to receive the information in electronic rather than printed form 80 that they can then select which pages they want to print out; . . . '' (pages ix and 24)
Diskettes

Presumably, departments would provide only one copy of the electronic information on diskette and the Table Office would be responsible for the copying of that information onto diskettes in order to meet requests for that information.

As already stated, there may well be problems of compatibility between departments' hardware and software and those of the Senate. Incompatibility would necessitate conversion of the documents at a substantial cost to the Senate and its Department, in both time and resources. The costs of copying the diskettes also have to be examined. The same skilled officer would need to be employed to carry out the copying, in order to ensure that all the technical requirements of the copying were met, to check the diskettes copied, to label the diskettes and to produce appropriate instructions for users to facilitate downloading and use of the information.

Advice has been received that a good-quality, multiple diskette copier would cost approximately $8000, plus ongoing maintenance costs. Such a copier copies a bank of diskettes at a time (for example, a bank of seven diskettes, so that the copier makes seven copies of the original diskette simultaneously) and takes approximately 10 minutes to copy a diskette onto the bank of diskettes, including setting up, loading, copying, checking and labelling. The current cost of 3.5'' diskettes is approximately $2.50 and that of 5.25'' diskettes is approximately $1.25. A full set of the explanatory notes would currently require 23 diskettes. To provide one Senator with a full set of the explanatory notes on diskette would entail a minimum cost of $28.75. To provide a full set of the explanatory notes to all Senators (76), 1748 diskettes would be needed at an estimated minimum cost of $2185.

Reference has been made in the earlier part of this response to the fact that the majority of the explanatory notes for the budget estimates are in excess of over 200 pages in length and the optimum length of a WordPerfect document for downloading onto the Senate information system is approximately 50 pages. One diskette could contain a department's explanatory notes, but in instances where the notes are longer than 50 pages, they would need to be subdivided into documents of approximately 50 pages. Advice has been received that approximately 6 working days would be required to complete the task of copying the diskettes and that converting and copying the electronically provided information would take approximately 11 working days in total (45 days for conversion and 6 days for copying).

If it were decided not to prepare a full diskette set of the explanatory notes for each Senator, but only to copy a department's notes as a request was received, it would still be necessary to arrange for the conversion of departments' electronically provided information. As already stated, this process could take 45 working days. If Senators do not request all the explanatory notes, there could be a reduction in the total copying time but only if a full bank of seven copies were copied each time. (Copying in full blanks is necessary to maximise the benefits of multiple copying and this would also result in some stocks being held in the Table Office). Each request from a Senator would be processed as received, and if there were no stock on hand, would take approximately half an hour to process from receipt of the request to the diskette leaving the Table Office.

Another matter of concern is the integrity of the material on copied diskettes. Although the officer carrying out the copying would check the copied diskettes, this does not ensure the integrity of the diskettes once they leave the Table Office. The diskettes could be corrupted either in their handling during distribution (for example, if mailed) or by Senators or their staff while using the diskettes.
Recommendation 2.(b)
`` . . . the Senate Table Office should:

(b) no longer print and bind the Additional Information but arrange instead for it to be added to the parliamentary database after it has been tabled. Printed copies of individual responses would continue to be provided by the estimates committee secretariat to the Senator who asked the question giving rise to it, and to other Senators requesting it, until the information became available electronically; . . . '' (pages ix and 24)
The additional information poses more complex problems. The implementation of this recommendation involves complex technical problems, including:

(i) there is a large amount of data involved-some 5418 pages of explanatory notes at around 3 Kbytes per page, and an unspecified quantity of additional information at possibly as much as 1 Mbyte per page (depending on how the images are stored);
(ii) the people accessing the information are spread throughout the country;
(iii) current parliamentary databases were not established to handle, nor are they capable of handling, image-based data or table-based data. They are essentially text-based databases.
(iv) the current information is provided from a wide variety (and quality) of sources, making imposition of a standard format impossible to administer.

Currently, the only way such information could be consistently electronically captured is by a process known as bit mapped scanning. This is, in effect, the electronic storage of photograph-like images of the original documents.
While this concept is technically feasible, it does pose some problems including:
(i) the scanning and storage of documents using relatively new and expensive resources; and
(ii) some form of indexing and retrieval technology would be necessary to recover the stored images for later reference.
The software used to manipulate this information would also depend, among other things, on how the information is incorporated into the databases for later retrieval.

Before any sound technical proposal can be developed to store this additional information in databases, and access it from the parliamentary network, or any future extended parliamentary network, an extensive technical feasibility study would need to be considered.
According to PISO such a study would need to:
(i) examine the most efficient mechanisms to collect and store the information;
(ii) examine the projected patterns of access to the information;
(iii) examine how Senators wish the information to be presented;
(iv) examine where the information needs to be delivered (e.g. electorate offices), and how best to get it there;
(v) determine whether delivery systems can be purchased, or if they will need to be developed in-house;
(vi) determine development and support costs for such a system; and
(vii) determine who will/can pay for the support (this may have an impact on the system design).

This feasibility study would be a major undertaking, as it would involve studying several technologies not familiar to the current parliamentary environment, such as SGML, image processing, E-mail, image databases and CD-ROM, and liaising with several groups of people, including technical specialists, the Senate Table Office, government departments and statutory authorities. According to PISO such a study would require several months work and could cost upwards of $50,000. Currently, no funding has been included within the budgets of either PISO or the Table Office for such a project.

It would not be sound management to proceed with aspects of recommendation 1 until the feasibility of recommendation 2 has been established, chiefly because the way in which this information is stored will have a significant bearing on how it can be accessed in the future. As the latter has not yet been determined, it would be unwise to proceed with the former.
Recommendation 3
This recommendation suggests that:
``Explanatory Notes be required to be lodged with the Senate Table Office no later than the Friday of the week following the presentation of the Budget;'' (pages ix and 25)

In recent years the deadline for the lodgment of the explanatory notes has been negotiated between the Clerk-Assistant (Table) and the Department of Finance each time. The tabling date has been determined by the date the Government proposes for the commencement of the estimates process. For example, for the current budget sittings, it was agreed that the explanatory notes should be tabled by the Thursday of budget week. Implementation of the committee's recommendation would have meant that, on this occasion, the notes would have been received only 2 days before the estimates committees' public hearings were to commence. By the time the documents were circulated to Senators they would in reality have a maximum of one day to examine them. Unless the Government agrees to schedule estimates committee hearings at a later time, it would be impractical to proceed with this recommendation. Further, as circumstances change from one estimates period to the next, it seems more appropriate to negotiate an appropriate tabling date each time, taking into account all the circumstances existing at that time.
Recommendation 4.
This recommendation suggests that:

``the President of the Senate table in the Senate a schedule of the date of receipt of each portfolio's explanatory notes on the first sitting day after the last set of Notes is lodged;'' (pages ix and 25)

While the preparation of the document presents no problem, the Department of the Senate questions the need for the document if the explanatory notes are received on a sitting day, as in that situation, they are tabled as expeditiously as possible and certainly within 24 hours. Any person interested in this information would be able to obtain a good idea as to the date of receipt of the notes by examining the Journals of the Senate.
Recommendation 5.
This recommendation suggests that:

``If explanatory notes are provided other than in a sitting week, the Government take the opportunity to arrange for them to be presented to the President of the Senate and deemed to be tabled in accordance with the resolution adopted by the Senate on 13 February 1991;'' (pages ix and 25)

In its report, the committee (page 25) explains the reasoning behind this recommendation: `` . . . that it is important for the explanatory notes to be given formal status as soon as possible 80 that they are available for distribution to Senators . . . ''. This reasoning appears to be based upon a false premise. There is no need for the explanatory notes to be tabled before they are distributed. Once the Appropriation Bills have been introduced in the House of Representatives the explanatory notes can then be distributed.
