DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the President's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on active citizenship revisited. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Active Citizenship Revisited Report
Response by the Presiding Officers

The Committee was given the task of inquiring into and reporting on developments which had occurred during the two years following the original report on Education for Active Citizenship. As the report on Active Citizenship Revisited raised a number of issues relating to functions carried out by offices in the Parliamentary departments, the following responses have been prepared to each of the pertinent recommendations:
(i) Recommendation 2.5

The Committee recommends that a coordinated approach be adopted to the production of resource materials for the national curriculum on studies of society and the environment. Production should be the responsibility of a variety of organisations including the Curriculum Corporation, the Parliamentary Education Office, the Australian Electoral Commission, State Education Departments and Legislatures and individual organisations with an interest in this subject. Materials should be designed to broaden the approach to active citizenship education in schools and to complement existing materials.
Response

I agree with the observation that there needs to be a coordinated approach to the production of resource materials for the studies of society and the environment and I understand that the Parliamentary Education Office (PEO) is but one key component in a network of agencies responsible for implementing parliamentary and citizenship education in Australian schools. To this end I have encouraged the PEO to establish highly effective and productive links with each of the agencies or groups mentioned in recommendation 2.5.

It is my understanding that the peak curriculum development organisation which appears to be strategically placed to assume a coordinating role is the recently established Curriculum Corporation of Australia. If it, or any other equally reputable and appropriate organisation, takes on a coordinating role and requires the cooperation of the PEO, I am confident that quality advice and assistance, subject of course to resource limitations, will be forthcoming.

However, until a national and agreed statement on parliamentary and citizenship education is finalised, it would appear that only limited progress could be made in respect of a more formalised system to coordinate curriculum development in the area. Until then, the PEO will continue to operate under its existing network arrangements, for example; conducting parliamentary education programs for schools and teachers, attending meetings of professional associations and entering into joint venture arrangements with relevant agencies to produce curriculum materials.
(ii) Recommendation 5.1

The Committee recommends the production and distribution of copies of the Australian Constitution, at minimum cost, to schools and to the general public through libraries, AGPS bookshops and parliamentary bookshops where they exist. This could be undertaken by the Curriculum Corporation, the Parliamentary Education Office or State Legislatures.
Response
I agree that there exists a need for the Constitution document to be more accessible and affordable to all Australians.

Accordingly, the PEO has arranged for a new format for the Constitution which will result in the production of a pocket sized document which will be available to schools for 60 cents per copy (minimum order quantity of 30). The Parliamentary Bookshop and AGPS now sell single copies for $2.50. During the Autumn Sittings this document was tabled in the Senate and referred to in the other place during Members 90 second statements. Bulk sales of the publication to schools already indicate that it will be popular document.
(iii) Recommendation 5.3

The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Parliamentary Education Office convene a meeting of education officers (or equivalent) of all parliaments to discuss cooperative approaches to parliamentary education in general and the production of resources in particular.
Response

During its first two years of operation the PEO has established effective lines of communication and ongoing liaison with the relevant education officers in each of the state and territory legislatures. This initiative has resulted already in a number of bi-lateral programs to develop materials which, inter alia, address the relationship between state and Federal parliaments.

As yet there have not occurred any multi-lateral initiatives which would bring about a more coordinated approach to parliamentary education by the state and Federal legislatures. We believe that considerable advantages would accrue if a small working party, with representation from each legislature, were convened to discuss options for future cooperation and collaboration. A project officer in the PEO has been given responsibility for arranging such a meeting which at this stage is scheduled for March 1992.
(iv) Recommendations 5.4 and 5.5

The Committee recommends that favourable consideration be given by the National Parliament to the enhanced funding of the Parliamentary Education Office for the purpose of extending its community education programs and its educational leadership role amongst Australian legislatures.

The Committee recommends that all Parliamentary and electoral education services re-examine their programs with a view to an increased emphasis on programs for adult clients, and to deliver those programs in a manner which encourages the content knowledge, contextual understanding and personal involvement necessary to promote genuine participation as an active citizen.

I recognise that there has developed an increased interest on the part of the adult community to learn about our system of government which includes the integral role of parliament as the law making institution. I also recognise that this interest will intensify as the nation moves towards its centenary of Federation and discussion and debate continues on the issue of constitutional reform.

I anticipate that during this time the PEO will continue to be seen by Senators, Members, educators and the community at large as being one of the key sources of information and advice on parliamentary and citizenship education. In keeping with the Office's flexible and adaptable approach in the past, I am quite sure that, where possible, and within the constraints of its existing resources, it will continue to provide this service.

However, the PEO is only a small office comprising fewer than ten (10) full time officers attempting to carry out its ``core business'' directed at the parliamentary education needs of more than 10,000 Australian schools who continue to draw on the resources of the Office at an ever increasing rate. It would appear that the work of both the PEO and the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, coupled with the efforts of Members and Senators generally, has stimulated a high level of interest in parliamentary and political affairs in schools and, in line with the findings in the Report, has resulted in an increase in demand for parliamentary education services.

Unfortunately, in the current environment of public expenditure restraint, there exists only a slim hope that additional human resources could be secured for the PEO to move into any major community education initiative beyond its present range of activities.

My preference is that the PEO should respond to demand in this area on a case by case basis and that any proactive efforts in the adult education area should be the responsibility of Senators and Members and their respective electorate or interest groups.
I remain confident that under this regime the PEO will continue to provide materials and services to those Senators and Members who require assistance.

Should circumstances change which would place us in an enhanced position to seek additional funding to support increased activity in the PEO in the community education domain, or should there be a slackening of demand by schools for PEO services and curriculum packages, it would then be entirely appropriate for a review to be undertaken with a view to allocating additional resources to support adult programs.
Conclusion

I would like to place on record my appreciation for the unstinting efforts of the Committee in increasing the level of awareness and reasoned nonpartisan debate about active and responsible citizenship in the context of Australian democracy. The work of the Committee has given all Australians an opportunity to examine the role that they should have in both community and public affairs in future years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I speak briefly to the President's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Active Citizenship Revisited. I will then seek leave to continue my remarks at a later date because I believe that there are other senators who wish to contribute. As honourable senators would know, this report is an attempt by the Committee to go back over the issues that relate to the question of active citizenship in this country. In particular, it is an attempt to review what has been achieved so far as a result of the Committee's report.

We made that decision quite deliberately. We have looked at a number of reports that have come into this chamber over the years. Many of the reports have been extremely valuable. They have made recommendations which governments should have acted on, or at least taken into account, in the optioning that goes before Cabinet. After that, nothing was done: the reports sat on the shelf and in many cases gathered dust. The effect of the reports was in many ways neutralised because no-one went back to them to assess whether action had arisen from their recommendations.

We are determined to go back to the issue of active citizenship. We believe that it is an extremely important matter for the Australian community to deal with. It is not just a question of whether Parliament is regarded in this country with a degree of authority or respect or as a place-as I think it may be regarded in some quarters-where people abuse each other and waffle on with no real aim in mind bar passing legislation or the occasional Budget.

Regardless of how Parliament is looked at, this report goes beyond that. The report is about whether people in the community, particularly young people, are able to participate in forums, in organisations, which have some degree of effect on their lives. It does not matter whether it is a sports club, the local council, the State Government or the Federal Parliament. It is an attempt to come to grips with a problem which has been facing many Western democracies over the last decade or so.

If we look at the last two American elections, we see that the figures that came out of those elections indicated quite clearly that less than half of those that were eligible to vote actually voted for the President. That is in a democracy which is expected to be one of the more vital and alive in the world.

I think the recent events in the Soviet Union- or what is left of it-should have indicated quite clearly to all of us that democracy is extremely valuable. Democracy has to be fought for and does not stay forever in any particular country. There will be challenges to the preservation of a democracy in every Western society. Parliaments have a duty to ensure that the institution of Parliament is protected against authoritarianism and apathy. Authoritarianism breeds on the apathy of voters. We have a much greater responsibility than that.

We have to ensure that at every level in life our young people in particular can become active citizens; that they are not just sheep but have some control over their own destinies and over their workplace-over any organisation which has an effect on their life.

The response from the President, I believe, has been positive. On many occasions, the President has proved extremely willing to support the Committee's approach to active citizenship. He has gone out of his way to ensure that this Parliament, particularly the Senate chamber, has provided the information, the ideas, to members of Parliament who want to get closer to young people in their electorates. He has made sure that the parliamentary visits program has gone beyond just a few lucky schools that happen to be close to this Parliament House. In fact, as honourable senators know, it is now a program geared towards bringing in young people from all over Australia.

The President has been very active indeed in ensuring that the televising of this chamber is done in the most appropriate way. In other words, all of those sorts of things which bring this Parliament closer to the people have been very much in the mind of the President. I congratulate him for that. The positive response of the President to the report of the Committee is taken on board. I will not go into the details because I want to deal with some of the principles behind the publication of the report and the President's response.

I think it is fair to say that the image of politicians in Australia at the moment ranks well below shonky used car salesmen. That is a real problem not only for democracy but also for the sorts of people that we will get into the chamber in the future and for the way that this Parliament operates. In many ways, the responsibility comes back to us. We cannot look at anyone else-after all, we are the legislators. We are the ones who determine how we operate in this place. I do not particularly care if people have brawls in the House of Representatives during Question Time-maybe that is entertaining-and I do not think the fact that parliamentarians are occasionally vitriolic and nasty to each other is the real problem. It just adds a bit of drama to the occasion. On the whole, it is not a problem that afflicts this chamber.

However, a problem is the way we organise our business. It is fair to say, as many people have said, that much of our time in this place is taken up by dealing with Bills, many of which should never have come into the chamber in the first place. I am not blaming the Government; I am just blaming the process. It would not matter who was in government, it would be pretty much the same. We insist, for example, on looking in this chamber at legislation which needs to be renewed every year. The question to be asked is: should that Bill have to come in every year? Does the Parliament need to vet in detail that particular Bill?

Governments today are faced with a rolling problem of legislation, much of which emanates from the bureaucracy. Much of it is patching up bad legislation from previous sessions, written again by the bureaucracy. Parliamentarians, in a sense, have started to lose control of their own chamber. The responsibility for that does not just lie with the Government; it lies with all parties in this chamber. If we insist that a Bill comes back here to be looked at every year because we do not trust anyone, because we do not trust the Minister, we are clogging up the Parliament. We are cutting off the opportunities for debate on issues that count and we are cutting off the opportunities to make sure that this place is relevant as a debating institution to the community as a whole.

The second point which flows from that issue is the question of fixed time debates. We have just listened to a debate on a report on animal welfare. The Select Committee on Animal Welfare is about to wind up. It has presented a number of very important reports. Those reports are relevant to a wide section of Australians-from people involved in animal sport, to farmers, to exporters, to our rural industries. The reports are in fact very interesting. They are not the sorts of things that I would willingly pick up, but I picked them up the other day, read them and finished them. I thought that the reports were interesting. The reports would interest a lot of people in the community at large. If honourable senators look up at the broadcasting sign, they will see that the Senate is not being broadcast today. The debate on the report has not been heard by anyone in the community. The debate will get coverage in Hansard and diligent senators may decide to send out a copy to interested electors. On the whole, the impact of that report will in many ways be negated by the way in which this Parliament works.

If this Parliament is to remain relevant and to add its contribution to Australian democracy, sooner or later we have to get to a system where we have fixed time debates. We need to have a system where major issues that are coming before this Parliament-whether they be a Bill, a motion moved by the Opposition or a report tabled by a particular committee-are advertised well in advance so that interested groups, people who have a particular interest in an area, are able to turn up here or tune into us on the television or radio at a fixed time and know that that is the debate they will hear or see. How can the average farmer, for example, who is interested in reports on animal welfare find out when and where to listen in to this chamber and how to find out when such reports are on? He has to take potluck at the far end of the dial.

It may be that the real purpose of this Parliament is to pass legislation. It may be that that is the major function of this Parliament-the Government certainly thinks so. But there is another function here which we overlook and that is the function of this place as a forum for debate-for the exchange of ideas and information-which flows out to the community and back again via honourable members and senators.

We are increasingly being seen as an irrelevant institution. The report on active citizenship showed just that. What was the average young person's attitude towards members of parliament? They were seen as stiff, sterile in terms of ideas and boring. That came through over and over again. That may suit, say, third parties that tend to rely upon disaffected young people to get their votes, but that is only in the short term. Even those parties, in the long term, benefit from an active citizenry which takes an interest in major issues, is prepared to be heard, knows how to work within the system and is prepared to contribute.

Already that disaffection with politics in Australia-and in the United States and most other Western countries-is showing itself in the decline in the number of people who belong to political parties which I understand is less than one per cent of the voting population in Australia. That is a minute percentage compared with a significant number of other countries, but even numbers in those countries are declining because, again, most of their institutions behave like ours. We do not give the consumers, that is, the voters, the opportunity to anticipate what is going on here and to play some role-if nothing else than simply listening at an appropriate time to hear the issues that they regard as important being debated.

We can televise this chamber until the cows come home. We can set rules about what should be included during that televising of Parliament-for example, we must not make the chamber look too empty, according to the rules that we have written; people can dress for television and wear the right ties and the rest it-but at the end of the day that is going to have very little effect on young people, in particular, and their perception of this Parliament.

It is not a question of having rules or a constitution which at the end of the day decides whether or not we go down the road towards a totalitarian country; it is a question of attitudes. First of all, do our citizens care? Are they active citizens or do they want to leave it up to politicians to handle themselves? The second question is whether or not the Parliament or the parliamentary institutions are, in fact, the fulcrums or centres of debate in the community.

I asked honourable senators today how they think the major debates that are going on out there-the major concerns that people have-are being reflected in this place or in the House of Representatives. Is there a real exchange and interchange of ideas between the political parties? Is there any indication that we, as individuals and as a corporate group, are prepared to put ideas in the centre and to debate them? Honourable senators should look at our matters of public importance-the MPIs that we have every week. They should look at the subject matter. Generally speaking, such motions relate only to economic behaviour-how the Budget should have been readjusted by the Government and how our fiscal policy as a government is extremely poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Glad you admit it.

—No, I am saying that this is what the MPIs put up by the Opposition have said. Occasionally, there are MPIs on unemployment. Three Opposition members will get up on one side and bash the Government, and Government members will get up and bash back. At the end of the day the public is no wiser and none of us are any wiser, I might say.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making about matters of public importance is that they are discussed after a couple of hours notice. A member of Parliament on our side, for example, can be told, `Oh, by the way, in about three hours time you are speaking on a matter of public importance'. It could be on the restructuring of the economy, the protection of the Argentinean ant or whatever it happens to be, and in three hours time that member would go into the chamber and debate it. Of what benefit is that type of program to anyone? Would it not have been better to have said, `The Opposition is going to move a major motion on Wednesday and notice will be given on Monday.'? Then people could prepare so that that debate would be the most positive, valuable debate we could have instead of the fairly low standard debate we tend to have in this place at the moment.

Basically, what I am saying today is that not only the Senate but also the House of Representatives have to examine very closely their procedures. We have to ensure that what is said in here is a reflection of the concerns in the community at large and is something we are prepared to stand up and be counted on. For example, gun laws are a matter of major concern in the Australian community at the moment. It is a very complex issue. How often has it been aired in this place? There are a few questions at Question Time, a couple of carefully worded replies from a Minister and one of the major issues in the Australian community goes in the front door of our Parliament and out the back door.

Yet, looking at the talent-and I use that word very carefully-that is elected to this Parliament, there are not too many drongos. There is a lot of talent in this place, and it is not used. It is a game of superficial ping-pong. I see people who came in here with me in 1983 who I knew had a lot to give and who, in a sense, intellectually are working at about half pace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly on the Government side.
—No, all around this chamber.
—You don't speak on your side.

—I will take advantage of Senator Tambling's interjection, `You don't speak on your side'. That is exactly what I am talking about. This side, on the whole, speaks less than the Opposition. Why? Because we have a legislative program to get through. Why? Because the time allowed for debates in the Senate is much greater than in the House of Representatives. For example, if we have to get legislation through by Christmas we have to sit and listen to 32 members of the Opposition debate the pig levy Bill-which may or may not be important-while one or two Government members will get up, because if we all got up that Bill would never get through.
—You didn't even put one up on wool.

—That is the problem. I am not saying that the Government is running the place perfectly, but all of us have to be honest about the way we run this chamber. I think there is room for negotiation and for us to get together and say, `What do people get out of it? What does the community get out of the way we run the Parliament currently?'. Heaven knows how the Australian Democrats, for example, respond to the avalanche of Bills that come in here and cover so many portfolios.
—We manage.
—Yes, they manage. That is what they do. That is all they do. They just manage to get by. Half of their responses to legislation are not what they could be.
—Wait for tonight.
—Maybe tonight will bring in a new era in this Parliament where we do not put through half-baked motions and amendments here and there.
—If legislation was better, you would not have these problems.

—Senator Lees is getting party political again. She is saying that if the legislation were better we would not have to amend it so much and therefore the place would run smoothly. That is not the case. The case is more as to the way in which we organise the whole of this Parliament. Of course the Government has a role to play. It has to organise its legislative program more efficiently. That means, for example, making some of the public servants in this town-who, incidentally, in many cases at the top level earn more than do the majority of us-work in January so that when we come back here the program is ready. Similarly, if some of the questioning that goes on in Estimates Committees-the thousands upon thousands of questions on notice that bog down departments and get nowhere-in some way were given a focus by Opposition members, if those opposite adopted tactics and a strategy to make their approach more efficient, there would be more time to do other things in this place, to debate the major issues that I think the community wants debated.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the program over the past five years in the Senate, one can see why the Australian public is turning off us at a thousand miles an hour. If senators do not believe that, they should ask why we are sitting at the end of the ABC dial. We should ask why the only thing that the press seems interested in at the moment is corruption among politicians.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the leadership.

—And the leadership. In terms of issues that ought to be taking precedence in the community, particularly political issues, surely they are not the only things that are happening in the community. We have a million unemployed out there. There is no easy answer to it but I do not hear too much discussion in this place that could be called a worthy approach to that issue. It is the ping-pong of defence, counter-defence, attack and so on between the Government and the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I am going on record today because after seven years in this place and nearly six years in a State parliament, I can see parliaments becoming more irrelevant year by year. The position, the respect given to politicians and the satisfaction they get from their jobs are also declining. I ask senators to look at the turnover. The average time that people stay in this place is now about eight years; they are in and they are out. We are starting to get a phenomenon now which is called the drop-dead phenomenon, where people come in here and at about age 45 or 50 start making a decision about their lives. They say `What am I achieving?'. If they have another option out there, they will go.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't blame them.

—As Senator Lewis says, one does not blame them, because for the most part the majority of people in this chamber are irrelevant. One does one's little bit but most people here are working at about half the effectiveness they should be because of the way in which this place operates. We can blame no-one else but ourselves. Every time we have moved to improve the Standing Orders to make sure that the rules govern the way in which this place runs, we have bogged ourselves down in a suspicious game of chess. `If the Liberals want this, we had better check this very carefully', says the Government, `because there may be some reason why they want it. They may get an advantage'. The Opposition says, `If the Government wants this particular move, we had better look at it pretty suspiciously'. The Australian Democrats say, `We will be cut out if we are not careful'.

SPEECH.PARA: There are lots of people who will have to give a little. For example, we should ask ourselves about fixed time debates. If three o'clock on a Wednesday is the time when a major debate occurs, and everyone knows that with three days notice of the fact that that topic will be debated, who gets an advantage? The Liberals have said that it is the Government because it can organise its PR. The Government says that it is the Opposition because it can make a major attack on the Government and embarrass it. The Democrats say that because there are two major parties, they will not get a look in.

The fact is that nobody specifically benefits. The people who perform benefit; the Parliament benefits if the level of debate goes up. If people improve their preparations, if people actually debate an issue rather than just shout across the chamber at each other, the Parliament benefits-not one party over another. When we come back to a review of the Standing Orders again, we must look at it objectively and fairly. Only a fool thinks it is better to ruin a Parliament or the parliamentary institution over a long period than to lose an advantage to the other side.

I am an historian by trade. Uruguay was considered to be one of the most viable democracies in the world. It is now a dictatorship. It has gone through the most horrendous persecution of out-groups, breaches of civil liberties and so on, all in about 20 years, because it did not nurture its democracy. The Weimar Republic had the best constitution probably written this century-the freest, the most caring of individual liberties and rights, with nice checks and balances built into the system. But by 1933 Germany was a dictatorship because of apathy. The apathy that the community in Germany was showing was a very dangerous seed bed for Hitler. People lost confidence in the economy. They started to look for scapegoats and so on. They looked for someone who would give them simple answers, and they got him.

The road to democracy, or the road away from it, is not a fixed one. Every community has to reassess its position every decade or so. In America they are just starting to do that now. They are saying, `How come only 50 per cent of eligible voters bother to vote for the President? How come people take the law into their own hands in so many places? What is wrong with our system?'. Then on the other hand one has the Soviets inching bit by bit towards a democracy. They may not even make it, who knows, but it is a very exciting time. All is change, as Heraclitus says.

I am leaving the Senate with a message because I want to be on record about this report. This report was just a start. It was an attempt to try to look at the way we get young people in particular to treasure their democracy, to treasure their right to participate in organisations that affect their lives. This Parliament is one of those organisations. We shall have to start thinking very carefully about where we stand in terms of the respect young people give us, the impact that we have on the community, and how we can improve that. It goes far beyond party politics. It goes to the core of the sort of political system we want. Do we want a system run by the elite with the apathetic majority just going along, or one which is a culmination of a proper participatory democracy? I seek leave to continue to my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the thirty-third report of the Committee of Privileges concerning a person referred to in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

This is the thirteenth report of the Committee of Privileges concerning a matter raised by a person under Privilege Resolution 5 of 25 February 1988. On 21 August 1991, the President, Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, referred a letter from Dr Alex Proudfoot relating to the remarks made by Senator Reynolds in the Senate on 30 May and to a question on notice, a response to which was published in Hansard on 14 August 1991.

The Committee has considered the submission and recommends that a response agreed to by Dr Proudfoot and the Committee be incorporated in Hansard. In making this recommendation, the Committee wishes to emphasise that, as with all matters of this nature, the Committee does not judge the truth or otherwise of statements made by honourable senators or persons, but rather it ensures that a person's submission and, ultimately, the response recommended by the Committee accord with the criteria set out in Privilege Resolution 5.

I might just elaborate on that point because there has been some publicity which from time to time has indicated that there is a failure by people in the real world to understand what the Privileges Committee is in fact saying in matters such as this. I can understand that because we do not expect people to be reading resolutions of the Senate. The situation is simply that when the Committee considers a submission under this resolution and reports, the Committee shall not consider or judge the truth of any statements made in the Senate or of the submission.

In this particular case, we are not judging the truth or otherwise of the statements made by Senator Reynolds in relation to the question and we are not judging the truth or otherwise of the statement made by Dr Proudfoot. We are presenting to the Senate Dr Proudfoot's submission, he having convinced the Committee that he complies with the requirements of the resolution and that his statement, in accordance with the resolution of the Senate, is now succinct and strictly relevant to the questions in issue and does not contain anything offensive in character, et cetera, in accordance with what is set out in Privilege Resolution 5 of the Senate dated 25 February 1988. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The response read as follows-
RESPONSE BY DR ALEX PROUDFOOT, FRACP
AGREED TO BY DR PROUDFOOT
AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7) (B) OF THE SENATE OF
25 FEBRUARY 1988
This is a submission under the Senate's Resolution 5 of 25 February 1988.
I have been referred to in the Senate by Senator Reynolds on 30 May 1991 (Hansard, page 3943) and in a question on notice (no. 994) published in Hansard 14 August 1991 on page 369.

Although Senator Reynolds did not mention my name, I am readily identified from the details given, my case against the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (HREOC) having been reported in the media on several occasions.
On 30 May 1991 Senator Reynolds described my action against the HREOC as an ``unfortunate dispute''.

I took the action in accordance with my rights under statute, with the aim of forcing the HREOC to entertain my complaint of sex discrimination. More than two months before Senator Reynolds' remarks, the Federal Court had given judgment in my favour (Proudfoot v Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, 100 ALR 557).
I have been adversely affected by Senator Reynolds' references to me, as follows:
The reference on 30 May 1991:

People (including my superiors within the Australian Public Service (APS)) may be led to believe that my court action was frivolous or vexatious, and that I lack judgment. Such a belief would be damaging to my reputation and to my ability to perform my duties as a senior administrator within the APS.
Part (4) of question on notice no. 994:

People (including drug companies with whom I deal as a therapeutic goods administrator, patients' advocates with whom I deal in the same capacity, and patients whom I treat in the course of approved patient care work outside the APS) may be led to believe that I am biased against women, that I regard fairness as unimportant, or that I lack objectivity in dealing with particular groups.

I regard part (4) of Senator Reynolds' question as a personal slur. I believe that the implication is that since I have complained of discrimination against men, I must be biased against women and cannot be trusted to adopt an impartial approach if in the course of my official duties I am called upon to deal with anything which relates to women.
I believe that I have never acted with less than scrupulous impartiality in the performance of my duties.
Alex Proudfoot, FRACP

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works, I present reports concerning the construction of the Australian High Commission complex in Islamabad, Islamic Republic of Pakistan; the development of HMAS Albatross, Nowra, New South Wales, Stage 2; and the redevelopment by the Defence Housing Authority of Seaward Village, Perth.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.

The first report that I have just presented is for the construction of a two storey chancery building and a new two storey head of residence and the provision of associated infrastructure, such as services, parking and landscaping for the Australian mission in Islamabad, Pakistan. The estimated cost of this work is $7.992m at March 1991 prices. The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

The Committee's public hearing into the proposal was held in Canberra and officers from Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Australian Construction Services as well as representatives of the Public Sector Union, Austrade and the Foreign Affairs and Trade Association presented evidence. I mention this because, as has been the case with previous inquiries into embassy-type overseas works, the Committee was precluded from carrying out site inspections and taking evidence from Australian representatives in Pakistan by virtue of subsection 12(1) of the Public Works Committee Act.

The report, once again, draws attention to the continuing difficulty the Committee faces in assessing overseas projects because of the restriction placed upon it. The report mentions that Australia's relations with Pakistan are significant. The south Asian region is of general strategic concern to Australia and Australia and Pakistan have longstanding trade links.

At present, the High Commission is housed in a building which was constructed in 1976 to accommodate the mission's garages, workshops and stores. Similarly, the official residence consists of an inappropriate and poorly maintained leased house which required major maintenance and repairs before it was occupied. The Government of Pakistan allocated a 1.45 hectare site in 1965 for the chancery and head of mission residence.

The Committee concluded, on the basis of written and oral evidence, that there is a need for a functional high commission complex which will project Australia's presence and reflect the importance that Australia places on its relations with Pakistan. The report also recommends that a permanent building services officer be located at the new High Commission.

The second report which I have presented relates to the second stage of the development of HMAS Albatross at Nowra, New South Wales. The first stage of development of the base was the subject of an inquiry by the Committee in 1986. This second stage is for the construction of a new building to house command operations, communications and administrative functions, a new building to provide offices for technical and administrative staff of two squadrons plus the upgrading of associated hangar annexes, and the upgrading of high voltage reticulation and emergency power supply.

The estimated cost of the proposed work is $9.9m at December 1990 prices. The Committee concluded that there is a need to construct the buildings and associated engineering works to provide facilities to accommodate support functions and for the high voltage electrical services to be upgraded. The Committee also concluded that the proposed work would be adequate in meeting the need.

The Committee gave some attention to energy issues during its inquiry. The Senate will be aware that the subject of energy conservation has been highlighted in a number of recent reports by the Committee. The Committee is mindful of the Government's objective to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005. This objective is highlighted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the forward in the Energy Guide which was recently circulated to every Australian household. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that as part of the stage 2 development an energy audit should be undertaken to identify methods by which the use of electricity can be reduced. Furthermore, it was agreed that those buildings in this proposal requiring the provision of hot water should be provided with adequate solar hot water heaters. The proposal as put to the Committee stipulated the use of electric hot water heating.

The choice of electricity was the result of an analysis of life cycle costing which indicated that solar hot water heating would cost 70 per cent more than an electric system. The Committee understands that the technique of life cycle costing is one of a number of techniques available for use in analysing capital and recurrent costs associated with investment decisions. It is limited in its focus in this instance because it does not take account of other factors such as investment in power stations or greenhouse gas emissions. Accordingly, the Committee believes that, as the citizens of Australia are asked to contribute towards the achievement of the Government's objectives, it follows that government departments and agencies should provide leadership in the achievement of the objectives.

The third report which I presented relates to the redevelopment of Seaward Village by the Defence Housing Authority. Seaward Village is adjacent to Campbell Barracks, Swanbourne, Perth, the home base of the Special Air Services Regiment. The proposal examined by the Committee is for the replacement of 77 substandard houses with 123 houses on 115 lots, new roads and the provision of new utility services. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $12.814m. The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed.

In doing so, the Committee has also made a number of recommendations that asbestos removal, the non-excavation of dune formations, access roads, energy targets and efficiency be carried out as part of the proposed work. As with the previous report, the Committee has recommended that the Defence Housing Authority use the concept of energy targets as a criterion by which it selects the suitability or otherwise of project homes submitted to it by builders. This recommendation is consistent with earlier reports by the Committee and reinforces the spirit of the Government's target to reduce greenhouse emissions by 20 per cent by 2005. The Committee has also recommended that the houses be provided with solar hot water heating for the same reasons as I mentioned in relation to the previous report. I commend the reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Messages from His Excellency the Governor-General were reported, informing the Senate that His Excellency had, in the name of Her Majesty, assented to the following laws:
Crimes Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991
Service and Execution of Process Amendment Act 1991
Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991 forms part of a package of six cognate Bills which are being introduced today. Taken together, these Bills increase the level of prudential protection provided to life and general insurance policy holders and provide a measure of financial support to policy holders of Occidental Life Insurance Company of Australia Limited and Regal Life Insurance Limited.
The Bills give effect to announcements made by the former Treasurer on 6 November 1990, 21 January 1991 and 11 February 1991.
The Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill now before the House sets out new rules for compulsory notification to the Minister and screening of proposals relating to:
* Acquisition or issue of significant shareholdings (15 per cent or more) in Australian insurance companies;
* Acquisition or leasing of a significant portion (15 per cent or more) of the assets of Australian insurance companies; and
* Control of agreements, whether formal or informal, relating to the directorate of Australian insurance companies.

The changes provided for in this Bill complement other measures being introduced today in the Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991 to strengthen and enhance existing insurance supervisory legislation. The Government is introducing legislation providing for the screening of proposed changes to the ownership and control of insurers in order to reduce the risk of financial loss to policy holders where inappropriate persons assume ownership or control of insurance companies.

The measures seek to preserve the good standing of these important industries and to ensure that the national interest is protected where changes to the ownership or control of insurance companies are proposed to be made.
The Bill aims to protect the public interest by:
* Ensuring that the conduct of the affairs of Australian life and general insurance companies is not adversely affected by changes in ownership or control of those companies;
* Preventing unsuitable persons from acquiring a position of influence over Australian life and general insurance companies;

* Preventing transactions or arrangements which would result in undue concentration of economic power in the Australian life insurance industry, the Australian general insurance industry or the Australian financial system generally; and
* Preventing transactions which would be contrary to the national interest.

In developing the measures contained in this Bill, the Government has taken into account other comparable legislation including the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975 and similar legislation operating in the United Kingdom.
The Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill is structured in 10 parts.
Part 1 provides a number of necessary formal provisions, a clear statement of objects, and a simplified outline of the Bill. It also defines key terms and concepts for the purposes of this Act.
Parts 2, 3 and 4 deal with the acquisition of ownership or control of Australian insurance companies. The parts deal with acquisitions by means of:
* Issue or acquisition of shares;
* Acquisition or leasing of assets; and
* Agreements relating to company directorships.
In particular, the 3 parts provide for:
* A trigger threshold of 15 per cent of ownership or control of a target company for purposes of notification of a proposed acquisition;
* A 30 day time-limit for the Minister to make a decision in respect of a proposal;
* The Minister to grant conditional approval, make permanent or temporary restraining orders and to make divestment orders where it is appropriate to do so; and
* Penalty provisions for contravention of orders made by the Minister.
Part 5 provides for the Federal Court to make judicial orders for the enforcement of ministerial orders made under the Bill.

Part 6 provides a mechanism to unwind schemes which may be effected to avoid the notification and approval provisions of the Bill. Part 7 empowers the Minister to set down principles, to be tabled in Parliament, to be followed in making certain decisions under the Bill.
Part 8 provides a mechanism for the review of decisions by the Minister and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Parts 9 and 10 contain a number of miscellaneous provisions of relevance to the administration and operation of the Bill. These include provisions relating to the secrecy of information provided to the Government for the purposes of the Bill.
The Bill provides that proposals involving the acquisition of ownership or control of interests in an insurer in excess of a 15 per cent threshold must be notified to the Minister.

The 15 per cent threshold is defined in terms which are sufficiently broad in scope to ensure the notification of proposals to acquire significant direct or indirect interests in an insurer. The threshold takes account of interests arising from the operation of informal agreements and understandings. It also has regard to the interests of persons who are associated with the acquirer as well as interests that may be directly held.

Under the Bill, proposals must be notified prior to the acquisition of an interest in excess of the threshold and the Minister has 30 days in which to make a decision. The Minister may decide that he has no objection to the proposal or, alternatively, that the proposal may be implemented with or without conditions. If the Minister makes no decision within the 30 day period then the proposal may be implemented.

The Minister may also issue a temporary restraining order where more time is needed to examine a proposed transaction. The life of such orders is subject to limits laid down in the Bill. Where the Minister is satisfied that the proposal is not in the public interest, he may issue a permanent restraining order.

The Bill also contains broad anti-avoidance provisions. In particular, it provides penalties for non-compliance and the Minister has power to issue a divestment order in circumstances where a person has acquired an interest in an insurer without seeking prior approval and where that acquisition is considered to be contrary to the public interest.

The need for the type of legislative controls which will be provided by this Bill was demonstrated by the circumstances leading up to the attempted sale of Occidental Life and Regal Life. In that case, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner was aware from informal industry contacts that steps were being taken to arrange for the sale of the two companies.
His attempts to obtain precise and detailed information concerning the proposed transaction were frustrated by the lack of formal authority to investigate the matter properly.

More generally, the Commissioner has been concerned that he has been required to rely on the cooperation of the industry rather than on formal arrangements for monitoring changes to the ownership and control of life and general insurance companies. Experience has clearly shown that it is an important element of supervision to be in a position to appropriately monitor significant transactions of this nature.

Such monitoring arrangements are important not only for prudential purposes but also to place the Government in a position to effectively monitor changes which could lead to undue concentration of power in the insurance industry and financial markets generally.

In framing the Bill, the Government has been aware of the need to build in appropriate safeguards and review provisions in order to avoid unnecessary intervention in the operation of the market. Accordingly, the Bill contains measures for the protection of the rights and interests of persons and companies affected by its operation. In particular, the Bill contains appropriate secrecy provisions and review provisions which will give scope for appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in respect of key decisions under the Act.

In summary, the measures being introduced in this Bill are designed to further protect the interests of insurance consumers as well as the broader national interest. The Bill does not unduly interfere with the open and competitive market for insurance business. At the same time it provides clear rules and guidelines with respect to the ownership and control of insurance companies while providing for the protection of the privacy of affected individuals.
Financial Implications

The measures contained in this Bill to provide for the screening of changes to the ownership and control of insurance companies, together with the improved prudential arrangements contained in the Companion Insurance Laws Amendment Bill 1991, will result in additional supervisory costs being incurred by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.
The additional resources needed to give effect to these measures have been estimated at $510 000 in 1990-91, $785 000 in 1991-92 and $410 000 in both 1992-93 and 1993-94.

These additional costs will be fully recovered through the life insurance and general insurance supervisory levies. It is for this purpose that the Life Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991 and the General Insurance Supervisory Levy Amendment Bill 1991 are included in the package of Bills before the House.
I commend the Insurance Acquisitions and Takeovers Bill 1991 to the Senate and present the related explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.
