DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Wool Tax (No. 1) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 209 and made under the Wool Tax Act (No. 1) 1964, be disallowed.
That the Wool Tax (No. 2) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 210 and made under the Wool Tax Act (No. 2) 1964, be disallowed.
That the Wool Tax (No. 3) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 211 and made under the Wool Tax Act (No. 3) 1964, be disallowed.
That the Wool Tax (No. 4) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 212 and made under the Wool Tax Act (No. 4) 1964, be disallowed.
That the Wool Tax (No. 5) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1991 No. 213 and made under the Wool Tax Act (No. 5) 1964, be disallowed.
The Opposition has consistently called on the Government to introduce a wool tax at the rate of 10 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The affordable rate.

—The affordable rate, as Senator Brownhill quite rightly points out. Consistently through the debates that have taken place in this chamber-and in the House of Representatives-in June, and subsequently when we returned recently in August, we have taken the view that 10 per cent is the maximum rate of wool tax that should have been implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: In moving this motion today I have drawn the Senate's attention to the list of instruments with regard to the regulations to implement the wool tax. There are five specific regulations contained in the various statutory rules. In moving this motion I am putting forward the view which the Opposition has continuously held and which it believes has been sustained on the economic benefits, the formulas and all of the processes that have been put before the Parliament at the time of consideration of this matter in June and more recently in August.

We have previously spoken in favour of a wool tax levy of 10 per cent. It was only the combined action of the Labor Government and the Australian Democrats that resulted in a compromise. The Government originally proposed a 15 per cent levy, but by agreement between the Government and the Democrats the figure of 12 per cent was arrived at. Again, I stress the point that we believe the economics and the situation of the industry totally support a maximum levy of 10 per cent. That point needs to be stressed over and over again. The figure of 10 per cent is probably rather conservative.

It is very interesting that we have not been able to get the Government to agree to any further changes. It is also interesting to note that these regulations apply only for a period of 12 months. The legislation that was introduced into the Parliament in June put in place a 15 per cent levy, and it was only because of the agreement that was struck in the dying stages of that session of Parliament that the Democrats agreed to implement the 12 per cent levy. On a subsequent reading of that process of legislation we found that it applied only for a 12-month period. Therefore, at some stage in the future the tax will revert to a rate of 15 per cent. We do not believe that on any of the arguments that have been presented-whether by ABARE or industry sources, or through economic analyses that have been done in various academic institutions or by people who are close to industry-this figure can be proved, sustained or, in effect, borne by the wool industry.

We are well aware that Australia is currently caught up in a very severe recession. This has dramatic effects on the primary industries of Australia. The primary producers are being asked to bear unnecessary additional costs at a time of extreme problems in their industry that have been totally forced on them by the policies of the Hawke Labor Government. We need to look at the plight of those in the bush, primary industry and the many people who live in remote and rural Australia who are caught up in the implications of these policies.

Nobody can deny that it is by the very firm and deliberate action of the Hawke Labor Government that people in rural Australia are suffering. They are suffering personally. They are suffering industry by industry. They are suffering in the associated communities, towns and supporting industries that have been so drastically affected by all of the policies of the Government.

We noted recently in the Budget that the Hawke Labor Government marched forward with a bigger, better cities-brighter program-or whatever it wants to call it, and somehow plucked out of the air $800m for a program to improve urban centres. Yet when we really look at the productive industries and productive sectors, we show up the hypocrisy of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't get much of a wool clip in the cities.

—Yes, but that $800m promise has been cast off into the future. There is only $50m of it in this year's program. When we analyse where that $50m is to be spent, it is worth noting that it is only in Newcastle, Sydney, Wollongong, Melbourne and Geelong. It is nothing but a marginal seat survival strategy by the Hawke Labor Government and has no bearing whatsoever on the productive sectors of the economy. Nothing has been forthcoming from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) as a result of the recent Budget that would allay the fears of those people who are producing the wealth of this nation and, particularly, the woolgrowers. It is for that reason that we bring forward this motion to disallow the regulations on the wool tax levy and call on the Government to make regulations at the far more appropriate level of 10 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we are again, probably for the fifth time this year, debating a wool measure-in this case wool tax regulations. It is a pity that we do not have a Minister at the table who knows something about the situation or, indeed, the same Minister who did the deal with the Australian Democrats. At this time and ever since then the coalition has demonstrated that a 10 per cent levy was enough. In fact, we had figures which showed that 9.2 per cent was enough.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that our projections have improved since then. Production is lower than the figure used at that time which, from memory, was 885 million kilos. Prices have been consistently above the 450c a kilo figure which was used in the exercise. The price is still over 500c a kilo, even with the higher volume that has been coming forward onto the market in the last few weeks. Our figures, and I believe even the Government figures, were based on 450c a kilo for 21 micro wool. There have been higher clearances of the stockpile than expected by the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. We were saying this back in February, March, April, May and again in the dying stages of last session. At least the Government and the Government advisers-if there is not a Minister who is interested in the situation-should have known that what we were saying was correct.

I thought there would have been some change by the time these regulations had come before us. But, no, the Government has decided to stay with it. My opposition has increased since we realised that the Minister misled the Senate by not advising that promotion had been cut from 3.5 to 2.5 per cent; in other words, reduced by one per cent. Nobody on this side of the chamber was told about this on the last night of the autumn sittings. The Democrats gave in and accepted 12 per cent. Senator Bell has just indicated that the Democrats were not told.

At the time the Minister at the table, assisted by Mr Crean, pretended that they were giving the Democrats something but they gave us nothing. It was just the three card trick-that is, they were giving in at 12 per cent and that 12 per cent was for one year only. These things only came out later. Perhaps even the Democrats would not have taken the same decision that evening had they actually known what the Government was offering. The Government got the Bill through that night by deceit. It did not put all the cards on the table.

The Government gave nothing away that night and, of course, it is not giving away anything now. We have argued since February, April and the last night of the sittings-21 June-that our figures are affordable. Although there has been a lot of shearing, less wool is coming through because the cut is lower than expected. The whole of Western Australia is down about 20 per cent and parts of the eastern States are also down. Next year's clip will also be down judging by the seasons that have been experienced in the east, in South Australia as well as in the west. The Government should see the light now because things are tough out in those places. Farmers are finding life very tough because of this levy along with the other non-measures in the Budget that Senator Tambling has already mentioned. A reduction in this wool levy would help to ease this situation.

I have said here in this chamber before that we should not have continued that night; once we had defeated the Bill we should have shut the Senate down and gone home. But we on this side, out of the goodness of our hearts, let the Government have another go for 10 minutes. That 10 minutes, as I said before, went to 40 minutes. The Minister at the table at the time could not think, Mr Crean intervened and something was sorted out.

I look again to the Democrats for support in defeating these regulations tonight. The threat of a 15 per cent levy is hanging over us. If we do not defeat these regulations we will have the 15 per cent. I could support a figure of 12 per cent for the rest of the five years. But these regulations, as Senator Tambling has already mentioned and as I am sure Senator Crane will also mention, set the rate at 12 per cent for 12 months. But then it reverts to 15 per cent. So, unless for some reason an amendment came before this chamber, we would have to wait 4 1/2 years before we could look at the 15 per cent again.

I call on the Democrats to think about it again. If we are going to finish up with 15 per cent after this year, we may as well take the risk of finishing up with the 15 per cent now. As I said before, we were hoodwinked into this by deceitful means. We were not given the full facts and, as far as I am concerned, that is a matter of deceit. I believe that we have always been on the right track. I think the next 4 1/2 to five years will prove that everything we have said during this wool debate was correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, the Opposition is calling on the Government to lower the wool levy to 10 per cent. By moving to disallow the 12 per cent levy that the Government has put forward in the regulations presently before the Senate, we realise that it is only for 12 months. In 12 months time the Government could raise that levy. But in the meantime, we can do nothing. We already know that there is no need for a 12 per cent levy. We know that we have already sold over 100,000 bales from the stockpile; and we know that the prices of wool are very much greater than earlier anticipated. On our side of the Parliament we had already come to the decision that a 10 per cent levy was more than adequate. This gave us a buffer of 0.9 per cent for things to go wrong because our figures proved that there was no need for a levy higher than 9.1 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether Government senators opposite realise the extent of unemployment in the bush. We are worried about unemployment in the cities but there is horrendous unemployment in Tasmanian bush areas. Young people are moving out of the bush into the cities to try to get work because there is absolutely nothing for them, even on one-man family properties. Yet, the Government is insisting on an additional 2 per cent levy that is not needed. The other day on the Today Show the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) showed that he was out of touch with the people of Australia when he said that John Hewson did not have any compassion because he owned a Ferrari.

The people ridiculed the Prime Minister, with his mansion worth $1.4m, and he could not understand why. We have a Budget with absolutely no compassion at all for unemployed people and absolutely no compassion for the wool growers of Australia who are being charged an extra and unnecessary 2 per cent extra levy, thus making jolly sure that there is no way they can afford to employ anyone on their properties, perhaps even their own sons and ensuring that they have to leave and go to the cities.

As Senator Panizza said, the Government was so deceitful in the original debate that it did not mention that it would claw back, on that 12 per cent levy towards the 15 per cent which it thought was necessary, an additional one per cent from the promotion of wool. We on this side of the chamber were unaware of that. I am quite sure that the Australian Democrats were unaware of it as well. The Government did not bother to tell us. The deceit was unbelievable. The lack of accountability of the Government was also unbelievable. I have with me an Auditor-General's report entitled Potential Erosion of Accountability to the Parliament. That report deals with the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill 1991 and the Australian Wool Corporation Bill 1991. It says:

The introduction and passage of these Bills with the current audit provisions could have a significant and serious effect on the ability of the Parliament to exercise the responsibilities entrusted to it by the Australian people.
The Auditor-General stated:
I am very concerned that a continuing effort to weaken the Parliament's role in the scrutiny and reporting on the activities of all public sector entities appears to be gaining strength.
This is the Auditor-General speaking of the Government. He continued:

In the early hours of 31 May 1991, without consultation with the ANAO, two Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives which tilt the balance against the Parliament's scrutiny, through the Auditor-General's involvement in the audit, of public-sector entities.

This action was despite the Government's decision that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities announced in a statement by the Government on 6 December 1990 in response to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' examination. . .
He continued:

While paying lip service to the Government decision, these Bills allow the entities to recommend the appointment of auditors other than the Auditor-General and put the onus on the Minister for Finance to explain why he declines to appoint a recommended private sector auditor. No such explanation is required if the Minister excludes the Auditor-General. The reverse should be the case, given that a private auditor is without responsibility to the Parliament.
He continued:

The fact that some States have found it necessary to tighten accountability by strengthening the roles of the Auditors-General in the light of recent history should be sufficient warning against the dilution of the Parliament's and the Auditor-General's role.
He further continued:

Parliament (and the public) have a right to know what has been done with power and/or taxpayers' resources granted or guaranteed to any group. This right will be undermined if the current attempt to weaken the audit mandate of the Auditor-General succeeds.
I hope this is a mistake which will be corrected, rather than a reflection of a change in Government attitude to the role of the Parliament and the ANAO.
I ask that the Parliament consider the implications of these Bills for its ability to scrutinise what has been done in its name.

I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) whether he will answer the question that I put to him and which the Auditor-General put to the Government. We on this side of the chamber once again plead with the Government to enable the wool growers in the bush to employ more people and not to rip off another 2 per cent levy, which is totally unnecessary. It is for this reason that we move to disallow the regulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion to disallow these Wool Tax Regulations will not be supported by the Australian Democrats. However, to some extent I share Senator Panizza's argument, to which I listened carefully. I agree, and I think it is quite evident, that circumstances within the wool industry have changed since the original assessment was made by the Government to recommend its particular level of taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what we were arguing in the original debate. We argued that the circumstances had changed since the initial assessment and the justification for 15 per cent. However, the figure of 12 per cent was the one which we proposed as an amendment and the figure which was finally achieved. It is true that during the debate, as Senator Walters and Senator Panizza pointed out-although I was not here for Senator Tambling's speech, I know he strongly feels this way too-there has been a sense of being misled, perhaps even cheated, by the Government not having explained to the Senate that when it agreed to the 12 per cent figure, that meant there would be a reduction in the promotion component of that levy; in other words, less of the levy would be spent on promotion. I share that sense of having been misled.

Having taken all that on board and thought about it, I have not changed my reaction to the proposal. There are two factors involved. The first factor is that I fail to see how, by disallowing these regulations, we can come up with any figure other than 15 per cent-the figure set by legislation. The Opposition has not been able satisfactorily to explain how any other figure can be delivered, if these regulations are disallowed. They cannot be amended; they simply must be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government can come back and amend them.

—The Government can fly to the moon as far as I am concerned. The Government can do what it likes. I know what it will do: it will sit on 15 per cent, because it was such a battle to get it off the 15 per cent to start with.
—And slug the wool growers even more.

—That is precisely what I think. I think that once we have the Government in that position we do not need to let it off the hook. That is one aspect. The other aspect that concerns me is the suggestion that the 12 per cent levy is for one year only. I think it is perfectly accurate to say that. But to suggest that the Government will be solely responsible for setting the next year's levy is to misunderstand what we have been able to achieve by means of the legislation. Next year's rate will not be set by the Government acting alone. This should be appreciated. I hope that the Minister will be able to explain exactly the process for setting the next year's levy. There is a requirement for consultation. It is not a case of the Minister setting the figure by bald decree, as has been the case in the past.
—He does not have to accept that recommendation for consultation.
—I will accept Senator Walters's interjection. I agree with her. The consultation does not need to be accepted and the Minister would have it on his own head to ignore that recommendation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have faith that that process is not the same process as we had before. I would hope that it is not a misplaced faith. It is quite a risky business to come in here and say that one has faith in the process that has been laid down before, because we have already seen the lack of information-sharing which occurred on that particular night with regard to the promotion levy. My belief is that it would require quite a cavalier step for the Minister to take no notice whatsoever of that consultation process which is enshrined in the legislation itself. I hope that the Minister will explain, for the edification of the Opposition, exactly how that rate will be set in future.

For the reasons that I have outlined, I see absolutely no point in taking the risk of disallowing these regulations and hoping with crossed fingers that anything other than 15 per cent can be achieved. I think that would be a faint hope. For those reasons we stay with the 12 per cent which we were pleased to have achieved originally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the regulations that we have before us, I want to support what my colleagues have said. I want to take issue with Senator Bell's statement that we achieved amendments on the last night we debated the wool legislation. We did not achieve amendments. The Bill says 15 per cent. The Government did a deal with the Australian Democrats and we ended up with the proposal of 12 per cent by regulation, which is before us now. I also want to disagree with him very strongly because I do not believe that if these regulations were disallowed the Government would not come back to this place with revised regulations. It would not be game to put a tax of 15 per cent on the head of the wool industry when, in fact, we do not even require a 12 per cent tax. We probably do not even require a tax of 10 per cent to do the job. It is about time a little economic rationality came to the people who sit on the other side of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: We have just seen $800m handed out in the Budget to the better cities program. I am going to work through a few figures here tonight because I think they are important. I am damned furious about what this Government has done to the wool industry. I have put the figures relating to the wool industry before. For a bona fide wool grower with 5,000 sheep, the difference between 12 and 10 per cent is $1,400. To people in a secure place in a secure job, $1,400 may not sound like a large amount but, for people who are operating at a loss, it is a hell of a lot of money; it is an enormous amount of money.

If one takes the figures a bit further and looks at what is happening to the infrastructure in rural Australia one will see that for 50 such growers the difference is $70,000. For 500 such growers it is $700,000. That is an enormous cash flow through businesses, whether they be in the transport industry or the service industry, in the various country districts.

Let us recount a few of the predictions that we put forward at that particular time. I still challenge the Government, including Senator McMullan who is chatting away there rather blissfully, to put on the table the figures by which it has come to its conclusions. We have put our figures on the table. They have not been knocked off. I want to remind the Senate of them. We said that at a clean price of 447c, just under 450c, with the sale of assets and the sale from the stockpile of $74m, one could deliver a tax of marginally over 9 per cent. Nobody has knocked those figures off.

I want to recap a little on what has happened in the wool industry since last year. Last week's price, even with the Russian coup and the disruption that caused to the market, was still sitting at 512c. The market last week stabilised at that when Japanese and western Europe buyers came back into the market, and 87 per cent of the wool was sold.

Prior to the Russian coup, the wool market was sitting at about 544c, and that is where it has come back from. It was significantly above and is still significantly above the figures that we worked from. On top of that, looking at the figures for last March, we were talking about 913 million kilograms of production. That was revised to 885 million kilograms of production.

Let us now look at the latest predictions from the Wool Council of Australia today. I also gather from survey work myself that the prediction now is of the order of 860 million kilograms, not the 885 million kilograms that was being predicted. So there is a logical reason why the Government should move to allow this additional cash flow from a lower tax to move through the industry.

Let us look at what has occurred in the three months to the end of last week in terms of sales from the stockpile. On our figures, we said there would be a requirement to sell $74m from the stockpile during the next 12 months. As of last week, 118,134 bales had been sold, at a value of $76m; so that figure has already been exceeded in three months. Whatever analysis is placed on the position we are at, it is not necessary to continue with this 12 per cent figure. It will have a significant impact on the ability of people to stay in the industry. I can tell the Senate now that there are many people in rural Australia who are absolutely incensed by Mr Kerin's statement, when he was Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, that it looked as though something of the order of 48,000 farmers would have to go.

If we continue to tax an industry out of business, like this Government is taxing primary producers out of business, that will eventuate. It is not necessary; it shows a lack of concern. People on the other side of the chamber have forgotten the meaning of the word compassion, which has already been raised in the debate today. They have forgotten what the Labor Party is about.

Let us look at the challenge that now exists in terms of the wool industry and its ability, if it is handled correctly, to address the twin evils of unemployment and bankruptcy. The challenge now, with what has occurred in eastern Europe, is to move into those countries and market our wool and set up structures by which we can start to get sales moving again. I put the question to the Minister at the table, Senator Cook: what is happening now in terms of Russia? What is happening now in terms of the Baltic states? What is happening in terms of Czechoslovakia, Poland or Hungary in regard to the marketing of our wool and getting it back into the factories that have been very important to this country and its wool industry over recent years? What trading arrangements are being looked at?

I also put the challenge to Senator Cook, as I did to Senator McMullan when he was in here, to spell out quite clearly the basis for staying with the 12 per cent. All economic analysis that we on this side of the chamber, including me and the people who work with me, can put together shows that it is not necessary and that, with what has occurred, less than 10 per cent will be what is required. When we look at those particular figures, we must bear in mind the debt reduction scheme that was put in place by this Government. Even before 30 June, almost the first two years of that requirement had been met. That is another valid reason for easing the tax burden in these initial stages while the adjustment goes on.

In the final analysis, the level of this tax is not necessary. I do not believe that the Democrats have the courage to support us or that if they did the Government would have the stupidity to try to apply a 15 per cent tax. Nonetheless, I must point out that in the final analysis, when it comes to the next year-which has been raised in this debate tonight-the Government does have the final say about what the tax level will be, despite whatever consultation may go on. The real challenge tonight in terms of the Government's position is to look again; to minimise the burden on the industry; to allow the industry and those people who live in rural Australia and are involved in the industry to maximise their returns so that they can at least get close to breaking even; and to maintain the very necessary infrastructure that has been broken down so dramatically. To do otherwise would indicate to me just how callous the Government is in terms of its attitude to the wool industry and many people in rural Australia, and how it is not prepared to look at this problem we now have in an objective, rational, sensible manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on this motion for the disallowance of certain wool tax regulations. The National Party of Australia took a very strong stand on this issue when it was debated at the end of the last session. We stand committed to the remarks that were made very eloquently at that stage by Senator Tambling on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing that has changed since May is that, if anything, the outlook for wool growers has got much worse. While wool prices at the start of the sales may have risen just marginally, the economic outlook is definitely no brighter. The prospect of drought has increased across much of Australia. Even where rains have fallen, there is still no opportunity for pastures to come away. The price of sheep has not improved in any substantial sense and neither has the value of the wool growing properties. In fact, the value of wool growing properties has fallen quite dramatically in some areas.

I do not intend to go over the arguments that the Opposition put forward as to why a 10 per cent tax was the appropriate level. I believe that our arguments and reasons are very well known and, as I said earlier, were very well put by everyone in the debate at the end of last session. If I had to choose just one area in which the Federal Labor Government has abandoned primary industry and let down and disappointed rural Australia it would be in the treatment of wool growers and its handling of the entire wool crisis over the past 12 to 15 months, when uncertainty was introduced into the industry by the lowering of what was going to be the immutable floor price at that stage. The uncertainty was put in by the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is now the Treasurer of the country, and then obviously had to be taken away.

I believe that the Government's handling of this issue has been, and still is, a national disgrace. Three years ago the wool industry earned some $6 billion for Australia. Today it is a quite different story. Wool growers' incomes by any ABARE or other standard for the short to medium term are desperate. Indeed, an ABARE farm survey report for 1991 predicted an 85 per cent decline in surplus income, with more than 50 per cent of Australian wool growers having a negative income this year and up to one in three forced into bankruptcy, as Senator Crane has already mentioned. The report suggested an even further decline this financial year, which I suggest vindicates even more the Opposition's stance in wanting to disallow these regulations.

We still believe that 10 per cent is the preferred tax level. In fact, it is the essential height of tax level that is sustainable and able to be paid. As I said, the Opposition's position of 10 per cent was the only sustainable option that the wool growers could afford to pay. What needs to be remembered is the capacity of these wool growers to pay any tax. Senator Crane has made that very clear with some of the figures that he has put to the Senate over time.

I suggest that honourable senators on all sides of this chamber should go out and meet with a few wool growers, especially in the western divisions, just to see how things really are. They would get completely different opinions of what they think is happening and what really is happening. I also suggest that a few people from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy should go out and see how it really is and not just look from the cosy confines of Canberra.

We have already witnessed properties from which families have simply walked away. There has been no talking to the banks or calling in agricultural consultants to help with the package. The situation is so desperate that the only hope is to abandon the farms. These are not the Depression years of the 1930s but, basically, for many farmers they may as well be. This Government will stand indicted for what it has done to the rural industries of Australia.

Even today we heard in Question Time the admission by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, that charges to commuter airlines such as Hazelton had increased substantially and were a part of the problem of that airline having to cut back substantially in rural areas. Senator Collins was unable to deny that Government imposed charges had forced this airline to give up no less than 14 services to rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Primarily wool growing areas.
—That is right. The Government has no regard for or interest in what is happening in the rural parts of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Last month we had a Budget. It seems a long time ago. There was nothing in it for rural Australia, save an increase of 34 per cent in charges at a time when farmers in all industries are basically on their knees. As Senator Crane, Senator Tambling and Senator Walters said, $800m was allocated to the cities. Apparently, that was the only solution to the problems of Australia that the Labor Party had. But wait a minute-$100m was given in rural assistance over the next few years to the farmers who are going out the back door.

Where are the policies that will get us back on the road? Where are the policies that will get the rural industries and, indeed, our economy back on track? There are none. Where are the programs that would address the difficulties faced by nearly one million people, especially our young, chronically unemployed? There are no programs, and that is what saddens me. We have programs. We have policies for taxation reform, labour market reform, increasing the efficiency of infrastructure, privatisation, fixing up things in transport and fixing up the waterfront. They are all things that this Government should be doing now. It should not be waiting for us to win the next election and then do them; they should be done now. That would at least help the wool growers and the people of rural Australia a little.

This Government made a mistake with its legislation in the first place. It set a level that was unaffordable and unsustainable for the wool growers. The Senate provided the Government with a way out and an opportunity to save what little credibility it might have had within the industry. The Government has chosen to be pig-headed about the level of the tax. Tonight the Opposition reaffirms its position for a 10 per cent maximum tax for the wool industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a notice of motion in the name of Senator Tambling regarding the disallowance of wool tax regulations Nos 1 to 5. Before I turn to my formal rebuttal of the arguments presented by the Opposition in this debate, I must say that I am struck by the weird set of circumstances. Those opposite must be saying a prayer of thanks for the good grace of whoever it was that put them into opposition during a time of rural downturn which has been caused principally by international factors. Those opposite must be saying a prayer because it gives them the luxury of never having to make a decision about how to contend with the difficulties but always having the luxury of criticising what is done. Thus they can be pure to their own rural constituencies without having to shoulder the responsibilities of good government.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the argument which has been put is based on the thinking, `Thank God we don't have to make the decisions, but we'll as sure as hell give those who do a run for their money and appeal to populist sentiment rather than good governance'.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is nonsense! Absolute nonsense!
—In my time?

—Yes, in the honourable senator's time and in the time of Senator Winston Crane. Much of the criticism here is based on the populist notion that if one simply declines to face the difficulties and argues a more sentimental cause, one is somehow doing a service. One may be doing oneself a service in terms of re-election, but one is not doing oneself a service in terms of facing the difficult, thorny questions associated with managing an industry when world markets have closed and prices have tumbled. They are serious questions which require not populist sentiment but serious answers.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to wool tax regulations Nos 1 to 5. The 1991-92 wool tax rate was dealt with exhaustively by the Parliament at the end of the last sitting. The arguments in favour of a 10, 12 and 15 per cent tax were canvassed extensively in both Houses at that time. The Opposition has now sought to disallow the regulations for the 12 per cent wool tax for allocating 9 per cent to debt reduction, 2.5 per cent to promotion, and 0.5 per cent to research and development. It should be noted that were the Opposition's motion to be successful, it would raise the wool tax rate to the 15 per cent maximum set in the wool tax Acts. Were the disallowance of the 2.5 per cent allocation for promotion to be successful, the full 15 per cent would still be collected, but none would be allocated for promotion.

The Senate cannot amend the tax rate in the regulations. It can only disallow what is there and hope that the Government will put forward new regulations in line with the Senate's views. However, the Government is not obligated to do that; it could persist and put forward regulations in the same terms as the disallowed regulations.

In moving for disallowance, the Opposition is not presenting new information in this debate. It is arguing from the basis of the information it presented to the Senate in June which was criticised then by both the Government and the Australian Democrats. That information is now more than just a little out of date. Although the Opposition used information based on an average wool price of 475c for 1991-92, the Opposition members expected higher prices. Senator Boswell told us that we were in a rising wool market; Senator Archer stressed this too, as did Senator Chapman. Senator Panizza, who is one of the interjectors here tonight, told us that the wool price in June was 33 per cent higher than that 475c average. Senator Crane-another interjector tonight-used the futures market prices to argue that a forecast price of 475c for 1991-92 was too low.

However, the Opposition's expectations for the market have not materialised. The price at last Friday's close of trading was 512c on the new indicator price, or 489c on the old indicator. In June the Government argued that a lower tax rate meant less income for the Australian Wool Realisation Commission, in particular, and that in order to cover its fixed costs it would have to sell more wool from the stockpile which would bring more wool into the market and depress the price. As it is, the price of wool, not the tax rate, is the determinant of growers' income. Lower prices mean lower grower incomes.

The Opposition is now advocating lower wool tax on an already soft wool market and is, in effect, seeking to soften the market further. By advocating the lowering of the wool tax payable to the Wool Realisation Commission from 9 per cent-which the Government made effectively 10 per cent by providing a $22.5m grant-to 6 per cent, the Opposition is arguing that the income position of wool growers will be improved by requiring the AWRC to sell another $60m worth of wool. The Opposition will not accept that argument, but it follows inescapably from the course of action that the Opposition has been advocating here tonight.

The Government rejects the disallowance of the 12 per cent total tax rate. The Opposition has argued that the 12 per cent tax rate applies only for 1991-92 and that, therefore, the tax will revert to 15 per cent. The Government has stated repeatedly that it is its intention to lower the wool tax rate by regulation as soon as possible-hopefully, in 1992-93. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) made this quite clear in the House of Representatives the week before last. He said that if the wool tax rate was 15 per cent this year he could guarantee that it would be lower next year. With the tax at 12 per cent he could not guarantee a lower rate, but he said that it was his intention to lower the rate if this was possible.

The Opposition's contention that the rate will revert to 15 per cent next year has no support in fact. Moreover, as Senator Bell points out, there is a consultation process laid out in the legislation for the period after 1 July 1992 and the industry will have a say; that is, recommendations for the wool tax rate for research and development and promotion will be considered by annual general meetings of wool growers to be held in and about May next year. Those recommendations will be forwarded to the Minister. As well, recommendations for the wool tax rate for debt reduction will be considered by the Wool Council of Australia and then forwarded to the Minister. The recommendations on the three parts of the wool tax will then be taken into account in the setting of the total wool tax. Therefore, industry will have a full say in the wool tax rate beyond 1 July 1992; it will not revert automatically to 15 per cent.

I now turn to the matters raised by Senator Walters. In relation to Senator Walters's question regarding the audit of the wool industry authorities by a private auditor, I remind her that the Government accepted Opposition amendments and that the Auditor-General is the auditor for the wool industry's bodies.

Finally, Senator Crane raised the issue of what trading arrangements are being looked at for the Soviet Union and eastern European states. Senator Crane may remember that in December 1990 a $500m 240-day revolving credit line was provided to the USSR for the purchase of wool, wheat and meat. Some $420m of that amount has now been taken up; so there is a positive commitment by this Government to penetrate the eastern European market further.

Obviously, the trade situation in eastern Europe is fluid. At present, the Soviet authorities are very busy restructuring their economy. Nonetheless, this Government has provided that revolving credit line and, as well, it has provided a separate credit facility for Poland.

In all of those circumstances, I conclude my remarks in this debate by saying that on this occasion I welcome the support, as voiced by Senator Robert Bell, of the Australian Democrats in not voting for the disallowance. I think many of the arguments that he has raised and presented are sound. I have quoted, in particular, one of those in my remarks.

I think that the Opposition should have a good look at itself. If the Opposition is not congratulating itself for being in Opposition and not having to face hard decisions, I wonder how it would face up to hard decisions were it ever to be in government. For those reasons the Government rejects the disallowance of a 12 per cent total tax rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In bringing the debate on the motion to disallow Wool Tax Regulations Nos 1 to 5 to a close, I point out that once again not one Australian Labor Party senator participated in a substantive way in the debate. We certainly heard the response of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), as is usual in any of the primary industry debates. We always get the Minister's predictable words and the briefs that he has been handed and given. It is very interesting that even on this occasion the Labor Party's one usual voice, Senator West, was again muzzled and is missing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister, in his response, made a number of very interesting points that, of course, do not take account of the changed circumstances in the industry or in economics. The compounding effects of the failed Labor Budget, of course, have produced so many other effects that are deliberately compounding on the industry at this particular time: the primary charges, the interest rates regime, the wholesale sales tax that has been continued, the transport costs that will be passed on through roads, rail and airlines. We heard from Senator Brownhill today on several occasions with regard to the catastrophe of Hazelton Airlines in New South Wales, which vitally affects this industry. There are also the increased household and domestic costs.

Senator Cook said that the Opposition had resorted to sentimentality and that it was basking in a luxury of the rural downturn. What a hypocritical load of nonsense! The coalition certainly in no circumstances engineered the recession or caused the unemployment of millions of people around Australia.

Let me remind the Senate that it was the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who said that there would be no child living in poverty. What we now have is a million Australian families living in poverty. What an exchange! How many of those are caught up in the primary industry sectors?

The Minister did not counter the figures that were presented by us throughout this debate this year. Instead, he fudged and fiddled whilst Rome burnt. Whether it is Prime Minister Hawke, Mr Kerin, Mr Crean or Senator Cook-they are still fiddling while more than Rome burns in Australia.

The threat that the Government could revert to the 15 per cent tax is nothing short of bully boy tactics that are totally unnecessary. I certainly hope that when the Parliament considers these regulations again, the Government will have better advisers, better representatives and better economists looking over its shoulder than those it has had this year. It certainly is a very sad day today when the Government and the Australian Democrats will not support a much more appropriate 10 per cent wool tax levy.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Tambling's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now debating the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. Many Bills going through this place deal with specific matters and some others deal with a wide variety of matters under one particular portfolio. In a sense, we kid ourselves that these Bills can be regarded as one package and called an omnibus Bill, when really such a Bill is an amendment to a whole variety of Bills. That is the case with the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: The more substantial amendments that this Bill makes are to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Act 1979 and the Trade Practices Act 1974. There are less substantive amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933, the Bills of Exchange Act 1909, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977, the Family Law Act 1975, the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, the Law Officers Act 1974 and the Statutory Declarations Act 1959. There are also some substantial amendments to the Privacy Act 1988.

The ASIO Act 1979 is amended by inserting a reference to the Crimes (Hostages) Act 1989 in the definition of politically motivated violence. The amendments also provide for the ACT to be in the same position as the States and the Northern Territory in relation to the performance of functions by ASIO. Other changes are made relating to the inspection of postal articles, requiring the Deputy Director-General of Security or a Deputy Director-General to certify warrants authorising such inspections. This procedure is in line with the procedure for the handling of warrants relating to telecommunications.

The amendments to the Trade Practices Act 1974 give the Trade Practices Commission the power to make a charge for supplying a person with material and for permitting a person to attend a prescribed activity. This, I suppose, requires some sort of definition of what a prescribed activity might be in case one's imagination got away with one. One might use the example of a seminar or a workshop arranged by the Commission. Where the Act does not expressly provide for a fee to be charged in relation to a discretionary service, the Commission may charge a fee agreed with the person. The expected revenue from these changes is $33,000 a year.

The Acts Interpretation Act 1901 is amended so that where a law of a State or Territory alters the name of a body or an office a reference in Commonwealth legislation to the body or office by its former name is to be construed as a reference to the body or office by its new name. The amendments to this Act also provide for members of statutory bodies to be able to participate in board meetings by telephone, closed circuit television and other electronic means of communication.

I see that these remarks, or perhaps it is something else, have caused some mirth. I wonder whether what has caused the mirth is the fact that in South Australia the State Bank, which is in such trouble, managed by a quick ring-around by phone to lend hundreds of thousands of dollars over the weekend. I certainly hope that these amendments, allowing statutory bodies to participate in board meetings by phone, do not result in such disastrous consequences for those bodies as this ring-around-loosely described as a form of meeting over the phone-did for the State Bank and, consequently, for taxpayers of South Australia.

As it turns out, the investment of that bank was a very bad one, about which there have been unkind allegations-I do not know whether or not they are unkind-that one of the members of the board had some interest. Questions have been raised as to the distance that that board member kept from that entire matter. I mention that not only because of your mirth, Madam Acting Deputy President, but also because I think that example raises a serious question that the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) might like to respond to about the risks of having board meetings by phone. I look forward to his reply in that respect.

The amendments to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Family Law Act 1975 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 are similar in nature. They delete the provision which is currently present in each of these Acts that the AAT, the Family Court and the Federal Court must seek the approval of the Attorney-General to expend appropriated funds. These bodies operate under the Department of Finance ledger system, whereby the funds appropriated are controlled and released by the Department of Finance in accordance with validated claims submitted by each agency. These provisions are therefore unnecessary.

The amendments to the ACT Supreme Court Act 1933 provide for the court to direct that the master and the registrar are to have interchangeable powers in relation to the winding up of a company. Currently under the Bills of Exchange Act 1909 there are three days of grace added to the date on which a bill that is not payable on demand falls due. This amendment removes that provision which is not in line with general international practice. Such bills will become payable on the last day of the time of payment fixed by the bill.

The amendments to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977 abolish the National Legal Aid Representative Council, and increase the membership of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council from seven to eight. These amendments are expected to achieve savings of some $15,000 a year.

The amendments to the Law Officers Act 1964 are designed to ensure that any person who has served as a Solicitor-General for an aggregate of seven years and who ceases to hold that office will be entitled to a pro rata pension, except if that person is removed from office for misbehaviour. Pursuant to amendments in 1988 such a pension is payable only to a Solicitor-General who has served at least seven years and who has not been reappointed at the end of his or her term of office.

The Opposition had significant concerns about this matter, which was debated at some length in the other place. The shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peacock, was satisfied by the explanation made during the debate in the other place on this Bill that the intention of the amendment is to make it clear that a Solicitor-General who is removed from office owing to disability or following bankruptcy is entitled to a pro rata pension. The amendment will bring the pension arrangements of a Solicitor-General into line with those of other officers of the Commonwealth.

The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), who shares with me and others a position on the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority, during the debate in the other place explained this amendment as necessary because in 1988, when of course the Hawke Labor Government was in office, these amendments were `stuffed up'. In view of the rate at which legislation is shoved through both the lower House and on occasion this place, it is no surprise that mistakes are made. Inadequate time is given to consider the consequences of various pieces of legislation.
The final amendments in the schedule to the Bill relate to the Statutory Declarations Act 1959. They simplify the processes for witnessing statutory declarations.

The Government has also introduced a series of amendments to the Privacy Amendment Act by way of amendments to this Bill. These new amendments relate to credit reference reporting, which was the subject of the Privacy Amendment Act 1990. That Act was first introduced more than two years ago and still has not come into operation. It was to come into operation upon the expiry of nine months after the date of royal assent, which was 24 December 1990. That would have made the commencement date 24 September 1991, a little less than one month from now. Under these latest amendments the commencement date will be delayed until 25 February 1992. These amendments were made available to the Opposition in the other place at the last minute. The shadow Minister for corporate and consumer affairs, Mr Costello, was given a somewhat hurried briefing on these amendments, and the Bill was dealt with in the House of Representatives in the evening following an afternoon briefing.

It is worth mentioning that the Opposition raised many serious concerns in relation to what is now the Privacy Act 1990, and moved more than 50 amendments. The concerns that we expressed at the time included, among others, the exclusion of publicly available information from the permitted contents of a credit file; the distinction between commercial and consumer credit; and the exclusion of general insurers, real estate agents, mercantile agents, purchasers in debt securitisation transactions and trading organisations from access to credit information files.

Briefly, this latest group of Government amendments contains provisions relating to the definition of credit reporting business; agents of credit providers; rights of access to credit information files and credit reports which may be exercised by a person with written authorisation from the individual concerned; telephone applications for commercial credit; the use of credit reports for internal management purposes by the credit provider; telephone applications for credit; advice of a credit provider to joint applicants for credit about a refusal of a credit application; and a range of circumstances in which disclosure of personal information by a credit provider will be permitted, including provisions relating to oral consent, guarantors, mortgage insurers, dispute settling bodies such as the banking industry ombudsman, State and Territory authorities which provide mortgage credit, merchants who provide for payment by credit card or electronic transfer of funds, persons who take on the assignment or discharge of a debt; and last, but not least, limits on use or disclosure by mortgage insurers or trade insurers of personal information contained in credit reports.

The Opposition welcomes these latest amendments to the credit reporting legislation. We maintained at the time that the legislation was seriously flawed, that it was being rushed through, and that the proposal of such a large number of amendments by the Government before the Act even comes into operation would tend to confirm this view. You would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, from your long service on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-I understand that you are the longest serving member on that Committee- of the concern of that Committee for those people in Australia who are affected by our laws and who are expected to follow them. People are expected to know what the law is. You will also know of the queries raised by that Committee when legislation which has been operative for only a limited time is amended. Here we have a Bill which has not even come into operation but which is being amended. Indeed, the Opposition said at the time that the legislation contained serious flaws and needed further consideration. That has been shown to be the case by the Government's introducing amendments.

We particularly welcome the amendments which water down the definition of credit reporting business, and those which allow for the normal commercial practice of telephone applications for loans to continue without insisting on having the applicant's consent in writing at that stage to the obtaining of a credit report.

We also particularly welcome the large number of additions to the circumstances in which credit providers may disclose personal information contained in credit reports, as we understand that these amendments pick up concerns expressed by the credit and credit reporting industries about the workability of the legislation.

It is noted that the Privacy Commissioner is of the view that these amendments do not change the protections given to individuals by the original legislation. I have a copy of a letter from the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate). One comment made by the Privacy Commissioner in the third paragraph of his letter is:
The amendments address reasonable consumer needs or industry concerns.

Well and good; I am pleased he thinks that. What concerns me is why were not these reasonable consumer needs or industry concerns addressed at the time when the legislation was put together? It is not as if everyone was saying, `Yes, this is the right way to go'. It is not as if the Government was not warned that consumers and the industry had some concerns that needed further addressing. The situation is quite simply that, despite the warnings, the Government decided to proceed. I do not want to labour that point any more, but it does bear repeating twice.

In conclusion, the Opposition is not opposing this Bill. The majority of the amendments it makes are technical and non-controversial. I reiterate our support for the amendments to the Privacy Amendment Act as they go some way towards improving this basically flawed piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. As Senator Vanstone said, this is an omnibus Bill largely making changes of a minor policy nature and administrative changes to the legislation. Perhaps the matter that has most substance, as is indicated by the Government's amendment, is the sections that deal with privacy matters-in particular, the credit reporting services and the procedures for credit providers. Senator Powell, who has dealt with privacy legislation in the past, will deal with those sections and I will address myself briefly to the other provisions of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said before, most of the amendments are fairly self-evident and necessary. For instance, I note the removal of the requirement for the Attorney-General to approve the estimates of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Family Court of Australia and the Federal Court of Australia. This is now not necessary since the funds appropriated are controlled and released by the Department of Finance in accordance with fairly strict procedures. In expressing approval for lifting this particular workload from the Attorney-General, I express the hope that this may speed up necessary amendments to the National Crime Authority legislation which I, and I am sure other members of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, eagerly await. The secrecy provisions in that legislation clearly need considerable amendment and the delay is now getting beyond the stage where we can accept it with equanimity.

I turn to some of the other provisions. It is quite clear that the amendments to permit interchangeability between the master and registrar of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court during the course of the winding-up of a company are essentially machinery provisions, as are the provisions that refer to the Commonwealth Legal Aid Act. There are other provisions which may have a little more substance. I refer to the minor changes to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 which are designed to place the Australian Capital Territory on the same basis as a State.

As to the amendment to the Bills of Exchange Act to remove the provisions for adding an extra three days-called days of grace-to the maturity date of a bill of exchange that is not payable on demand, one wonders why that provision was ever enforced before. I also note amendments to section 64 of the Judiciary Act to prevent the application to the Commonwealth and the States in civil suits of laws to which the Commonwealth and the States are not themselves subject. Again, I would have thought that that is essentially a clarification provision. There are other amendments to the Statutory Declarations Act 1959, the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the Law Officers Act 1964. I shall not detain the Senate by making detailed references to those; suffice it to say, that the Australian Democrats support this Bill in its unamended form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Spindler has mentioned, the Government amendments in this legislation also include amendments to privacy legislation in relation to the credit reporting industry. As honourable senators will recall, last year-somewhat belatedly, in the view of the Australian Democrats-the Government introduced legislation extending the operation of the Privacy Act to the credit reporting industry. During the passage of the Privacy Act in 1988 the Democrats had contended that it should apply to the private sector, but we were unable to persuade either the Government or the Opposition to support this view at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Even after the introduction of last year's amendments with relation to the credit reporting industry, we played a constructive role in amending and improving the legislation and in striking what we saw as an appropriate balance between the protection of individual privacy and legitimate industry concerns about its commercial activities. After extensive industry consultations and protracted committee discussions, I believe that this chamber passed a balanced and effective piece of legislation. For all that, it is still possible that minor amendments become obvious even after legislation is passed. In this case, we have the context of the development of the Privacy Commissioner's code of conduct.

The relatively technical amendments that we have before us tonight are aimed at accommodating industry concerns that certain legitimate industry practices would constitute technical breaches of the legislation if left unamended. Most significantly, the amendments deal with the regulation of access to credit histories by the agents of credit providers or for internal management purposes.

As the Commissioner noted in the lead-up to these amendments, it is important that they be carefully drafted so as to minimise the possibility of irresponsible credit providers using them to avoid the strictness of the controls imposed by the Act. Proposed new section 9C, referring to agents, and proposed new paragraph 9F(a), referring to internal management, are the important provisions in relation to the access issue. Proposed new section 9C amends section 11B of the principal Act by providing that an agent of the credit provider can be taken to be another credit provider if the agent is performing a task that is a necessary step either in processing an application for a loan or in management of a loan. This is to avoid the risk of credit providers and their agents committing technical breaches of the principal Act when they are acting properly and lawfully in accordance with accepted commercial practice.

The Privacy Commissioner has examined the clause. He considers that the words linking agency use with `a task that is necessary in processing an application for or in the arrangement of' a loan are sufficiently specific to prevent abuse. Similarly, new paragraph 9F(a) amends the legislation in relation to the permitted use of information for internal management purposes. The use of information is subject to the express qualification that the internal management purposes must be directly related to the provision of loans or the management of credit-such as occurs in credit scoring, for example. Once again, the Privacy Commissioner has looked at this matter and considers that the clause is sufficiently specific to prevent abuse.

At this point I note that the securitisation industry has raised some concerns in relation to these amendments. That industry does not believe that its problems have been solved by the above amendments. I believe that these concerns, as they have been expressed, should be borne in mind as the Parliament continues, as it must and will, to monitor the operation of this legislation. I would draw attention to the Privacy Commissioner's professed view that reasonable industry concerns and consumer needs have been met by the amendments that are before us tonight.

On balance, then, the Australian Democrats welcome these amendments as part of the ongoing parliamentary review of this important piece of legislation-the Privacy Act. Subject to this being confirmed in practice, we share the Privacy Commissioner's view that these amendments do not change the protections originally given to individuals in any way which could reasonably be regarded as threatening individual privacy. If the practice proves otherwise, the Australian Democrats will be the first to move to ensure that the protection of individual privacy is maintained and strengthened. We welcome these particular amendments as part of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank members of the Opposition, Senator Vanstone in particular, and the Australian Democrats, especially Senator Spindler and Senator Powell, who spoke in relation to the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, indicating their support for the speedy passage of its provisions. As was pointed out by the senators who spoke, this Bill deals largely with matters of some technicality and of a generally uncontroversial nature.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of which Senator Vanstone made some mention is typical of that more technical-type amendment. I would like to deal with the question that Senator Vanstone raised of the amendment which inserts a new section 33b into the Acts Interpretation Act. The view of the Attorney-General's Department was that, unless expressly authorised by the relevant Act, a board member of a statutory authority had to be physically present at a meeting for participation in the meeting to be valid participation.

In a technological age, as we all know and have practised at various times from our own offices, it is possible to participate at meetings by way of telephone, closed circuit television, et cetera. Indeed, this Parliament has already passed various Acts making provision for this form of participation, for example section 68 of the Australian Postal Corporation Act of 1989. This provides a means of enabling a more convenient meeting to take place, particularly in a case where several members of national body almost invariably have to travel great distances from various parts of the Commonwealth to participate in a meeting.

Whilst the norm no doubt will be that a meeting will be conducted around a table with all members able to interact at a personal level, the possibility is there for telephonic hook-ups and so on. That possibility has been recognised in other statutes. Specifically, the legislation that we are dealing with will enable that provision, that permission, that empowering, to be available for all statutory bodies without the need to amend all the individual Acts. Of course, that is the purpose of the Acts Interpretation Act type of amendment.

I suppose the more interesting amendments are those to do with the privacy legislation. I thank those honourable senators who have spoken with a degree of understanding about what did occur. The process that the Senate undertook, particularly through its committee system, in relation to dealing with dozens of Government, Opposition and Democrats amendments to the original Bill, was a testimony to the way in which the committee system can operate. I believe that it was the initial test of the committee system and it proved to be extremely efficacious. At the end of the process we had a Bill which was workable and satisfactory in terms of policy from the Government's point of view. I do acknowledge that the Opposition thought that a different structure altogether ought to be adopted which would include real estate agents and insurance agents as persons who would be entitled to access to the credit reports of a person who had borrowed finance from a particular organisation to undertake the purchase of some goods or service.

Putting that major difference to one side, I think it was agreed that that process had led to the emergence of a very satisfactory outcome. We do live in a credit-ridden society, a society where access to funds through borrowing is absolutely essential to ordinary existence. Great privacy concerns have been aroused and misgivings have been expressed constantly in the community about the extent to which persons who have nothing to do with the initial borrower, credit provider or lender can have access to credit files which may not even be accurate.

This Bill attempted to ensure that the credit reports held by lenders or credit reference associations were absolutely accurate and up to date in their information and that they were only made available to credit providers in very specifically delineated circumstances. The Bill emerged and it was passed by the Senate. Then the consultation process was undertaken, as it needed to be, with Kevin O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner at the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission. His consultation with the finance industry and with other interested groups led to the recognition that certain matters might be best clarified by way of amendment in order to ensure that there was absolutely no nervousness in the commercial community about the impact of certain provisions in the Privacy Act. Also, certain technical matters needed to be adjusted and remedies were required to deal with matters of concern. But these were matters that were not apparent at the time of the passage of the Bill.

On the whole, the amendments that are incorporated in this legislation are of a technical or clarifying kind. Indeed, the Privacy Commissioner wrote to me on 12 August 1991 in relation to these proposed amendments, saying:

They do not, in my view, change the protections given to individuals by the original legislation in any way which could reasonably be regarded as threatening individual privacy. The amendments seek to recognise a range of industry practices or consumer concerns which have come to notice during consultation on the Code of Conduct. The amendments address these issues in reasonably precise terms.

That short paragraph contained in the letter from Kevin O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner, indicates why this chamber ought to be very ready to give its assent to the passage of these amending provisions. They do not change the basic protections given to individuals, so essential in this credit-ridden society, in relation to credit reports that may be held about them by credit providers or credit reference associations. The need for privacy of records which ought to be accurate is a matter of great concern to all in this community, based as it is on such a need for credit.

It is necessary to let the Senate know the reason for the decision to delay the effective operation of the majority of the amendments to the Privacy Act until 24 February next year. I was contacted by various members of the finance industry, primarily Alan Cullen, the executive director of the Australian Bankers Association. He had several conversations with me which he reduced to writing. He indicated to me that he thought that the consultative process had been extremely constructive but had nevertheless taken a considerable amount of time.

He indicated that the final emergence of the need for some clarifying and technical amendments and the final form of the code of conduct would apply right up to the proposed coming into operation of the Act on 24 September. Therefore, members of the finance industry and the Credit Reference Association and borrowers would not have sufficient time to accommodate themselves to the changes that might be brought about by the passage of amendments or by the finalisation of the code of conduct. For that reason alone, a delay would seem to be appropriate. Irrespective of the question of amendments or the late finalisation of the code of conduct, Mr Cullen informed me:

Despite the fact that review and development of the systems has been underway, as noted above there are final requirements under the Code to be settled and the Code is then subject to the Parliamentary process. The impact on credit assessment practices and systems, especially where on-line computer links to the Credit Reference Association of Australia and automated credit assessment systems have been undertaken, requires development and testing of both the financial institutions systems and that of CRAA.

Because those computer changes were so extensive, it would obviously take several months for them to be brought into operation. Therefore, I was very happy to accede to the request for a delay in bringing into operational effect the provisions of this particular piece of legislation, apart from those provisions dealing with the entitlement of a person to have access to his or her credit report to ensure that it is an accurate and up-to-date report. That will come into effect immediately, but the other parts of the amendment Bill will be delayed.

I thank those honourable senators who have spoken. I believe that the Senate, particularly in dealing with the privacy Act amendments, has acted in a way which is consistent with policy, yet very sensitive to the legitimate needs of the finance industry to the world of trade and commerce and to the needs of borrowers in this society so dependent on credit. The other amendments are mainly technical, as has been enunciated by Senator Vanstone. I believe that the Senate ought also to pass those amendments as speedily as possible. I commend the second reading to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (DISABILITY AND SICKNESS SUPPORT) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill 1991 gives effect to changes announced in the 1990 Budget which were designed to restructure income support for the sick and the disabled. The Government, by that announcement more than 12 months ago, conceded that for many years the basis for and the operation of invalid pensions and sickness benefits have not been satisfactory. Accordingly, the invalid pension will be replaced by a disability support pension and the sickness benefit by a sickness allowance. The sheltered employment allowance will be abolished; the rehabilitation and incentive allowance is being phased out; and the mobility allowance will be increased from $22 to $40 per fortnight.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has a number of concerns about the nature and extent of these changes, although ultimately we will not be opposing the Bill. I should say at the outset that the change in name from invalid pension to disability support pension tells us quite a lot, because if one goes back to the original qualifications for an invalid pension they were meant to be very tough. In order to qualify for an invalid pension, a person was required to have a permanent incapacity-defined as 85 per cent-of which at least one-half had to be due to physical, mental or psychological impairment. Over the years that very tight standard has been gradually whittled down so that in practice invalid pensions have been granted to persons with impairment levels as low as 15 per cent, leading to an extraordinary blow-out in the numbers of those receiving the invalid pension as a pensioner, a wife or a carer.

Despite the concessions of failure and despite the change of name, the future will probably demonstrate that there has been an even greater weakening of the provisions. Instead of the original concept of effectively total and permanent disablement, we now have a situation where a person can qualify for and continue to receive indefinitely a disability support pension with a physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment of as little as 20 per cent as long as that person has a continuing inability to work for at least two years. A time frame of that duration is certainly quite inconsistent with the original concept of total and permanent disability. The extent of the impairment similarly indicates that this is far from what the original pension was intended to be.

Nonetheless, we welcome the various initiatives in the Bill which are aimed at providing additional support for disabled people. I have already mentioned the raising of the mobility allowance. The extension of health care cards to child disability allowees and the availability of a $200 employment entry payment to people who leave the disability support pension to take on full time work are all supported. These targeted measures make much more sense than simply across-the-board adjustments.

We also support some of the tightening up measures, such as restricting the portability of the disability support pension and the removal of non-medical factors from the pension eligibility criteria. Paying the invalid pension on the basis of socio-economic factors and impairment has led to what can only be described as massive rorting of the pension, leaving little in the government coffers to assist those who are seriously disabled.
