Since bringing in this Bill to the Parliament, the Government has drawn up more than 100 amendments-on the latest count I think it is of the order of 116-and to a great extent the amendments have alleviated the concerns expressed by many of the interest groups who represent people with disabilities so ably. Nonetheless, the amendments themselves are testimony to the abject failure of the Government to consult with these interest groups. In particular, in the face of the statement made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) that he had engaged in very extensive consultations, these amendments just make a mockery of his definition of consultation.

One of the Government's decisions is to remove the penalties clause from the Bill. Perhaps we can deal with this more in the committee stage, but again it seems a trifle incongruous that, on the one hand, a person on the pension is required to undertake training and rehabilitation programs but, on the other, if he or she chooses not to cooperate, there is currently no penalty for refusing to do so. In a sense, that seems to be the worst of all possible worlds. On the one hand, the Government is signalling that it wants to ensure that people are not simply left to languish and where they do have a capacity to undertake those additional programs they ought to be required to do so but, on the other, in not following through with a penalty provision, the Government clearly makes a mockery of that good intention.

In so far as the Bill was supposed to get off disability payments people who should never have been there in the first place, the Bill is a major disappointment-a manifest refusal to bite the bullet. Despite its many changes, the disability payments regime proposed here will still leave Australia with one of the most generous schemes of its kind anywhere in the Western world. Many countries pay disability payments on a partial basis-a part payment to match a part disability-while most link payment levels and the duration of payment to past contributions to cover such contingencies. Some countries still recognise only a total incapacity to work and pay a benefit only on that basis.

In France a disability payment is made available only where the individual experiences a two-thirds loss of earning capacity. This compares with the substantially more generous system proposed in this Bill whereby a person may become eligible for pension if unable to work at award wages or more for at least 30 hours a week. It is interesting to note also that in the Netherlands before a disability payment is made a labour or occupational specialist visits the disability payment applicant's employer or former employer in order to make a better informed determination as to whether the applicant is able to work. Thus the Netherlands imposes this extra eligibility test on its applicants, something that the current Australian regime does not.

The Bill's restructuring of the regime of income support for those people who are temporarily incapable of work due to injury or illness is largely supported by the coalition. The problems with the sickness benefit have in part mirrored the problems with the invalid pension. The numbers of sickness beneficiaries have exploded over recent years. The increase in the number of payments since 1971 has been in the order of 660 per cent. Not only this, but the average duration of time spent on the benefit has risen markedly. For a benefit that was supposed to have been temporary, it is ironic to see significant numbers of people who have now been on the benefit for three or more years. During May 1990 the average time spent on the benefit for all sickness beneficiaries was more than one year; in fact, 56 weeks.

This felony has been compounded by the Government's past lack of resolve in reviewing benefit entitlements. For example, during 1989-90 just 6,500 sickness beneficiaries were reviewed by Commonwealth medical officers out of a total client population of almost 80,000. I note the Government's decision to introduce an amendment to reduce the maximum period of time that can be spent on the new sickness allowance from two, maybe three years, to one, maybe two years. But even then there are some additional extensions that can operate to have the payment made for up to 3 1/2 years. To a certain extent it is heartening to note that amendments moved by the coalition in the lower House have at least evoked some support from the Government in tightening the duration to some extent.

The invalid pension scheme was first introduced on 15 December 1910. At that time the requirement was that a claimant be permanently incapacitated for work. Over time there has been both a de jure and a de facto whittling away of the strict eligibility criterion which has led to an explosion of the invalid pension numbers in recent years. This explosion is one of the great welfare scandals. Since 1983 the number of invalid pensioners has expanded by 52 per cent, way ahead of the increase in the general population of some 11 per cent. To emphasise this point I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a graph demonstrating the explosion of numbers of people on the invalid pension.
Leave granted.
The graph read as follows-
[GRAPH OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1098]

TALK.START.PARA: —We have now reached the point at which outlays on the invalid pension program currently amount to over $2.5 billion. The real scandal in all this is that the Government has done very little to assist those who are seriously and even manifestly disabled but instead has poured scarce Government resources into propping up those people with only mild impairments-people who are more unemployed than disabled and whom this Government has been shoving off the dole queues and onto the invalid pension in a desperate effort to get the dole queue numbers down, a battle which it is now losing in a quite spectacular way.

SPEECH.PARA: I should say that this is not mere speculation on my part. I have had complaints from doctors in three different States who have all reported to me along identical lines that they have had patients come to them and say that they have gone to the local regional office of the Department of Social Security seeking unemployment benefit only to be told that they would be much better off going around the corner to see the doctor and obtaining a certificate entitling them to sickness benefits.

In one instance, a doctor in a country town told me that he had rung the regional office when this first happened and had rung again when it continued to happen, all to no avail. He finally sent me a copy of the letter which he had sent off to the Minister. I assume that, again, nothing has happened in that regard. One would not suggest a giant conspiracy theory that the Government is somehow requiring regional offices of the Department of Social Security to try to alleviate the unemployment queues in this way, but the fact remains that they have been made aware that this practice operates on, presumably, a sporadic basis, yet have chosen to do little about it. It has to be a scandal because not only is it totally inconsistent with the notion of invalidity but also it serves no useful purpose; indeed, it simply encourages people to abuse the system, to become dependent when they do not want to be. When they are genuinely interested in finding work they are really being told that it is quite a simple matter to have themselves classified as not only incapable of work but also, to a significant extent, either sick or disabled. That is the sign of a sick society rather than a sick patient.

The number of people who joined the invalid pension ranks during January this year alone was 802. By April, the monthly figure of new entrants was 1,222. By June it had blown out to 2,516. None of these numbers can be explained by a deterioration in the economic climate. Bad and all as that is, it certainly has very little to do with any sudden deterioration in the health of the population. Clearly, it is a function of a more generous application of the rules by departmental officers. I think that highlights one of the great problems in this area.

The Labor Government's indifference to people with serious disabilities is nowhere better evidenced than by its attitude to disabled persons sheltered workshops. By 30 June 1992 these workshops will be closed regardless of their excellence and the demand for them, leaving many disabled persons who have found employment and the self-respect that comes from being gainfully employed in the workshops to compete in the open labour market with the almost one million able-bodied unemployed Australians for whom, indeed, jobs are very hard to get. Not only this but at the same time that it is forcing the seriously physically and mentally impaired onto the open market the Government has not even bothered to earmark any significant number of places in labour market programs for the disabled. Thus not only will disabled people have to compete on the open market for jobs with other people who are not impaired, but now they will also have to compete with the able-bodied for places in training programs.

Reform of the income support system for people with disabilities is long overdue. As I have just indicated, the explosion in numbers has been due not only to sloppy legislation and its interpretation but also to a far from zealous application and enforcement of the eligibility criteria. A combination of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal taking increasingly generous views of what constitutes incapacity to work and general confusion within the Department about how to implement invalid pension legislation has led to the pension being granted on near negligible medical impairment grounds. In fact, over the period 1988-90, 7,302 people were granted the invalid pension, even though their assessed medical impairment ratings were put at 20 per cent or less. Technically, it is possible to claim the invalid pension with an assessed impairment as low as 5 per cent making, of course, a mockery of the current definition in the social security legislation.

This has been assisted by taking into account prospective claimants' education, age, poor English skills and other factors connected with labour market disadvantage-all matters that are, indeed, quite relevant to determining the degree of difficulty which a person might experience in obtaining work on the open market. Clearly, it is a basis for entitlement to what used to be the unemployment benefit. But by no stretch of the imagination can those factors aggravate one's physical, mental or psychological condition. To no extent ought they to affect the application of the eligibility criteria for invalid pensions or sickness benefits.

So the confusion about what constitutes incapacity for work has also led to many costly appeals to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the AAT. During 1989-90 this led to 1,264 appeals to the SSAT alone over decisions regarding incapacity for work. Michael Horsburgh, a deputy member of the SSAT, has publicly stated that when determining a claimant's eligibility for the invalid pension SSAT members tend to subjectively decide whether they feel the individual ought to get the pension and then to attach an incapacity rating on that basis rather than, of course, the other way around as specified by the Act.

If the Government were serious about making the disability support pension the preserve of the genuinely disabled, allowing for more targeted and specific assistance, it would take real steps to remove from the invalid pension the many thousands who are not seriously disabled and place them on a more appropriate work-tested income support payment basis. As the proposed regime currently stands, the Department estimates that some 2 per cent of invalid pensioners who received the pension on or before 21 August 1990 will have medical reviews scheduled and therefore will have their eligibility reviewed within the year after the introduction of the new regime. This is far from good enough. It will be necessary, but not sufficient, to have an assessed impairment rating of at least 20 per cent under the new impairment tables. The use of these tables is far from perfect and the Government has undertaken to monitor their performance.

The fact remains that, once again, the most serious question of all has not been addressed. What we will find is two streams of recipients. There will be those who got the invalid pension on the easy basis-those for whom a whole range of socioeconomic factors was sufficient to entitle them to a pension. Those people will, in the main, continue to receive that pension indefinitely. Alongside them will be the persons who happened to apply after a certain date and who will suddenly be exposed to a whole range of other criteria. That is a nonsense.

There is no good reason for not reviewing the conditions and continuing entitlement of those who have been on the invalid pension for many years. Indeed, the individuals themselves are often being done a disservice. If they are capable of getting back into the work force, exercising their capability for work, even to a moderate extent on a part time basis, they would be much better served than to be left languishing as second-class citizens in the way that this legislation proposes. It is quite clear that we will effectively have a 20 per cent impairment level being necessary and sufficient and that, as I predict, in due course, we will find that the Bill will actually loosen the eligibility criteria and merely formalise the de facto arrangements that have been operating in recent years.

We will be keeping a very watchful eye on how the system operates. If it is found to be inadequate we will take measures on coming to government to ensure a genuine tightening of the system. In either case, we will sequentially and regularly review all disability support pensioners who are not manifestly impaired in order to redetermine and reassess their eligibility.

As well as questioning the 20 per cent level, we are also somewhat taken aback at the degree of inactivity when it comes to what purports to be an active employment strategy for those with mild impairments and those who will be determined to be labour-market ready. In introducing the Bill, the Government is acknowledging something that everyone else has known for years: there are many people who have been on the invalid pension and who are not significantly impaired, let alone disabled. It therefore seems extraordinary that those disability support pensioners who successfully complete training and rehabilitation programs and are assessed as labour-market ready will be placed back on the pension if they cannot find work. This seems to be a significant departure from that which was originally intended.

A working document on restructuring disability payments obtained from DEET last year shows that the Government was considering the introduction of an activity-tested short term disability payment which was intended for `those with a temporary or permanent low-level disability and who have the capacity for . . . or are now capable of full-time work in open employment'. Its receipt was to be contingent upon undertaking training and Job Search. Now it seems that such people who do not find work will be allowed to slip back onto the pension without a requirement to even search for work. The Government estimates that some 12,000 pensioners annually will be selected for training and rehabilitation. Of these, 20 per cent are expected to find full time work, 30 per cent part time work and the rest-some 6,000 people who have been assessed as capable of work-will simply slip back onto the disability support pension.

Most of the concerns about the Bill which have been indicated to me by various groups appear to have been addressed in the multitude of amendments. Once again, I can only say that the fact that this Bill went before the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs and still resulted in in excess of 100 amendments is very powerful testimony either to the failure of the Government and the Minister to consult with all the relative groups and organisations before the Bill was introduced or sheer incompetence in not being able to draft the Bill despite the fact that we have been on notice about it since August 1990.

I would now briefly like to indicate what will be part of our agenda for real reform in the disability payments area on coming to government. First, we will be earmarking places in government training schemes for those with impairments who have not made the transition to work but wish to do so. In fact, the funds set aside for these people will be significantly increased and the types of programs offered will be enhanced. We will not permit the spectre of the disabled competing against the more able-bodied for places in such programs. Furthermore, we will be targeting the disability support pension far better. Those whose impairment is not significant will not be permitted to remain on the pension. This was what the Government set out to do but what it has miserably failed to do.

We are convinced that there are significant savings which can be derived from an effective eligibility criterion and from effective enforcement of the tests that ought to be in place without jeopardising any pensioner who is seriously, let alone manifestly, disabled. Whilst we are confident that significant savings can be achieved, these will come from targeting those who have been placed on the pension by the Government for socioeconomic reasons and not just those who have come on the pension since August last year. These people will be assisted back to work and, as a result, will have access to higher incomes, higher living standards and real career prospects. Those whose disabilities mean that they could not reasonably be expected to make the transition to work will be provided with more, rather than less, support by the next coalition government.

In conclusion, let me simply say that the changes in the current Bill are a political response to a system which is widely perceived to be out of control. Despite the fact that one of the greatest areas of need in terms of reform relates to those persons who are already on the invalid pension, virtually nothing is to be done to address that problem. As a result, we are seeing what will probably turn out to be largely cosmetic changes.

The Government has not tightened up on monitoring and reassessment. Indeed, in deciding whether or not payments ought to continue, there will not be first recourse to Commonwealth Medical Officers but, rather, there will be reliance continued to be placed on certificates provided by an applicant's general practitioner. That, I would have thought, was simply an invitation to people to get onto the benefit much more readily and unnecessarily. As a result, it is quite clear that the Government is not serious in its monitoring and assessment of these schemes, let alone in raising the eligibility high-jump bar in a way that most other countries have long ago recognised needs to be done.

In many instances we will find persons receiving these payments as proxies for Job Search allowance and Newstart and there will not be the financial capacity to properly address the needs of those who are at the hard end of disability and who are very much in need of continuing government support.

This amendment essentially condemns the Government in terms that I have already addressed for not dealing with those who are already recipients and it expresses concern at the Government's totally inadequate consultation with those persons who would have been very well placed to give the Government advice if it had sought to learn from that. I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:

(a) condemns the Government for failing to extend the proposed reforms to Australia's current unacceptably large invalid pensioner population, with the inevitable result that there will be two classes of pensioners, poor targeting and a reduced capacity to assist the most disabled.

(b) expresses its concerns at the Government's totally inadequate consultation with medical practitioners, health professionals, welfare groups and representatives of people with disabilities and their carers, resulting in serious uncertainties about the reliability and validity of the proposed Impairment Tables as well as over 100 proposed amendments since the bill was guillotined through the House of Representatives.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my remarks tonight by referring to Hansard of 19 June 1991 and reading some comments made by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, at that time. I must add that this was the date when the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill 1991 was supposed to have gone through this place, having been guillotined through the House of Representatives. It was included in a package of three Bills that were supposed to be passed at that time. Senator Richardson said:

SPEECH.PARA: For all those like Senator Lees who think that in some way getting the disability Bill referred to a committee will give those affected time to consider it, I should say that I have been with officers of the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled this afternoon. They are keen to see this legislation passed and implemented. The disability community itself has given a great deal of support to this Bill and takes a different view from that of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS). I would have thought that if we are going to look at who among community groups is actually representing the disabled, we cannot go past their own organisations. They are, by and large, in support of this package. I know that there are those in the Australian Democrats and those in ACOSS who have an absolute view that giving some of these people the opportunity to work is not a good thing. I am not in accord with Senator Lees's views on this and, I hasten to point out, neither are the organisations which represent the disabled. They welcome this package and they reiterated that to me today.
Having read that, I must ask: who did the Minister really consult, apart from the one group mentioned, and what exactly was he talking about with those groups?

As we passed through the committee stage it became very evident that this Bill was far from perfect. Indeed, as Senator Alston has already mentioned, we now have well over 100 amendments. If the Government did not consult with key groups such as the Australian Council of Alcohol and Other Drug Associations and the Australian National Association for Mental Health, why not? Did not the Government recognise these groups as key groups in this area? I understand that the Minister has certainly been talking to these groups in general terms about general disability issues and about areas that obviously do need some reform, but it seems that at no stage was this Bill on the table.

It was the Australian Democrats who pushed for this legislation to be delayed and sent off to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Part of the reason for doing so was our experience with the Newstart legislation. We were determined not to let this Bill also be pushed quickly through the Senate. We were convinced at that stage, after only a brief look at the Bill, that the Government had failed to consult with disabled people, their families and the various disability organisations that represent them. If we look at the amendments before us now, we can see that they bear out the lack of consultation with the key groups who were very concerned-and, indeed, are still concerned-that this legislation was not going to be in any way for the long term benefit of the majority of people that they are representing.

I guess that some comments could be made with regard to how much time the Department of Social Security actually spent with Senator Richardson going through some of these proposals in the Bill. Basically, the Minister came into this chamber and presented a piece of legislation which would have had serious detrimental effects on the lives of thousands of disabled and sick Australians. Indeed, we now still have before us tonight a Bill that is by no means perfect and will disadvantage the very people it is supposed to be assisting.

Disabled groups are asking a number of questions as to why they were not more involved in the lead-up to this legislation, and why the majority of these groups did not even see the legislation until it was passed through the House of Representatives and we had posted it out to them. I will run through the list of groups that made submissions to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. These groups said very clearly to the Committee that they had certainly not been consulted about the detail of the legislation. They had not seen the Bill at the time that the Government-if, indeed, it did-discussed any disability issues with them. At the time that this legislation was supposed to be being discussed, the actual Bill was not before them. They also said very clearly, in varying degrees, that they were not happy with what was in it.

I will just run through those groups that made submissions. They were the Australian Council of Alcohol and Other Drug Associations; Schizophrenia Fellowship of Australia; Australian Council of Social Service; Australian National Association for Mental Health; the Welfare Rights Centre; Disabled Peoples International; Disability Resource Centre; Office of the Public Advocate; Disability Employment Action Centre; Villamanta Legal Service; Victorian Trades Hall Council; Alliance for the Mentally Ill; Women's Information and Referral Exchange; St Kilda Community Health Centre; and ACROD, which I do acknowledge had had some contact with the Government.

In addition, I have been contacted-as late as today-by numerous organisations across the country expressing their concerns about the legislation. Many of these groups have only just caught up with the amendments-which have only been available for about a week and a half-and are now in the position where they are trying to mesh into the Bill the new amendments and trying to make some sense of what is now a very different piece of legislation. Some of those groups that have contacted me are the Consumer Advocacy Programme of South Australia; the Australian Association for Speech and Hearing; Parent Advocacy; Parent and Adolescent Conciliation and Counselling Service; Queensland Council of Carers; welfare rights centres in Canberra, Adelaide and Melbourne; the Association of Relatives and Friends of the Mentally Ill in Victoria and Queensland-and the list goes on.

This says a lot for the Senate committee process and, I must add, the work done by the Committee secretary, Dr Pauline Moore, and her staff. These groups were provided with an excellent opportunity to express their concerns. The Government was ultimately forced to take many of these concerns on board, hence the amendments. One hundred and three changes are, indeed, a lot of changes. We certainly acknowledge that at least the Government was prepared to make these changes and that this late consultation process certainly was very valuable.

Unfortunately, the Government is still ignoring several major concerns about the Bill. The Democrats believe that it would be in the interests of all concerned-and, indeed, may save the Minister some further embarrassment down the track-if the Government, after we finish the second reading stage, deferred this legislation, did a bit more work on it and got more serious about consulting properly with all sections of the disability community. I stress that we really must start putting people before numbers on a balance sheet.

In 1988, the Government Social Security Review, headed by Professor Bettina Cass, produced Issues Paper No. 5: Towards Enabling Policies: Income Support for People with Disabilities. This was a very comprehensive report. Its underlying thread was a desire to provide increased opportunity for people with disabilities to enter the work force. Not many people, if any, would take exception to that goal and it has long been the aim of many organisations working in the disability field. But the Government, claiming to be in pursuit of this goal, has ignored many of the major recommendations in its own report. This total disregard for its own research, combined with the sheer stupidity of forging ahead with the so-called active employment strategy when a million Australians are already out of work, makes a mockery of the Government's professed aims for this legislation.

The actual detail of this Bill clearly demonstrates that the Government is opting for an approach that is based upon misconceptions about the lives of people with disabilities. I believe that it is not much more than another opportunity to further tighten the screws in the social security system.

We still have major concerns about this legislation along with, I must state again, many community groups, people with disabilities, academics and doctors. In particular, we all have major concerns about the elimination of non-medical factors and the use of impairment tables. I will go back to the Social Security Review and its comments with regard to this. It states:

. . . for some people with disabilities `incapacity' to undertake gainful employment may not result from total physical or intellectual inability to perform the tasks associated with the range of jobs for which the claimant is broadly qualified. Rather, incapacity may be the consequence of the interaction of an impairment with other non-medical factors which significantly reduce the likelihood that the person will be able to obtain and hold regular, full-time gainful employment.
Again, we should look at the actual recommendations of the review. Recommendation 7.7 states:

. . . while a major component of reduced potential for substantial gainful employment should be attributable to a physical, psychiatric or intellectual impairment, this would not be established by a rigid threshold level of impairment, but rather by the interaction between:
- level of impairment;
- relevant socio-economic factors (eg age, sex, educational qualifications and skill level, literacy, and previous work history), and
- labour market factors pertaining to the reasonable availability and accessibility of job opportunities which are appropriate to the capacities and skills of the person.

It is further recommended that level of impairment be assessed using the impairment guide currently being developed by the panel of medical experts. It is recommended that the assessment refer to broad bands of impairment denoting effects on function, rather than discrete degrees of impairment, and that the level of impairment assessed in this way be taken as indicative rather than as rigidly determinative. In other words full account would be taken of the possible compounding effects of socioeconomic and labour market circumstances on the level--
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last sitting week I rose to speak on the adjournment debate to address the need for Australia to recognise the independence of the Baltic states. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on the action he has taken in this regard. However, I think it is also appropriate that at this time we cast our minds a little further ahead and consider the consequences of what is happening in the Soviet Union. It could be said that events are occurring so rapidly in the Soviet Union and everything is in such a state of flux that it is difficult to do this. But there are evidently going to be problems in certain areas, if not in the next couple of weeks, in the next couple of months or years. It is the obligation of all of us in this place to consider Australia's reaction to those possible developments.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern relates to the economy of the Soviet Union and the effects it will have on Australia, in terms of both our trade-either directly with the Soviet Union or with other countries, or our competition in markets where the Soviet Union is a large buyer: for example in beef, which I will turn to in a moment-and the consequences for the Western world of a possible default on the Soviet debt obligations. I will address the debt obligations first, because this is an area to which nobody seems to have paid enough attention.

The Soviet Union is one of the world's largest debtor nations. At the moment we are seeing developments which will result in at least some of the republics splitting away from the existing USSR and not joining a new federation. I note, for example, that in the last couple of days the proposals for a new greater Russian federation have been put forward by just 10 republics: Russia, Ukraine, Byelorussia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan, Armenia, Kirgizia, Turkmenia and Tadzhikistan. Of course, a number of republics have sat out of this process: for example, Georgia has been a participant as an observer only; Moldavia has declared that it will not be part of a new federation; and the Baltic states have already declared their independence.

The consequence is that there will be fewer republics to share the Soviet Union's existing debt burden. It is very clear that every one of the republics which wants to break away from the federation will say, `We don't have an obligation for the Soviet Union's debt'. There is very little chance of our being able to persuade these republics to pick up even a portion of that debt obligation. The logical consequence of just the developments to date is really quite simple: there will be fewer republics and fewer people to bear the obligations of the current USSR to its international creditors.

We have already seen predictions that, even if the USSR were to stay together, there is a very high risk of default in the next year to 24 months. For example, I think Westpac predicted recently that the likelihood of a default on the Soviet Union's wheat debt to Australia was quite high. We have to consider what response we will make in the event of the Soviet Union running into difficulty on its debt- particularly as a large portion of that debt is owed on the trade of Australian agricultural exports.

What concerns me, as I am sure it concerns most honourable senators in this chamber upon reflection, is the fact that we cannot afford to have the Foreign Minister agree to write off debts owed to Australia and to Australian farmers in the same fashion as he wrote off the $200m wheat debt which was owed to Australia by Egypt-a $25m cost to Australian farmers. If we were to write off the Soviet Union's debts to Australia just in agricultural commodities, the loss to Australian farmers would be even greater.

At this stage nobody seems concerned with putting a plan in place to deal with possible Soviet default. There seems to be no attempt around the world to consider the ability of the republics which remain in this greater Russian federation to meet their debt obligations. It is my grave fear that in the next 12 months to two years this will become a problem. Unless we give it thought in advance, we run the very real risk of getting caught out.

Of course, this has immediate consequences for our aid program. It has been suggested that we must give aid to the Soviet Union in the form of loans to purchase commodities. Two months, or even two weeks, ago this may have been a viable alternative; but not now. It is my belief that if we are to give any aid to the Soviet Union-especially for the sale of agricultural produce-unfortunately, it must be in the form of assistance with purchases, not by loan but by way of a grant. If we clock up the loan, because of the nature of the incomplete national interest cover of Australian agricultural exports, we will expose our farmers, our primary producers and other exporters to a performance risk by the Russian federation which is clearly unacceptable.

The final area of concern for me is what will happen if the Soviet Union is incapable of buying the agricultural commodities which it has been purchasing in international markets in recent years. For example, what if the Soviet Union does not purchase as much beef as it has in the past? I recently visited the Cattlemen's Union conference. I believe it is of concern to everybody that the Soviet Union may pull out of the international beef market because it does not have the hard currency to purchase beef. We do not export a lot to the Soviet Union but everybody knows who does: the European Community, which faces the very real prospect of a one million tonne stockpile of beef by the end of this year. If it cannot unload some of that stockpile on the Soviet Union, it is not unreasonable to expect that it will try to unload some of that stockpile onto our traditional markets.

Therefore, it is important that we act now to coordinate international efforts to ensure that the events in the Soviet Union do not have a calamitous effect on international commodity markets or international markets for agricultural produce. Accordingly, I believe it is the responsibility of the Government and the Parliament to encourage efforts now to ensure that the beef market around the world does not collapse and drive prices down further for Australian producers. I note that only last week the cattle price index slumped below 110 points. We have to give the matter immediate consideration.

I raise these matters because I believe it is important that Australia looks ahead to the future. There is a prospect of a brighter future, but only if we plan and consider matters carefully. If we do not, we will be caught napping and all Australians will pay-particularly those in the Australian agricultural exporting sector.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Representation of Queensland in Hawke Government

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was prompted to rise tonight when earlier this evening I saw the Secretary of the Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wayne Swan, stalking around the corridors of the Senate.
—It doesn't take much to arouse you.

—It was very interesting and I would think it has quite a bit to do with Senator Collins. Mr Swan is the so-called saviour of the ALP in Queensland. I just call him lucky: he happened to be in the right spot at the right time. But I remind my Queensland colleagues in this chamber that it was only a few months ago that Mr Swan said on the 7.30 Report that he was interested in running for the Senate. I warn my Queensland colleagues from the ALP that maybe that is why Mr Swan is down here.
—They had better duck.

—Maybe he is looking-just checking out the red leather and seeing whether he likes the place so that he can knock a few of his Queensland colleagues off. I wonder whether he is down here just to see what the Senate is like, seeing whether he likes the red leather, or is he down here to make another deal with Mr Hawke? Is that why he is here-to drum up the numbers for the coming leadership challenge?

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that rumours are rife around the building about the next phase of the leadership challenge. Seeing Mr Swan down here today makes me think that there must be something in it. I just hope that Mr Swan is down here this time to keep the Queensland ALP right wing on track and to make sure that it supports Mr Hawke again; that he is down here to do the deal that if he gives Hawkie-Mr Hawke-the Queensland Labor Party people again, they will at least get something back in terms of a few ministries for Queensland. Some good Queensland representation in the Ministry is what is needed in this Parliament.

Mr Deputy President, you will recall that on 15 July I drew the Senate's attention to the fact that Mr Hawke now has the dubious honour of being the first Prime Minister since Federation to preside over a Cabinet without anyone from Queensland in it. The recent redistribution in Queensland makes it appear that there will be even less Queensland representation on Labor's front bench when the Liberal Party defeats one of the sitting members, Mr Beddall, in the southern Queensland seat of Rankin.

In recent times the Prime Minister has paid much lip service to getting people from Queensland into the Ministry. He breezes into the north, where I come from, and keeps saying-as he has done prior to the last four elections-that there are good north Queenslanders who should be in the Ministry, that he knows that they would make good Ministers and that he is considering it. He has done it all of the time and he did it again the other week. Poor old Mr Lindsay, the Federal member up my way, has been overlooked time and time again. The Prime Minister was up there just a few weeks ago again saying what tremendous ministerial potential Mr Lindsay had.

One of the reasons why we do not have Queenslanders in the Ministry is that both of the two Labor parliamentarians from the Northern Territory hold ministerial or Parliamentary Secretary rank. The Northern Territory does not do too badly-it gets two out of two. In Queensland, out of 19 ALP figures we have two junior Ministers and one also-ran.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regional preference is the only way you would make it.

—That is the problem. I suppose the Minister is a little concerned because he does not hold his position by anything other than the Prime Minister's favour. Maybe if there is a leadership change, he would be one of the ones to get knocked out.

SPEECH.PARA: It was reported in the Courier-Mail of last week that there had been a secret meeting of members of the Queensland right wing of the Labor Party to talk about the continuing leadership crisis. I hope that in that secret meeting about the leadership crisis-about whom Mr Ludwig said the Queenslanders should vote for-something was done to extract from Mr Hawke a promise of some additional representation in Queensland. Maybe that is what Mr Swan is down here to do today. Maybe he has seen the writing on the wall. Maybe he is down here talking to Mr Keating and saying to him, `Mr Hawke would not give us any representation, although we supported him en bloc; maybe you will do it'. Maybe that is what Mr Swan is doing down here-trying to extract a deal from Mr Keating to get a few more Queenslanders in the Ministry. If that is what Mr Swan is doing here, he comes with my support. He has got nowhere with Mr Hawke in the past. At least, if he could get a commitment from Keating-Mr Keating-to get more Queenslanders in the Ministry, it would be good for Queensland.

As Queensland Labor people would know-and I do not address you, Mr Deputy President, because you are in the chair-members of the Queensland Right are petrified that they will lose preselection because of threats from the Australian Workers Union. It is a bit the same as Mr Goss being too petrified to sack Mr Prest, the Deputy Whip, for his outrageous racist slur in the Queensland Parliament. Mr Goss will not dismiss Mr Prest, in spite of that outrageous slur, for fear of upsetting the fragile AWU faction with the right wing Old Guard faction in the Queensland area.

The Labor member for Leichhardt, Mr Gayler, quite openly boasts that he has no chance of a ministerial guernsey because of his failure to join the AWU faction in Queensland. It is common knowledge that Mr Gayler may be toppled by the AWU at his preselection because of his tendency for individual thought. I understand that Mr Bates, a prominent north Queenslander, is trying to get that preselection from Mr Gayler. No doubt, Mr Bates will have to come to some accommodation with the AWU. By the way, I would be interested if anyone could tell me which members of the Queensland public elected Mr Ludwig to sort out these matters for Queenslanders; but that is another story.

Labor's leadership brawl is perpetuating some of the many failures of the Hawke Government. It has a Ministry in which Queenslanders are grossly under-represented. I emphasise that this is the first time since Federation that Queensland has not had any representation in the Federal Cabinet. Queenslanders are so under-represented that Mr Goss has had to ask West Australian Mr Kim Beazley to represent Queensland's interests in the Cabinet. Could you, Mr Deputy President, or any of your colleagues, think of anything more stupid than asking a West Australian, Mr Beazley, to represent Queensland's interests in Cabinet? Maybe, Mr Deputy President, I underestimate Mr Goss; maybe he is cleverer than Richo and Senator Ray--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not know whether the honourable senator has been deliberately doing it but he is not using proper titles and then he is coming back to use them. He did not use the proper title at all then. I ask him to refer to Senator Richardson in the proper manner.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Maybe Mr Goss is cleverer than both the numbers man for Mr Keating, Senator Richardson, and the numbers man for Mr Hawke, Senator Ray. Maybe Mr Goss realised a few months ago-long before Senator Richardson or Senator Ray realised it-that the third man, Mr Beazley, would come out on top. Maybe Mr Goss was being terribly clever in getting Mr Beazley to look after Queensland's interests. Mr Goss does not just go around the edges; he goes right to the person who will be at the top.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that if Mr Goss has done that, maybe he has much more intelligence than I have ever given him credit for before. If he has got that commitment from Mr Beazley, that is tremendous news for Queensland. We do, in fact, desperately need some Queensland input into the decisions that this Cabinet makes.

This Cabinet is principally made up of Victorians; 11 in the outer Ministry, nine in the Cabinet. Look at the mess the ALP has made of Victoria and look at the mess it is making of Australia. Perhaps we could get some of them out and try to get in good people such as Senator Colston, Senator Jones and Senator Reynolds, who used to be the only woman on the front bench in this chamber but who was tossed out ingloriously by the Labor Party which claims to be an equal opportunity party.

Mr Deputy President, I just hope that, having seeing Mr Swan in these hallowed halls tonight, he is down here to try to crank up a bit of support for whoever-whether it be his old mate Mr Hawke, or maybe he has switched sides and gone to Keating or maybe he is just following up Mr Goss's--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Mr Keating, thank you.
—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President.
—Show a bit of respect.

—I would, Senator, but it is very hard to do it when you are in the chamber. We must hope that Mr Swan is here to elicit some support from Mr Hawke, Mr Keating or probably, if he is clever, at the bidding of his boss, Mr Beazley-the new Leader of the Labor Party, the new Prime Minister. Whichever way it happens, I would be only too happy if Queensland can get some better representation in the Cabinet and in the Ministry-a much better representation, I might say, than it has at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.50 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Report of the Interdepartmental Committee (IDC) on the Wrigley Report:

(1) Please outline the process used to arrive at the calculation that the relative costs of Australian Defence Force Regulars, Ready Reserves and Conventional Reserves will be in the ratio of 1:0.4:0.1.
(2) Does this calculation of cost include so called `on-costs', that is, those costs additional to salary and immediate training costs.

(3) Did Army Office arrive at higher calculations for the estimated costs of the Ready Reserve proposal than the 0.4 as a proportion of a regular which is referred to in the IDC report; if so, what was Army's costing for a Ready Reservist expressed as a proportion of the cost of a regular.

(4) With reference to the IDC report estimate that the cost of an existing Army Reservist amounts to 0.1 of the cost of an Army Regular, how can this figure be reconciled with the costing contained in the Auditor-General's Report No. 3 1990-91 on Australia's Army Reserve, which found that, `the cost per day of a reserve soldier is more than 50% higher than that of a regular soldier'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The relative costs of Australian Defence Force Regulars, Ready Reserves and conventional Reserves were estimated by comparing their direct personnel costs. In the case of Ready Reserves the relative cost was an estimate based on a possible conditions of service package. That package has now been refined and details are available in the report on the Ready Reserve Program tabled in Parliament by me on 30 May 1991. Following this refinement the estimated direct personnel cost of a Ready Reserve member is now assessed to be about 0.3 of a Regular member. However, as the Ready Reserve Program has no precedent, this estimate can only be validated with experience.

(2) No, these calculations do not determine the ratio of the full costs of Regulars, Ready Reserves and Conventional Reserves. Such ratios would need to take into account estimates of all indirect costs which would include administrative and operational expenses, management overheads, stores consumed and capital costs and depreciation. These estimates, which could have differing confidence levels, would impact differently on Regular, Ready Reserve and Conventional Reserve members and units.

As the ratios are prospective in nature they would also need to include estimates of other matters such as expected wastage rates and the likely impact of major reviews and initiatives such as the Defence Regional Support Review, the Force Structure Review, the Defence Logistic Redevelopment Project, the Defence Commercial Support Program, Program Management and Budgeting, as well as the Wrigley Interdepartmental Committee itself. The confidence levels of these estimates would also vary.

The definition and inclusion of the cost implications of the matters referred to above would have involved many additional assumptions, any of which might turn out to be incorrect. The compounding effect of increasing the number of assumptions involved would increase the probability of the resulting estimates of the ratios of costs having little relationship to actual costs.

In order to broaden somewhat the basis of the estimates of the possible costs of Ready Reserves, however, the Force Structure Review assessed the relative costs of Regular and Ready Reserve members on the basis of their refined direct personnel costs, as referred to above in part (1) of this question, and operating costs. Operating costs were included because of the availability of historical data from which estimates were made. As a result, the report on the Force Structure Review, also tabled in Parliament by me on 30 May 1991, advised that Ready Reserve personnel are expected to cost about 42 per cent relative to regular personnel.

As indicated in my response to part (1) of this question, even the development of relatively simple ratios of direct personnel costs involved a number of assumptions, some of which subsequently have required adjustment. As a result and as recommended by the Wrigley Interdepartmental Committee, Defence will assess the effectiveness of the Ready Reserve Program, including costing aspects, once it has been in operation for some time. In view of the time it will take for the impact of the major reviews and initiatives currently being implemented in Defence to begin to take effect this assessment will be conducted in three years rather than in two years as suggested by the Wrigley Interdepartmental Committee.

(3) Yes, Army constructed a costing model for the Ready Reserve which produced a higher estimated cost of approximately 0.5 to 0.6 of a Regular member. Army has advised that this higher estimated cost was basically attributable to assumptions made about higher throughput of Ready Reserves for training.

(4) The estimate of the cost of an Army Reservist used by the Interdepartmental Committee relates to the annual direct personnel cost of a Reserve soldier. The cost per day estimate made by the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) cannot be compared with this figure.

This is because the ANAO's estimates include components relating to the cost of the Regular Army manpower allocated to Reserve units and indirect costs related to administrative and other support overheads, estimated by the ANAO to be provided to the Army Reserve by other Regular Army personnel and civilians employed in the Army Program. These two elements total almost 60% of the ANAO's total estimated cost for the Army Reserve.

The attribution of indirect costs between Regular and Reserve elements is difficult to assess as Army's cost structure has increasingly been based on the principles of Program Management and Budgeting. This focuses on the cost of particular Force Element Groups which, subject to preparedness requirements, may contain both Regular and Reserve personnel.

(4) Has the uranium broker NUKEM recently purchased the entire Nabarlek stockpile.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Presumably this question refers to a statement attributed to a Mr Yves Thomas of EDF, which was reported in the 12 November 1990 issue of a nuclear industry trade journal, Nuclear Fuel. This would not contravene Australian Government policy from either a commercial or safeguards perspective and would not entail any diminution in Australian export earnings.

(3) Decommissioning and rehabilitation at Nabarlek will take place in accordance with directives issued by the NT Minister for Mines and Energy, under the Uranium Mining (Environmental Control) Act. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 16 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister seen the recent reports in the Australian of 11 June 1991 and statements by the organisation, Friends of the Earth, which claim that continued low uranium spot prices and reduced global demand for new reactor capacity are likely to make expanded uranium mining operations uneconomic.
(2) What assessment has the Minister made of these statements.

(3) What is the Government's response to recent reports by the International Energy Agency which suggest that the consumption of nuclear electricity as a share of total electricity generation is unlikely to increase this decade.

(4) Does the Government intend to take action in relation to Australia's uranium industry as a result of International Energy Agency predictions that there is unlikely to be any growth in nuclear capacity this decade.
(5) How do the International Energy Agency projections of nuclear capacity growth differ from those projections made by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The availability of large stocks of uranium over the past few years has led to increased trading on the spot market and a fall in spot market prices. These developments have adversely affected production at some mining centres. Although spot market prices can be expected to remain low for the short term, the reduction of stocks and the fact that current production levels are well below reactor requirements suggest that, over the medium to longer term, spot market transactions will decrease and prices will rise.

Most international trade in uranium has continued to take place under long term contracts, whose prices do not necessarily reflect spot market prices. In the last few months, for example, Australian uranium producers have been successful in concluding new long term contracts at prices substantially above the spot market. These contracts confirm that buyers are concerned about security of supply and are not prepared to rely entirely on the vagaries of the spot market.

The nuclear power industry is a mature industry. It is to be expected that the rates of growth evident in the early decades of the industry's history should slow as the industry expanded. However, it continues to grow. Western world nuclear generating capacity is currently about 280 GWe and even conservative forecasts expect that capacity will exceed 300 GWe by the year 2000.

As far as the uranium market is concerned and, in turn, the profitability or otherwise of existing or expanded uranium mining operations, new reactor capacity is a small but positive variable. More important variables are the uranium requirements of nuclear capacity currently in operation and, on the supply side, the growing deficit between production and requirements.

(3) The International Energy Agency (IEA) expects that nuclear energy's contribution to electricity generation in OECD countries will increase from 1558.1 terrawatt hours (TWh) in 1989 (23.6%) to 1895.7 TWh in 2000 (22.8%). The very marginal reduction in nuclear's share of total electricity generation in this time frame (from 23.6% to 22.8%) is not significant, particularly in the light of the expected growth in nuclear power in absolute terms.

On 3 June 1991, the Governing Board of the IEA, of which Australia is a member, issued a communique which recognised the substantial contribution that nuclear energy makes in a number of member countries and, consequently, to the overall energy supply and mix of IEA countries. The communique also noted the view that nuclear energy provides an important response to the challenge of stabilising greenhouse gas emissions because it emits no sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides or greenhouse gases.

(4) The assertion that the IEA has predicted that there is unlikely to be any growth in nuclear capacity this decade is not consistent with the IEA's 1990 review of energy policies of IEA countries. In this review the IEA forecasts that nuclear capacity in OECD countries will increase from 261.1 gigawatts net in 1990 to 292.1 gigawatts net in 2000.

(5) The projections of nuclear capacity growth rates made by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) and the IEA are not directly comparable. DPIE's past analyses have been based on supply and demand in the `world outside centrally planned economies areas' (WOCA), the same category used by Friends of the Earth, Greenpeace, NUKEM and many others, but not IEA.

In any event, projections of nuclear capacity growth rates do not differ markedly. All analysts agree that nuclear generating capacity will increase between now and the year 2000. Some analysts expect the growth rate to be about 1% per annum, others expect the rate to be about 2% per annum. For the purpose of assessing future market outlook, demand variables alone are not going to enable reasonable assessments to be made. It is the relationship between supply and demand which will determine the market outcome.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With respect to the Government's promise that no age pensioner will pay income tax after 1995:
(1) What work has so far been done on the cost of this promise.

(2) How is the promise to be implemented and how does the Government intend to ensure that superannuants living on low incomes but not receiving the age pension and who will therefore presumably still be liable for income tax after 1995 are not put at a severe relative disadvantage compared with age pensioners.

(3) What is the estimated cost to revenue of removing all age pensioners from the income tax system after 1995 and, if this promise is to be extended to non-age pensioners but who are of age pension age, what will be the cost to revenue of this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The taxation treatment of social security payments is a matter for the Treasurer. I have, however, consulted with him and the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Officers of the Departments of Social Security, Treasury, Finance and Veterans' Affairs have met and are examining various implementation strategies for the 1995 removal of age pensioners and equivalent service pensioners from the income tax system. The strategies are being considered against the criteria of equity, efficiency, simplicity and maintenance of incentives for income maximisation.
(2) The exact implementation mechanism has not yet been finalised.

The honourable senator refers to `superannuants living on low incomes but not receiving the age pension'. Superannuants who are ineligible for pension on the ground of income have incomes in excess of $17,867 pa if single and $30,004 pa if a married couple. It is a matter for conjecture whether $30,000 and above is generally regarded as a low income.
(3) The cost to revenue will depend on which implementation methodology is selected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many times per year are recipients' eligibility for the sole parent pension reviewed.
(2) When review forms are sent to sole parent pensioners, is information on JET enclosed; if not, why not.
(3) When review forms are sent to sole parent pensioners, are these forms accompanied by information making sole parents aware of Employment Entry Payments (EEP); if not, why not.

(4) For 1990-91, how many sole parent pensioners received EEP and how does this compare with the Department's estimate of the number who would receive such payments prior to the start of the 1990-91 year.
(5) How many sole parents who became ineligible for the sole parent pension as a result of a return to full-time employment in 1990-91 received an EEP.
(6) How many sole parent pensioners are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders.
(7) How many JET participants are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders.
(8) How many Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander sole parent pensioners received EEP during 1990-91.
(9) How many JET Advisers are: (a) female; and (b) male.
(10) How many sole parent pensioners received EEP in 1990-91 but who were not JET participants.
(11) What was the average number of JET interviews the average JET adviser conducted per week for 1990-91.
(12) What is the usual duration of a JET interview.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answers to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 1986 persons granted sole parent pension, with the exception of recently bereaved widows, are required to complete a review form at 4, 8 and 12 weeks after the date the claim for pension is lodged. After that initial period, all sole parent pensioners have their eligibility reviewed by completing a form each 12 weeks while pension is payable. Since January 1990 selected sole parent pensioners are personally interviewed either 8 or 12 weeks after grant depending on the likelihood of a change in their circumstances. In addition, selective reviews of sole parent pensioners based upon the possibility of incorrect payments are done at any time. A Budget initiative announced on 20 August 1991 was that the percentage of sole parent pensioners interviewed at 8 or 12 weeks after grant will be increased from 30% to 50% beginning on 11 December 1991.

(2) Review forms are bulk mailed to sole parent pensioners to minimise costs. Sole parent pensioners are serviced by 210 regional offices and 27 local offices; JET Advisers are located in 80 offices. On a trial basis, JET information has been included on two occasions with all review forms in Tasmania. In other States, individual JET Advisers are trialing distribution of JET information with the review form given to sole parent pensioners at the pre-grant interview which they are obliged to return four weeks after the claim for pension is lodged. JET information is also being handed to sole parent pensioners when they return subsequent review forms. It is intended to extend the distribution of JET information in this way.

(3) The Employment Entry payment (EEP) was introduced from 1 January 1991. All sole parent pensioners were advised of EEP through information on a card insert which was included with their 12 weekly review form during the period 1 January to 1 April 1991. The 12 weekly review form also contains a message alerting sole parent pensioners to their possible entitlement to EEP. In addition, sole parent pensioners are advised about the availability and eligibility requirements of EEP at their pre-grant interview. JET Advisers also inform sole parent pensioners about the payment in preparation for work entry.

(4) For the 6 month period from its introduction on 1 January to the end of June 1991, 12,656 sole parent pensioners received an EEP. This compares with the estimated number of payments of 7,500 for that period.

(5) Of the 12,656 EEPs made for the 6 month period 1 January to 30 June 1991, 2,448 sole parent pensioners had their pensions cancelled following payment of an EEP. Some of those remaining on pension may have been working full-time, but their income still enabled them to receive part-rate pension.

(6) As at 21 June 1991, 6,791 current sole parent pensioners had self-identified as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders. This may not be a complete record of participants from these groups as, for privacy reasons, it is optional for social security recipients to declare their Aboriginality.
(7) 308 JET participants have self-identified as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islanders. This may not be a complete record of JET participants from this group for the reasons in (6) above.
(8) The number on record is 194 and is subject to the qualifications at (6) above.
(9) As at 31 July 1991, there were 67 female JET Advisers and 13 male JET Advisers.
(10) Of the sole parent pensioners who have received an EEP in the 6 month period 1 January 1991 to 30 June 1991, 10,104 were not JET participants.

(11) In 1990-91, 32,000 JET new client interviews were conducted by JET Advisers. On average the number of JET interviews conducted before November 1990 was eight per week. After November 1990, when JET Advisers had the assistance of clerical support, the number of interviews conducted on average by JET Advisers was twelve per week.

The first full year of operation of the JET program will be 1991-92 with 80 JET Advisers in place for the full year. The average national target number of new interviews per JET Adviser per week is 12.5.

Conducting new client interviews is only one part of the JET Advisers' weekly workload. Their other duties include follow up of established clients, including second and subsequent interviews; liaison with Departmental Officers, e.g; Social Workers, Aboriginal Liaison Officers, Migrant Liaison Officers and Officers administering the earnings credit and child support schemes and other support provisions; liaison with the CES and other areas of the Department of Employment, Education and Training; liaison with the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services and JET Support Workers on child care provision; liaison with State Government agencies and Community agencies; liaison with secondary and tertiary education bodies; generating client response through invitation letters, outreach activities with community and welfare organisations and sole parent pensioners, distribution of information materials and placement of local advertising about the program; post-interview follow-up of JET clients; and telephone contact with JET clients.

In most areas, and particularly in rural and regional locations, time is also spent travelling between regions where visiting services are provided. Currently the JET program provides a visiting service to 132 centres. In addition, in some JET locations, particularly those servicing special needs clients such as remote Aboriginal clients or those of Non-English Speaking Background, the nature and needs of the client population mean that the JET Adviser must spend more than the average time per client.
(12) The average duration of a JET interview is around one hour.

Travel by Scheduled Commercial Services: Ministers are entitled to first class travel at official expense for official purposes within Australia and to Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Norfolk Island.
The spouse or nominee of a Minister may also travel for official purposes.

As determined by the Remuneration Tribunal each dependent child of a senator or member may travel at official expense on a maximum of 3 return visits at economy class between Canberra and the electorate each financial year. With the prior approval of the Minister for Administrative Services the cost of travel at economy class (or at first-class if accompanying the Minister or spouse) for a dependent child will be met for:
1 return visit to any place within Australia each year;
travel to and from Parliamentary functions in Canberra attended by the Minister or spouse; and
return visits between the nominated principal residence and Canberra when the Minister and spouse are in Canberra for lengthy periods.

Charter Aircraft: Ministers are entitled to use charter aircraft for official purposes in circumstances where scheduled services are not available, or where to use scheduled services would not enable the Minister to keep an official commitment.

Special Purpose Aircraft: Ministers may use Special Purpose Aircraft for official purposes for travel within Australia and overseas in accordance with Principles for the Use of Special Purpose Aircraft (tabled November 1990). The flight is to be authorised by the Prime Minister or the Minister for Defence.

Car Transport: Ministers and their spouses are entitled to the use of official cars for official purposes. Ministers may utilise self drive cars for official purposes. Ministers may if they wish have access to the backbench private plated vehicle entitlement under terms and conditions determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

Overseas Travel: With the prior approval of the Prime Minister, Ministers may travel overseas in the course of their duties. The cost of travel by an accompanying spouse or nominee and (in most cases), one member of personal staff will also be met. By government decision Ministers do not have access to the Remuneration Tribunal's provisions in respect of overseas study allowance for themselves and spouse or nominee while holding Ministerial office.
Postage: Ministers are entitled to postage in relation to the duties of their office.

Staff: In accordance with the provisions of Part 111 of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 and Determinations which have been made under the Act, Ministers may engage, under an agreement in writing, three electorate staff and a number (set by the Prime Minister), of personal staff to assist them in meeting their portfolio responsibilities. Similarly in accordance with Part 11 of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, Ministers may with the approval of the Prime Minister, engage consultants under the supervision of the Minister or the Secretary of the Minister's Department.

Office Accommodation and Facilities: In addition to the backbench entitlement to an electorate office Ministers may establish Ministerial offices in the capital city of their home State, or may upgrade their electorate offices to become combined Ministerial/electorate offices. In a combined office my Department provides basic furniture and equipment to the limit of a backbench entitlement. Any additional equipment required by Ministers is provided by the Ministers' departments.

Ministers' departments may also make Ministerial office accommodation available within departmental holdings. When visiting a city where they do not have their own office or suitable office accommodation within their departments holdings, Ministers may have access to visiting Ministers' suites if available.

Certain entitlements and facilities which arise from the performance of a Minister's portfolio duties and responsibilities are provided by the Minister's home Department and include official home telephone, official hospitality and newspapers.
My Department provides to the Opposition Office-holders entitlements similar to those listed above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services the following supplementary question, without notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister be challenging the allegation in the Age newspaper of 20 June this year which claimed that up to 30 (homeless) students from one Victorian school had recently had their AUSTUDY allowances cut without warning or explanation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The article in the Age newspaper did not identify the school where homeless students are alleged to have had their AUSTUDY payments cut. From the numbers quoted in the paper, however, it is likely that the school is a particular Melbourne college where there is a high concentration of students receiving assistance under the homeless rate.

As part of the Department's routine enrolment and attendance checking procedures, the Principal of that college was sent a list containing the names of 74 students at his school receiving AUSTUDY. Based upon advice provided by the college about these students, adjustments were made to the payments of 27 students, including 11 receiving payments at the homeless rate.

The college has stated that it is supportive of action taken by the Department to adjust payments where a student cannot legitimately explain an absence from school. Many of the 27 students who had their payments adjusted were absent for lengthy periods without reasonable explanation and a number had actually left school. The school had made special arrangements to meet the circumstances of homeless students who might otherwise have difficulty providing evidence when their absences were justified.

The Melbourne office of the Department followed its standard procedure of double-checking adjustments to payments of homeless AUSTUDY students, in order to minimise the possibility of penalising students without just cause.
